talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the House:
(1) agrees to amendment No. 21 insisted upon by the Senate;
(2) does not insist upon amendments Nos 1 and 3 disagreed to by the Senate; and
(3) agrees to the consequential amendments made by the Senate to the bill.

Honourable members on both sides of the House may well note that the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 has had a relatively long, interesting and colourful debate in both chambers—some would say it has been an exercise of democracy at work. It is worth noting at the outset that the government's intention, in amending the electoral and referendum provisions arising from the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the 1996 election, has always been to improve the integrity of the enrolment and voting process.

On 12 May 1999 the House agreed to all but two of the Senate's amendments of 18 February 1999. The two amendments not agreed to by the House of Representatives were Senate amendments Nos 21 and 26. The Senate has insisted on amendment No. 21, and the government is prepared to accept that. Also, the Senate did not agree to government amendments Nos 1 and 3, which related to assisted voting provisions. As a consequence, the opposition moved further amendments in the Senate, which received support from the government, to reverse the anomaly created by the Senate's acceptance on 18 February 1999 of the assisted voting amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. This will ensure that the assisted voting provisions of both acts remain consistent.

In short, the assisted voting provisions of both acts will remain unchanged. The government obviously preferred its original amendments, but it does not intend to pursue the matter of assisted voting at this time as it is a matter currently under consideration by the inquiry of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters into the 1998 federal election.

I ask that the House accept the Senate amendments in order to ensure passage of the remainder of the bill. Much work and discussion has taken place among all political parties in both houses to secure the passage of this bill, which includes important reforms and important amendments. This is commendable, and I commend those amendments to the chamber.

talk.start.para: —The opposition strongly supports the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 as amended by the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the requested amendments be made.

In so doing, I would just like to make a couple of points. The amendments are necessary only because the opposition in the Senate failed to agree to the bill being classified as noncontroversial, which would have allowed it to have had passage in June of this year, and the implementation date of 1 July 1999 would then have been able to have been met. The opposition chose, however, to not give this status and, indeed, to move amendments to the bill which were all defeated in the Senate.

It is necessary to have a new commencement date in order for elderly Australians who are in residential care to have those new protections that are afforded by the bill. Perhaps it is well to recap on precisely what this means. The government amendments to the bill, as I said, simply change the implementation date. The bill itself amends the Aged Care Act of 1997 and the Aged Care (Consequential Provisions) Act of 1997 by introducing a number of measures to aged care structural reforms and by addressing some administrative and procedural issues that had become apparent since the implementation of that legislation on 1 October 1997.

The bill introduces a range of resident protection measures and addresses anomalies in the act in relation to the revocation of approved provider status and the imposition of sanctions for breaches of provider responsibilities under previous aged care legislation. This bill also implements the 1999 budget initiative to exempt from paying an accommodation charge those nursing home residents who were in care at the commencement of the Aged Care Act in 1997 and who would otherwise be liable to pay an accommodation charge on moving to another aged care facility. The implementation date for the budget initiative was, as I said earlier, 1 July 1999; and those people who would have had a refund as of that date have in fact been penalised by the opposition's failure to let the bill pass by 30 June 1999.

The bill was introduced into the House on 10 June 1999 and was passed by the House on 23 June and, despite acknowledging the desirable nature of the resident protection and the charge repayment measures included in the bill, as I said, Labor refused to grant the bill noncontroversial status. I might add that, at the time, I did point out that the shadow spokesman Senator Evans had put on the record that he thought the bill was implementing good measures and that he would help it through. That did not turn out to be the case. Due to that occurring, the bill could not pass by 30 June and allow the starting date of 1 July. This means that people who were in nursing homes when the Aged Care Act was introduced can still be asked to pay an accommodation charge on moving to another facility after 1 July 1999. People should recognise that this is simply because of the refusal of the Labor Party to acquiesce in having the bill declared noncontroversial and in fact moving amendments which were all defeated.

In addition, repayment of charges already paid by qualifying residents is delayed, pending the passage of the legislation. The government amendments are therefore necessary to ensure that elderly Australians do not suffer as a result of delays in passing the legislation. The government amendments ensure that people who become charge-exempt residents after 1 July 1999 but before the passage of the Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 are covered by the provisions exempting the principal home, and rental income earned on a principal home to pay for accommodation charges, from the pension income and assets test.
These amendments merely change the date from which the bill will become operational. It is a regret that it was not able to be done as from 1 July 1999, for the reasons I have just outlined.

talk.start.para: —The minister certainly does have a hide coming into the House and complaining about the timing of the Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 . The whole bill is necessary because of the mess that the government made of its so-called aged care reforms which were introduced in the 1996-97 budget. If you want to know what has gone wrong with aged care in this country, you have simply to look at the bill and go through the provisions, because each of the provisions is there to fix the government's mistakes through its mishandling of aged care.

speech.para: The biggest element of all of that is that the government's problems came about because they cut $0.5 billion out of aged care in their first budget, at the time that they were talking about reform. That was a so-called reform which did nothing to benefit older Australians and did everything to benefit the government's friends in the industry. The requested amendments that are coming back from the Senate are the government amendments that are required because the bill was not passed by 30 June 1999; but you have to look at why that was not the case.

We even have the extraordinary suggestion by the minister that somehow the Australian Labor Party did something wrong because we moved amendments. It is an interesting view of parliamentary scrutiny and democracy in this country when we have a minister who is prepared to go to the box in the House of Representatives and say that the opposition dared to move amendments to try and make the Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 a more satisfactory bill.

You have to look at the whole timetable of what this government did. In 1996-97, we saw the reforms introduced. For day after day in this chamber, the former ministers—the member for Pearce, Judi Moylan, and the member for Bass, Warwick Smith—said that there were no problems. They said that aged care reform was going well. But, after much agitation and campaigning from elderly Australians themselves, and with leadership shown by the then shadow minister, the member for Jagajaga, we finally saw on 5 March 1998 an aged care amendment bill come in to try and fix some of these problems. The second reading speech was given in the Senate on 26 March 1998, and then the bill simply disappeared. The government chose not to pursue it—because to pursue it in the lead-up to the October 1998 election would have been to acknowledge the mess, the difficulties and the confusion that were being created by the government's reforms. So they put political expediency before good public policy by not pursuing those changes prior to the last election.

They had a number of other changes as well at that time, one of which was the problem of the move to coalescence. As 1 July 1998 was approaching, it appeared that there needed to be a response there, and the government announced that the Productivity Commission would have an inquiry which was to report to the government by 13 January 1999. The commission report was finally made public on 31 March 1999, but we still did not see, in a whole range of areas, any real move by the government to pursue change. This bill was tabled in the House only on 10 June 1999. It was debated only in this chamber—the opposition at the time had not even had time to consider the bill in appropriate detail and to move amendments here. That is why we had to move them in the Senate, and we foreshadowed that at the time. There is no surprise in that. (Time expired)

debateinfo.title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (MORE JOBS, BETTER PAY) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 28 September, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Bevis moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
(1) "the House condemns the Government for introducing a bill which:
(a) further entrenches unfairness and bias in the existing industrial relations system;
(b) ensures that the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is further restricted and the independence of the Commission is compromised;

(c) reduces the minimum conditions available to all Australian workers by further undermining the award system as the dynamic framework for the protection and advancement of wages and conditions, through further award stripping;
(d) denies Australia's lowest paid workers any further wage increase unless their award is stripped of basic entitlements such as long service leave, superannuation and paid jury service leave;

(e) further removes workplace and enterprise bargaining from the protection of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, placing it solely in the hands of the Office of the Employment Advocate, which is run by one the Minsters former senior personal political staffers;
(f) further weakens opportunities for employees to organise and bargain collectively;
(g) aggravates problems of inequality for women and the most vulnerable in the labour market;
(h) further restricts workers who are denied proper industrial protection in their state from accessing federal protection;
(i) prevents the Australian Industrial Relations Commission from conducting much of its traditional conciliation role;
(j) further dismantles the framework for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes;
(k) amends the termination of employment provisions to limit an employee's right to pursue an application and extends the cost provisions;
(l) emphasises the punishment and prevention of industrial action rather than its resolution;
(m) unduly hinders the entry and inspection of premises by relevant organisations;
(n) demonstrates a lack of balance in freedom of association provisions;
(o) fails to ensure that Australia's labour standards meet our international obligations; and
(p) has a short title which is deliberately misleading and fails to represent the actual intention and impact of the bill; and

(2) the House also condemns the Government for its eagerness in tabling a bill that will specifically strip workers of their basic rights while failing to protect workers' legally accrued entitlements in cases of corporate insolvency; and
(3) recommends that a new bill be introduced which:
(a) delivers fair and equitable outcomes for Australian workers;
(b) preserves basic conditions for all Australian workers;
(c) provides for an independent commission with the appropriate power to conciliate fairly and settle disputes; and
(d) provides jobs and income security.

talk.start.para: —As I was saying last night before the adjournment debate interrupted this debate, in my cynicism I believe that some of the deals we have seen being made over the past few months between the coalition government and Democrats have only paved the way for the Democrats to support this legislation in the Senate.

speech.para: I want to examine a couple of the main aspects of the bill now before us. With this amendment bill, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is seeking to destroy the effectiveness of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in order to pave the way for the commission to be totally replaced with his hand-picked Employment Advocate. For nearly 100 years, the AIRC has fulfilled the role of an independent umpire in any industrial disputation or worker negotiations. It has operated independently of governments and trade unions over that period. The AIRC has provided a comprehensive and transparent process of conciliation and arbitration, and this will be all but destroyed if the Democrats in the Senate pass this legislation.

This bill will restrict the IRC's role of compulsory conciliation to only those disputes which involve allowable matters, and I will talk further about how those allowable matters are being diminished to zero. If workers or employers want to engage the IRC to conciliate or arbitrate in any other disputes, then somebody will have to pay. We have here the introduction of a user-pays system for a service which for nearly 100 years has provided practical benefits for governments, employers and employees. The minister also plans to introduce seven-year terms for commissioners. This step would take away any last vestige of independence. It means that the hire and fire of commissioners will depend on the political colour of the government of the day.

As well as stripping away the independence of the IRC, this bill also seeks to further strip awards to a bare minimum. This bill will ensure that awards contain only basic minimum wages and conditions. Under the terms of allowable matters, we will see awards stripped of skill-based classifications, tallies and bonuses, long service leave, notices of termination and even jury service. Awards will be stripped further and workers' rights eroded further by disallowing from awards transfers between locations, training or education provisions, record keeping of hours of work, make-up pay for accidents and union picnic days, and transfer rights of employment. We will also see the abolition of maximum or minimum hours of work for regular part-time employees.

What security does this provide? How can part-time workers plan their lives when the hours they work are at the whim of the employer? What about when a worker reports for jury service or takes up military reservist training? What happens to their jobs? They do not know, we do not know, but I will bet the minister pushing this legislation knows. What kind of working environment is this government providing for workers? One that is steeped in insecurity and uncertainty without the conditions of employment which they and generations of workers before them have struggled for and have achieved.

I turn now to workers' rights to organise and to unionise, their rights to be represented, their rights to a fair go. Employees, whether or not they belong to a union, do believe that unions are needed and are of benefit to workers. Employers recognise and appreciate the role of unions. Most employers enjoy the good relationship they have with the union representing their own workers. The only person with an apparent ideological bent for destroying unions and their role is this minister. He is even trying to outlaw any workplaces which have a work force with union membership greater than 60 per cent. If this bill passes through the Senate, it will pave the way for Reith's mates in Patrick and Rio Tinto to sack 40 per cent of their unionised work force and to replace them with non-union scab labour. They tried to do this under the existing legislation and they failed. Now Reith is providing more tools but they will fail again, not in spite of this legislation but because the Australian community—the wide and diverse group in the Australian electorate—believe in fairness and a fair go. The whole community mobilised against Corrigan and Reith and their tactics before and they will do so again.

Another attack on workers and unions which will be enshrined in this legislation is the extension provided for individual agreements—those secret contracts which alienate workers from their traditional award and union coverage. These agreements will be made even more secretive as they will be able to be implemented from the date they are signed rather than from the date they are approved by Reith's mate, Jon Hamberger, as the Employment Advocate.

talk.start.para: —Order! The member for Charlton has an obligation to refer to the minister by his title.

—The agreements will also be legally able to undercut collective agreements even though those collective agreements are still in place. Another dire, unheeded warning which was given by the trade union movement at the initial discussions on the implementation of individual contracts will have been warranted if this bill is passed. It will allow worker to be pitted against worker. In this bill, the minister proclaims the right of employers to discriminate between employees. For two workers performing comparable tasks, an employer will be legally entitled to offer each of them different individual contracts with different pay and different conditions of employment.

speech.para: In the last week we have seen in relation to the East Timor dispute how that is happening in Telstra with the support of the government. We have seen Telstra workers under award coverage being offered different consideration for their military reservist leave than those who are on individual contracts. Those on individual contracts are being given more leave and more entitlements than those who are staying under their award coverage. It is a disgrace that two workers in the same government owned corporation should be pitted against each other like that.

The minister's continued ideological attack on unions is also included in this legislation. This bill will severely limit a union's ability to enter a workplace. For the workers' representative to enter an employer's premises to hold discussions with employees or to investigate breaches of awards or agreements, the representative must have a written invitation from an employee union member and that invitation cannot be more than 28 days old. This legislation will also severely impede the unalienable right of workers to take industrial action.

I would now like to talk for a moment about the kinds of workers, the kinds of people and the kinds of organisations that the minister is seeking to attack and destroy with this legislation—the trade union movement and those workers within the trade union movement who have taken strong stands in our local and national communities as well as in our international community. In the early 1940s we saw the waterfront workers take action on the waterfront by refusing to load on the boats pig-iron that was headed to Japan to be sold. At that time Japan had already invaded Manchuria, and its aggressive militarism and its expansionist intention were all quite clear. The Waterside Workers Feder ation at that time said that the pig-iron that was being sold to the Japanese would come back as bombs, and they refused to load it.

Further on from that, the MUA in the most recent conflict in East Timor was one of the first groups to mobilise and take action to enforce sanctions against the Indonesians. In Newcastle the MUA mobilised and refused to load two vessels bound for Indonesia which were in the port of Newcastle. The loading of these vessels was delayed for about two weeks. The Cape Moretan had a regular route around Indonesia and South-East Asia. There was an agreement with the shipping company that all non-Indonesian cargo would be loaded but that the Indonesian cargo would not be moved, and the ship departed without the cargo. This was due to the actions of the MUA in Newcastle. Another ship, the Arktis Fantasy, had a regular run to Freeport in Indonesia. This vessel had been loaded up primarily with Indonesian cargo. It remained neither discharged nor loaded for about 10 days.

A point that was made at various public meetings around Newcastle in relation to the East Timor conflict was that Patrick—the same company that the minister employed to enforce his workplace relations legislation previously—said to its unionised work force during that time that, if any Patrick workers on the waterfront took part in any sanctions against any Indonesian vessel as part of industrial action to send a message to the Indonesian government, they would not be penalised under the minister's current Workplace Relations Act. I commend Patrick for that stance, and I would encourage Patrick to take further such stances in light of the minister's encouragement for them to use the tools that he provides to destroy the unions.

I might also say on that point that had the minister and this government been successful early last year in the waterfront dispute in their total push to destroy the MUA then the action that the MUA took on the waterfronts across the country and in Newcastle in relation to not loading Indonesian vessels would not have been able to occur. Those Indonesian vessels would have been loaded in Australian waters and would have passed through unfet tered, and the Indonesian government and the Indonesian military would have seen that as a sign of concurrence with their actions at that time.

In the short time I have left I would like to mention another person. This person is one of the people who will be destroyed if this legislation is allowed to pass unfettered through the Senate. We are talking about people here who have given their lives to the rights of workers—fighting for conditions and entitlements for workers in their particular industry. The man I want to refer to is Mick Watson, the northern district president of the CFMEU. He is based at Cessnock, and he has spent his entire life in the mining industry.

To give an indication of the kind of person Mick Watson is, when you go into his office on the wall there is a photo of him with Nelson Mandela, taken when the international trade union movement held a meeting in Johannesburg in South Africa. They are the kinds of people that Mick Watson attracts—people like Nelson Mandela, people of integrity. Mick Watson is a man of integrity. In an article recently published in the Newcastle Herald, Mick said:
It's been a tough four years; with the industrial relations campaign waged by the Federal Government's Peter Reith and the flagging state of the coal industry.

He said the coal industry is the worst it has been in the 31 years that he has been in it. Over the past three years, 3,500 jobs in the mining industry went in the northern district. The article also went on to say:
Where other union memberships have crumbled, the miners have been the strength.

Mick Watson boasts that he has lost only 30 people to individual contracts out of 5,000. The workers and the employers place their trust in the trade union movement. It is a trade union movement which supports its workers; it is a trade union movement which works well with employers.
He also makes the point that the workers in the mining industry had a victory over the federal government's handling of the financially stranded Oakdale miners. He said that:
`It was just unfortunate that we had to shut the pits for 24 hours to prove the point' . . .
And he added:
`We were arguing for $6 million and it cost the industry $24 million.'
That was all because the government could not and would not take the necessary measures earlier on to provide the correct entitlements for those workers.

Mick Watson said that he is going to stay in this game. He is going to stay in the industry, he is going to stay representing workers' rights. If the minister's legislation is allowed to pass through the Senate, then it is going to destroy people such as Mick Watson, people of the integrity of Mick Watson. These are the people who keep up the fight against conservative governments, who have done so over the past decades and who will continue to do so.

The minister did not win in April last year on the waterfront with his existing workplace relations legislation. With the second wave of industrial relations legislation that he is proposing now he is not going to win while the trade union movement is as strong as it is and, while it has people such as Mick Watson, the workers will always succeed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The self-proclaimed prince of power has paraded before this parliament pronouncing `More jobs, better pay'. Let me say here that the people I represent, the people of Paterson, do not see him as a white knight with a key to the future. In our region, where unemployment is twice the national average, people see him as the politician who uses dogs and thugs in the name of reform. This is a government that spent $350 million to get rid of over 1,000 jobs on the Australian waterfront. They claimed it was reform. The benefits would be immense, they said. They spent $350 million when everyone knew that what was needed on our waterfront to achieve efficiency was investment in equipment and infrastructure to modernise our docks.

speech.para: The short title of this legislation is an illusion. It is not only an illusion but a slap in the face to workers and their families, the people in my electorate. This legislation is a personal and ideological vendetta for Peter Reith, the Minister for Employment, Work place Relations and Small Business. The Reith vendetta will see workers in my electorate compromise their basic working rights in a thinly veiled disguise of what he calls reform.

The Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 reveals the illusion of reform that the Howard government is intent on trumpeting. This legislation is put forward by a government that stood opposite us thumping the table saying, `If only the opposition would allow us to make it easier to sack people we would employ more.' How easy do they want it to be to sack people? What a cynical approach to the development of Australian society. Where is the vision in this approach? How on earth can you fabricate a positive title like `More jobs and better pay' out of a negative? And that negative is retrenchment, and the word `retrenchment', as it echoes around the Hunter Valley today, strikes fear into the thousands of families where there is no breadwinner.

This minister has not been there since BHP announced its closure, since the mines have shed 2,000 jobs, since the Aberdeen Meatworks closed shedding 400 jobs, and he has the audacity to come in here and say, `This legislation is more jobs, better pay.' How can you respect a minister that has such audacity? To me, my colleagues and the workers of the Paterson electorate, this negative focus on retrenchment makes this legislation an ideological joke.

The title of this legislation belies the real push of this government. That real push is to do away with awards, to do away with penalty rates and to increase the competition between workers for the few full-time jobs that may exist. Obviously, this becomes a cut-throat world very quickly and, quite frankly, I think it will come as a surprise to the government that Australian workers do not want this type of dog-eat-dog world. They want job security, they want a valued lifestyle for their families. The workers of Australia believe they live in a community, not an economy. And how can an individual worker demand a fair go when there is such a large pool of unemployed?

We have seen reports from the transport industry in the last week that drivers are being forced to work longer hours to guarantee that they have a job. This cutthroat approach has led to increased accident rates and a transport industry that not only threatens workers but threatens workers' lives. It threatens the lives of all people who use the highways if we overwork our transport drivers, but this government would claim that is a small price to pay for the supposed reform they have brought about.

This week in question time I have listened intently as both the minister for workplace relations and the Deputy Prime Minister have praised the decision to do away with tallies in meatworks. In northern New South Wales these days you have to look pretty hard to find a meatworks—they are virtually all closed. Since the Howard government came to power, they have closed the meatworks at Gunnedah, they have closed the meatworks at Macksville, they have closed the meatworks at Grafton and earlier this year they closed the meatworks at Aberdeen. Well over 1,000 regional jobs have gone, jobs that will not return. The economy of those towns and their communities will face an undeniable and irrevocable downturn because those sorts of jobs do not come back to those communities.

The Deputy Prime Minister claimed that these reforms would yield greater efficiency and cheaper costs to the producer. There was no mention of workers and no concern shown for the 400 families at Aberdeen—in an area adjacent to his own electorate—where jobs are certainly at a premium. They do not exist. The associated mining areas in that part of the Hunter Valley have also shed over 2,000 jobs in the last couple of years. How about the efficiency and the cheaper costs that the Deputy Prime Minister refers to? Meat producers in the Hunter Valley, the cattle growers, are now paying $80 a head to have their cattle shipped live to Dinmore in Queensland for slaughter. Is that efficiency? Is that the reform this government is driving—driving jobs out of rural and regional Australia into our metropolitan areas? If that's efficiency, if that's reform, Australia can do without it. There is not a single export abattoir in the Hunter Valley today. Workplace relations such as those being proposed by this minister will ensure that not another one will take its place.

I also noticed in today's media that Justice Michael Moore has ruled that employers have a legal right to make the signing of Australian workplace agreements a condition of employment. This is a further push to oust the unions as representatives of workers' rights. Perhaps this was envisaged by the minister when he introduced this legislation a few months ago because he said:
These reforms will continue to give workers and employers at their workplace more choice and more opportunities to manage their relationships without the forced interference from unwanted parties.

The unwanted party that he refers to is the union—unwanted by this government, unwanted in the case of some employers. But in the case of many workers I know it remains the only organisation that they can turn to for a fair deal and that understands their needs—the needs of their family and of their community. This government has shown by many pieces of legislation, by the slashing of services to communities, that they do not particularly care about workers and workers' families.

I would suggest to the minister that there is no way he would have budged for the miners at Oakdale if it had not been for the strength of the CFMEU. The continual confrontation with the CFMEU to ensure that those workers got their just rights made this minister back down. But how many other thousands of workers out there are waiting for their rights? Many of them do not have a union to represent them. This minister would say that is good. He also knows that because they do not have a union to represent them they will not get their rights. They will never see their long service leave, their holiday pay, their sick leave. All those entitlements they contributed to while they were employed they will never get. This government will not ensure that they get them.

The Howard government has a perverse and tedious paranoia about unions. I am proud that I come from an area where union strength is a major part of the community. It is about the brotherhood of people. This legislation is all about reducing the power of the unions. Would the minister like to tell us how much his department has spent this year to advertise and promote a non-unionised work force? How eager he and his department are to tell workers, `You don't have to belong to a union; the government will look after you.' We are seeing how the government will look after workers.

The vendetta by the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, the Hon. Peter Reith, against unions involves a worker negotiating their own workplace agreement and in the event of a dispute appealing to the new conciliation commissioner, for a flat fee of $500. When there is a dispute because somebody does not like some of the conditions and they appeal, they have to front up and pay $500. Five hundred dollars may be a minimal amount to the minister or an employer, but to the breadwinner of a family $500 can be a month's repayment of the mortgage. It can mean being able to eat that month or not, it can mean the family having a holiday at Christmas or not and it can mean having something in the Christmas stocking or not. Five hundred dollars may be a nominal amount to a minister, but it is a gigantic amount to a worker simply to register a dispute. Once he does that, what happens to his job? His job is placed in jeopardy. The employer is aware that the worker is not content with the workplace relations, so how long will that job last?

In June the minister said that workplace relations does not only involve economic considerations; it is also about fair dealing between employers and employees and about social considerations. Australian workers are not stupid, Minister. Australian workers know full well where you stand and what you believe in. The same minister made the following statement when addressing a luncheon in Perth this year:
. . . let's not forget whose side we are on . . . let's not forget we are on the side of private capital.

This is a statement by a minister who does not realise that our society should be, and can be, a symbiosis of workers and employers. That is the ideal and that is what any minister should be promoting. But this minister is not doing so. This minister would rather promote conflict than consultation. This minister does not want peace in the workplace. He wants competition, because he knows that when there is competition between workers for the thing they value most—a job—that will drive wages down.

talk.start.para: —It hasn't. Their real wages are up, Bob. They never achieved that in all the time you were in office.

—The minister opposite might like to come to the Hunter and explain that to the 1,500 who will walk out of the gates of BHP for the last time with no job and no job prospect. That is the situation and it is something the Howard government will always be condemned for in the Hunter region. It took no step to stop BHP closing that steelworks—a steelworks that has been seen as the lifeblood of the Hunter region for the past 80 years and more.

speech.para: The rhetoric of this government about work, family life and social consideration means absolutely nothing, and Australian workers will not be fooled. The Hunter region has one of the highest unemployment rates in the country, with a skills drainage out of the Hunter. The shameful thing is that most Australians like to consider that we have a family way of life. If you have a family that lives in the Hunter, be prepared that as soon as your children get to workable age, they will leave the Hunter. They will go to one of the capital cities because there are no jobs in the Hunter. That is a shame because the Hunter is diverse and it is one of the most productive regions in the whole of Australia. It has a larger population than has Tasmania and it is the biggest coal port in the world. It produces 85 per cent of the state's electricity, yet it cannot provide jobs for its own young. And the minister says, `Well, that's part of the small price of reform that we have to pay.' As I have said, this is an ideological vendetta at the expense of thousands of workers in my electorate. I have no shame in claiming I represent workers. I represent the workers of my electorate. The people of Paterson have one important and indispensable asset to barter with—

talk.start.para: —As long as they don't work for the forests. You will not look after forest workers. You won't vote for the RFA when it comes back here.

—I find it interesting that the minister opposite wishes to interject. I am quite happy to stand on my record of supporting forest workers. I also find it interesting that the minister, who has known that the New South Wales government signed off on the RFA for the North Coast last November—it has been with the minister opposite since last November—will not sign off. I can tell the minister that already they have stopped taking woodchip from the sawmills because they will not allow a carryover from 1 January. Until the minister signs off, that woodchip cannot be exported. Already there is a downturn in employment in the timber industry because of the action of the minister sitting opposite. Minister, your leader said the other day that you were the champion of blue-collar workers. All I can say is that you need to get your act together and realise that 10 months is a long time to sign off on state legislation.

speech.para: The workers of Paterson have only one important and one indispensable asset to barter with—and that is their skills and their labour. This asset not only feeds their families and creates a valuable and enjoyable lifestyle but also benefits the whole of the country, as we develop our regions and our productivity. This government shuns this asset. It regards it as a commodity to be devalued and dishonoured. I support the amendment that this government should be condemned because of the stance it takes on Australian workers.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—I most certainly do.
—Please proceed.

—There is no completed regional forest agreement for New South Wales, other than the Eden agreement that has been signed. There has never been a document delivered to me that would meet all of the regional forest agreement processes. The process continues up there. It was delayed dramatically by the New South Wales government. I challenge the member to prove his claim, because he has misled the House.
—Order! The minister has made his personal explanation. He will not debate the issue any further.

—Like the two previous speakers, I come from the Hunter. On a daily basis, I see the impact of this government's attack on workers and on ordinary Australian people. Nowhere in this country have the workers and the people of an area felt the cruel changes brought upon them by this government more than in the Hunter. Each day in every way this government attacks the workers and the people of the Hunter and Australia.

speech.para: The Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 —`More Jobs, Better Pay' is a most inappropriate name for this bill as it is a blatant attack on all Australian workers—is about reining in the pay and conditions of workers which will result in the disempowerment of workers and workers working long hours with reduced benefits and conditions of employment. There is also a more subtle decline in workplace safety which will result from the workers being forced to work long hours to earn a survival wage and avoid being sacked.

It really is disgusting that workers are working in conditions where every day their safety is put at risk. This will increase with this legislation. There is now a disincentive for employees to report any breaches of occupational health and safety rules. I know of one place in the Hunter where they employ contract labour. Let us face it: this legislation increases reliance on contract labour. It leads to a further casualisation of the work force. At the workplace I referred to, if a contract labourer actually reports an accident, they are not brought back the next day because there is such an oversupply of labour that an employer has the choice of terminating that worker's employment. That worker stays at home and waits until maybe the labour hire company decides to give them a call and offer them employment in another workplace.

I know of an instance where a worker had a steel pole go through his leg. Instead of calling an ambulance for the injured worker, the employer insisted that he be taken to a doctor who immediately said, `Why wasn't this worker taken to the hospital?' The reason the worker was not taken to the hospital was that it was the second accident at the company that week and they would have been investigated by the WorkCover Authority.

This is hardly a pleasant picture of workplace safety and what we have to look forward to in Australia. This is not pleasant legislation either. It is going to lead to a worsening situation. It is driven by an anti-union philosophy and a sheer hatred of unions. It does not recognise that workers or unions have a role to play in the workplace and stopping employers using unsafe practices. Under this legislation, a worker has to give a written invitation to invite a union into the workplace with 28 days notice. By the time that union gets into the workplace, the employer will be able to give a picture of being a model employer doing all the right things. When the union goes, they do the wrong thing again. Then 28 days later they have cleaned up their act again, but the employee has probably gone because the name of the employee who invited the union in must be written on the invitation. It is a very unpleasant picture.

The government in this parliament believes that the employer is the boss and the boss is supreme, and whatever the boss says goes. They are setting up a situation that totally disempowers workers, where the workers and the boss are against each other. That creates division within the workplace. The idea is to force the worker into submission, rather than have a healthy scenario of the workers and the employers all working together for the good of the business and for the good of the country. The government will not achieve harmony in the workplace or increased productivity with this 1950s style industrial relations. Employers need to appreciate that workers take pride in their work. They are there not only because they need to earn an income but also because they are Australian and want to see our country thrive. I believe you can only achieve that in an environment of harmony, respect and safety.

This legislation will make fundamental changes to our industrial relations system, changes not only to the pay and condition of workers in Australia but to the face of our entire society. It undermines the system which has developed over many years to address the inequities that arose out of the industrial revolution. It is always important to adopt a historic perspective when you look at new legislation. In this case, it would seem that history is repeating itself.

As we all know, Australia was settled in 1788, and that was because British jails were overflowing. Why was that? To answer that question, we need to look at Britain at that time. It was as a result of the Industrial Revolution. Parents were unable to feed their children. They worked long hours under appalling conditions and lived in absolute poverty.

There was a breakdown of the family. There were Oliver Twist type workhouses where children were living, separated from their families. There were orphans and children of the street. The children themselves were chimney sweeps and going down the mines. It was a really appalling situation and a sad society—a society falling apart at the seams. It was a society not coping with change, a society that had no hope for the future. It was a society where crime raged, where jails were full and where people lived without security.

We must compare that to Australia today. We have a country of haves and have nots. We have a country where children today go to school with empty stomachs and where the schools have to feed the children. Children live in abject poverty in conditions that those on the other side of this House would not understand and could not understand in their wildest dreams. The incidence of family breakdowns is at an all-time high. Kids work. Nowadays you have children finishing school and then going to their job at McDonald's or Coles and working long hours just to survive.

We have a society where drugs are rampant and where young people look to the future and wonder what hope there is. What is the government's answer to this? This second wave of industrial relations reforms, reforms that are going to lead to less hope, poorer working conditions and a further breakdown in our society. We need to look at crime. Crime is at an all-time high. Our jails are full. People in Australia feel very insecure. We are always hearing about how people are feeling unsafe in their homes. Why is this? People in Australia have no hope. They do not have the security of knowing that they have jobs and that they will be able to get good pay, or that the jobs they have will survive and that there is hope for the future.

This legislation is unfair and un-Australian. It moves to strengthen the minister's first wave of industrial relations reforms—or so-called reforms—and create the society of post-Industrial Revolution Britain. The Labor Party was born as a result of the changes forced on society because of that industrial revolution. It came about to redress the imbalance of power that existed between employers and workers and situations where the employer was supreme and could just dictate to workers what they did, how they did it and under what conditions. It also looked at reducing the working hours. Over a period of time, since the Labor Party has been on the political scene, there has been a reduction in working hours. There is fair pay for a fair day's work. There have been improved working conditions and job security. These are all things that have evolved because of the union movement and because of the fact that the Labor Party has been on the political scene moving in there to see that the bosses do not have all the power.

The first wave of industrial relations legislation actually led to an increase in working hours. Anyone who listens to the news or reads the newspapers will see that the number of unpaid hours being worked by workers has never been greater. This is a legacy of the first round of industrial relations changes that have taken place. Executive workers are getting an increase in their working benefits, their conditions and their pay while on the other hand workers—ordinary, average Australians—are being attacked. Their working conditions are being eroded. They do not have the security of knowing that they will go to work and that their job is going to be a full-time job. As the previous speaker said, we are faced with the closure of BHP, which is devastating for the Hunter region.

I, along with all Australians, was brought up to believe that it is right to share and that it is wrong to succeed or benefit by exploiting someone else. I think that that underpins our society. As a child, if you had some lollies, you shared those lollies with your friends. You did not keep them all to yourself or go into a little corner and eat them all. It is all about sharing and making sure that there is enough for everyone—that the wealth of the country goes around. Even our religious philosophy in this country has always encouraged us to care for other people, to share with other people and not to succeed at the expense of somebody else.

In Australia we have a philosophy of fairness. I believe that we have always been committed to fairness. But this second wave of industrial relations legislation will lead to a winner-take-all mentality. In Australia we are part of a society. Australia is composed of states and territories, communities and individuals living in those communities. That is our strength. Our strength is in our sense of community, with everyone working together and everybody caring for each other. We thrive because we are a caring society. We thrive because we care for each other. We thrive because we stand together. We will not thrive if we are a divided society. That is what this legislation does—it divides us. It puts the employers against the workers.

The economy supports our communities and our society. The society and the communities are not there to support the economy. In this country we could be forgiven for believing that we are all about the economy, and that the economy is not about us. Businesses, workers and pensioners are all part of a community, and we all have a role to play and all those roles are important. Unfortunate ly, Minister Reith and the Prime Minister and his government do not recognise this. If they did, we would not be considering this draconian, anti-worker legislation today. This legislation is designed to create division and to erode the independence of our industrial relations system. Minister Reith has built his reputation on attacking workers. We have only to look at the maritime dispute and at how he supported Patrick's and the mass sacking of workers and at his reforms that have delivered nothing to Australia. It is symbolic of this government's approach to industrial relations.

This second wave legislation attacks workers and their opportunity for security and career development. That is a very important aspect, because if Australia is to succeed in the world arena we must be a knowledge based society, a society that is at the cutting edge in the area of technology. We must have a highly educated and highly skilled work force. But part of this legislation actually affects the skills based career path of workers. This will affect the progression of workers within a company and it will also lead to a lower skilled work force. Instead of us being out there at the cutting edge of society, out there on the world market with this highly educated and skilled work force and with our Australian know-how and our ability to bring innovation and new ideas to the world scene, we will be left behind because this government is offering a disincentive to workers to better themselves through a better education and more knowledge.

We are going to end up with a divided, two-tiered society, and that can lead only to social destruction and a society that we do not want here in Australia. We do not want to go back to the post-Industrial Revolution era. We do not want to go back to the time when Australia was settled. We do not want to have our jails bursting at the seams. We want to have a caring, inclusive society where every member of our society is as important as any other member.

I think the Treasurer understands a little better than the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business that there is this two-tiered society developing in Australia. In the Financial Review over the weekend he pointed out that there are workers in Australia living on $15,000 a year—not $15,000 a week like some CEOs. It is important for employers and those in big business to understand that there are a lot of people out there struggling to survive. If we go through with this legislation, if this legislation is forced on Australian workers, then it is going to be a sad day for Australia. This legislation does not recognise the value of workers. It seeks to take Australia back to the days of the Industrial Revolution. It seeks to pit worker against boss and it seeks to destroy our society. That is what it is going to do. It is going to lead to the disintegration of our society as we know it here in Australia. We need to have an inclusive, caring society where every person is part of that society and we can all embrace the new millennium with open arms.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on the amendment to the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 , a bill which demonstrates this government's duplicity and its cleverness with words because the legislation is called the `More Jobs, Better Pay bill'. We now have this peculiar situation in parliament where all the legislation coming forward has trick titles—the title is opposite to the actual legislation. We all on both sides of the House know that the idea that this is actually about more jobs and better pay is an absurdity. But, from this minister who deals in mirages or nightmares, this is perhaps not surprising.

speech.para: We have the Employment Advocate whose main job seems to be to try to get stuck into unions and fine union activities on job sites—it has nothing to do with employment at all. This is the same minister whose cleverness with switching from being a monarchist to a republican to a monarchist to a republican almost monthly is famous nationwide. We sat here week after week while he denied any knowledge of what was occurring at Patrick's or in Dubai. We heard those protests. We knew he was not being honest with the House. The legislation now has quite other objectives. It is not about more jobs and better pay; it is about gutting the functions of the unions in the workplace and about disempowering—

talk.start.para: —What about the workers?

—The minister from the North Shore has a really good knowledge of shop floors around Australia! This is what happens here—these guys come out of the North Shore of Sydney and sit here and tell people how to run their businesses. This legislation is about war. In a place like Newcastle, this government is trying to get my employers to go to war with their workers. This is about trying to incite war between employers and workers.
—That is ridiculous.

—Minister, you go back and tell your friends on the North Shore that the employers in Newcastle do not want a war, they just want to work with their work force. They want to work with them cooperatively because they know they will get the best that way. That is no better demonstrated than in recent times at BHP. So go back to the North Shore and learn a bit about what is happening on the shop floors.
—What have you ever done in Newcastle?

—I have spent the last four years trying to fend off what you are doing in Newcastle. This minister has helped cut 500 jobs from the federal payroll in Newcastle. The government has cut services. I have got 1,500 people being retrenched tomorrow. For the first time in history, those men will not have access to income support and most of them will not have access to job placement support from the government. It is the first time for many decades. Who is that done by? It is by this minister, sitting here rabbiting on that he knows what it is about and about what is happening in Newcastle.

speech.para: These guys should hang their heads in shame. What they have done to my community is absolutely appalling. They pay lip-service to involvement. Go to Newcastle and talk to the employers. Ask them whether they want this legislation. The fact is that they do not. This government is going to heavy employers to make them do it. This govern ment wants employers to go to war with their workers. Why? Because of its ideology. We are back to the dear old days of Thatcherism when there is no community, just individuals. Put them against each other, put them to war with each other and it is much easier to control them.

This is about ideology. We have watched here month after month while this government gets caught up in its ideology versus application. Its view of the world is so warped and twisted, as shown by the title of the bill—`more jobs, better pay': what a warped way of putting forward legislation. The government's view of the world is so distorted by its 1960s ideology that it really has lost the plot. The tragedy is that in the process it has damaged this country enormously. We have seen events in recent weeks in other spheres of government activity which are so damaging to this country, to its work force and to all of its people. Who is going to pay for all that? The BHP workers who have just lost their entitlements. Entitlements to income support have been given to people being retrenched for decades and decades, but that is now gone. Where has it gone to? To make up the surplus which the Treasurer boasts is his surplus. It is not his surplus; it is paid for by the workers of this country. Now it is going to pay for the fiasco in foreign policy.

This legislation being debated today is timely in the sense that it does contrast the real world and the government's world, the nightmare that they live in: the demonising of unions, the demonising of workers and the whole attempt to divide our community and our employers. Tomorrow we are going to see 1,500 people retrenched at BHP Newcastle with the cessation of steel making. That is going to be a very difficult period for those people and for our whole community. But make no mistake, we will soldier on through that. We are a tough community, we are tough people, and we adapt. The question is whether we should have needed to and whether what is being done in terms of that is appropriate.

The great lesson out of this last two years—one is now seeing it mentioned in the media increasingly—is the level of cooperation between that work force and their management. The figures demonstrate that the reliability, the productivity and the safety record of the plant in the last two years have never been better. It is absolutely astounding. BHP management have been quite stunned to find that the more they deal with their people on a close and personal basis the better results they are getting.

There was an annual dinner just a few weeks back in Newcastle of the Australian Industry Group, the old MTIA but now called AIG. The guest speaker at that dinner was Mr Bob Every, President of BHP Steel Australia wide. His speech was quite riveting in that he gave an outline of the history of Newcastle and BHP Newcastle which was both germane and beneficial. Then he stopped speaking and brought on five workers from BHP to finish his speech for him. The five workers went through the events of the last two years within their own personal working lives. What they conveyed to a dinner of 400 of Newcastle's leading industrialists and businesspeople, particularly in the engineering and metals field, was that they have, like never before, learned to cooperate and work together. Apparently these five people gave a presentation to all of BHP Steel management a few months earlier—some 60 of the senior management—and got a standing ovation. The message they gave was that, by working together and cooperating, staff and management had actually all improved their performance and, what is more, they had enjoyed their work more.

The stories they told were absolutely fascinating. One man said he had been taken ill at work and when he woke up in hospital the first face he saw was his supervisor's. He said, `That never used to happen. The idea of a supervisor coming in to see me in hospital was unbelievable. He actually cared about me. I couldn't believe he actually cared.' He said, `I then found out that not only that but he had actually arranged for a taxi to bring my wife in as well.' Another worker talked about the birth of their first child and the flowers that arrived from the work group in the plant. In other words, there was actual caring for each other across the demarcations. The staff- worker divides and all those things have actually been forgotten in the last two years. The results are phenomenal. They went through story after story of improvement, of change, of their self-esteem, of their confidence and of their greater satisfaction—all the things one looks for in a working life these people talked about. The response they got at the end of the performance was truly amazing.

The tragedy of that speech that night was that it took a closure of steel making to bring that lesson forward. What BHP are actually saying now and what was said publicly that night was that they have learned more about industrial relations and about management of their work force in the last two years than ever before in the previous 83 years. What is more, they are applying it and will be applying it into the future. Talking to the people at the dinner later that night, it was obvious to me that the lessons had not been missed. The people who were there, managers and owners of businesses right across Newcastle and the Hunter, were all applauding the comments that had been made but they were also endorsing the sentiment. The way to greater productivity, the way to better quality and the way to improve economic performance in a company is by better utilising your greatest asset.

As one of the people said that night to BHP, `You invest in us and we'll look after your business.' That was coming from a person, a straight BHP worker, who understood a very simple thing that the government has not even thought about and does not want to hear about. The message that was coming out that night was so powerful, and it is a shame that the ministers of this government do not go and listen to those kinds of people because that is where the real issues are.

talk.start.para: —Oh?

—They are not on the North Shore of Sydney but on the shop floors and in the meeting rooms. The dialogue between workers and management has been taking place across this country for the last 20 years. In Newcastle we actually have a quite unique industrial history. Back in August 1982, when the current Prime Minister was then Treasurer in the Fraser government, BHP announced the retrenchment of 5,000 people overnight. We dropped 5,000 on-site jobs overnight and as many jobs off-site within months.

speech.para: The government would not even come to Newcastle to talk to anybody. We tried to get to Newcastle a minister who would actually talk to us about it; no-one would even come. Some ministers in the government now, like the Minister for Defence and the current Prime Minister, were ministers in that government in those days and they would not come near us. We could not get anybody to even think about it. We had to do it all by ourselves. We had to work our way through the most difficult and challenging problems faced by industrial areas that this country has ever seen, and we did that.

We changed faster than anybody in the world. I have been to other steel centres. I have been to Liverpool, Birmingham and Dusseldorf. I have looked at steel centres around the world and our adaptation in Newcastle was faster than that of any of those steel areas. So my community responded to that challenge with no help from those opposite. When Labor came into government in 1983 we instituted a program to help retrain people, to help companies to restructure and to help shift the focus away from price and across to quality, performance and marketing. How come we are exporting? How come our manufacturing exports have gone up so much? Was it because of those opposite? Of course it was not; it was because of the workers and the managements of our companies who learnt how to compete in manufactured products in world markets.

The performance of our companies, particularly the ones in the Hunter, has been absolutely staggering. All through that period of adaptation, multiskilling and the dropping of demarcation, the whole process of adapting and making our work force more productive was based on cooperation. It was based on the need for the workers and the management of an organisation to work as a team and to work together for common objectives. We have done that like you would not believe. And what happens now? The government brings in legislation to remove all that, to remove all the underpinnings. All the sense of equality, all the sense of inclusiveness and all the sense of ownership are being taken away so what we have in fact is back to the battlefield.

We are going back to the 1930s, not to the 1960s. This is back to the 1930s stuff, when ideology ran rampant. This has nothing to do with reality—this does not relate to the real world. There is no serious manager in Australia who wants this legislation. The government is forcing it on the community and on management and it will then try to force companies to actually apply it and generate the kinds of scenes it wants to see. It wants the nightly news to have footage of workers and management at war in a pitched battle of some form.

talk.start.para: —Oh?
—We have already seen it on the damn docks, for god's sake, Minister.
—Really?
—Don't go into your fantasy for the North Shore of Sydney. Go back up there and tell them all that stuff. They might believe you; we in the real world don't.
—You're in the real world?

—We are faced daily by the issues of industrial relations, of workers working together, of getting our quality right and of getting our performance right, and you lot opposite simply sit there and pontificate about nonsense. This is nightmare stuff. This legislation is a waste of money, it is a waste of time, it is a total distraction to the country and it pushes us in exactly the wrong direction. It goes all in the wrong direction.

speech.para: Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Productivity and profitability are not about this legislation. They are about performance. They are about investing in your work force and making it the best it can possibly be and telling it that it is the best.

speech.para: The conversion of our work force more and more into casual, part-time, body-hire processes—and the escalation of that in recent years is quite staggering—undermines the skill base and the long-term continuity of organisations and simply puts us on a price performance-only basis. We will never be the cheapest at anything; there is always someone cheaper. Any country that focuses itself on price alone is being absolutely suicidal.

This government is ratcheting down wages, step by step by step, by undermining the basis for negotiations between workers and their management. If you look at the European economies of Sweden and Germany, they are not the world's cheapest; they are the world's best in a whole range of issues.

talk.start.para: —Why?
—We were getting to be the world's best in a range of products.
—Yes, but why?

—Look at the export of electronics, Minister. Where did that come from? Did you generate that? You had all those years in government before we came in. In 1982, in that one year alone, our manufacturing work force dropped by 10 per cent. With John Howard as Treasurer, in one year our manufacturing work force dropped by 10 per cent. Why did that happen, Minister? Why was that? Because of the mentality in this legislation. Because you generated a wall between the work force and their management. Who suffers? We all suffer. In those wars there are no winners: we are all losers and we are all victims.

speech.para: What we have here now is not a government on the sidelines as a cheer-squad like it used to be. Now it is right in the battlefield. There is a wonderful irony here. We have the architect of Dubai and the Patrick's scam of shifting a work force into a shell company with no capacity to pay its entitlements. We have the great scheme that was put forward in the Patrick's exercise engineered by the minister, yet the same minister brings in, a few weeks ago, legislation while trying to tell us he is actually going to protect entitlements. Jekyll and Hyde have nothing on this guy! Jekyll and Hyde are kindergarten stuff while these people are seriously schizoid, and malevolently so. They are manipulating the Australian work force for ideological ends, because they think there are still votes in that old 1930s hysteria. The fact is that not only are there no votes, Minister, but there will be disaster for the country. After tomorrow we will stop exporting a billion dollars worth of steel a year.

talk.start.para: —That's rubbish.
—A billion dollars worth of steel will be stopped from being sold by this country.
—That is just rubbish.
—Where is the government at?
—That's rubbish.

—That is how much he knows. Go back to the North Shore. We currently export over a billion dollars worth of steel a year from Australia. After tomorrow, we stop making a billion dollars worth. The steel is no longer made. We drop production of steel by 1.7 million tonnes a year; therefore we will not have it to sell. Where is the government? Sitting on the treasury bench whipping up a war. When the real war is taking place in the marketplaces of the world, these guys are here trying to have a little war at the shop floor level by bringing in legislation to massively empower employers who do not want the power—to virtually force them into war. This legislation is not just irrelevant. It is not just a distraction. It is absolutely dangerous, because it puts us back to the mind-set that we worked so hard to get away from.

speech.para: Tomorrow I talk to those people at BHP—the management, who are also losing their jobs, and the workers. It is not just one side or the other. There are no winners there. They are all going to lose their jobs. The message that will come across from those people is, `Give us hope. Give us positiveness. We work together, why can't you?' The Prime Minister came to town a few months ago. Who did he talk to? Not to me. Not to the Lord Mayor. Not to the state members. He talked to a private group in a private meeting. This was the first time that I can recall a Prime Minister being in Newcastle and not talking to the Lord Mayor of Newcastle. These people are seriously partisan.

My workers and my management from my companies who are facing enormously difficult times want to see some constructive governing. They want to see some positive things happening—not gutting awards and not inciting war between unions and management. They want to see governments governing for all of us. Remember the slogan in 1996—`For all of us'? What happened to that? This legislation is not about all of us. It is about a very small few. But the tragedy is that if it is carried in its current form it will damage all of us. That is perhaps what Mr Howard means by `governing for all of us'—to hurt all of us. It is only by his ideology they actually can do that.

This legislation should not just be amended; it should be tossed out. It should not be on the Notice Paper. There are much more important things to be dealing with in this country. We have some real major crises. Industrial relations is not one of them. It is no longer an issue. Unions are part of the solution, not part of the problem. The sooner the government realises that and gets down to governing properly the better off we will all be. If the government has any sense at all, it will get it off the agenda. At this time and place, this is not appropriate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This legislation, with its laughable title, `More Jobs, Better Pay', represents the basest of motives in stripping the rights of Australians at work and returning us to the struggle between capital and labour. It is a bill that is ruthless in its attempts to diminish the conditions of Australian workers as well as destroy the impartiality of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

speech.para: Unlike the conservatives, we on this side have adapted to change. We do not take the view that employers are the enemy. We support the new attitudes we are finding in workplaces across Australia where teamwork and intelligent approaches to doing the job are valued by business and employees alike. We support the new partnerships being established where problem solving is shared to the mutual benefit of both parties. We were the party that introduced a corporatist approach to industrial relations under the Hawke and Keating governments, most notably the introduction of enterprise bargaining.

We have come a long way since the 19th century. It was Labor that in 1904 fought for a system of conciliation and arbitration which has served Australia well for the best part of the century. It was Labor that in recent years restructured the Australian work force to embrace the new era of globalisation. It was painful, it was difficult, it was bold, but we did it in such a way as to minimise as much as possible the impact on working Australians. The fruits of Labor's work are about us today. The government might be claiming the credit, but many economic analysts will contend that the reforms of the Hawke and Keating governments in the 1980s and 1990s brought about the economic growth that the Howard government crows about today.

I really have a problem understanding why this government and, in particular, this Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business are so hell-bent on destroying the social fabric that Australia has embraced for a century. Sure, there have been a number of bitter industrial disputes over the years, but the commission through its various forms has contributed greatly to the settling of these disputes. A study by the ABS found that management was five times more likely to be the cause of industrial disputes than employees. The finger points to incompetent management, a problem that I would suggest is much more pressing than bashing unions. To work smarter, employees today rely on good management and communication. Bad management does not anticipate problems, does not communicate objectives and does not value the contribution by its most valuable resource—the people who make it happen.

Unions have been playing the liaison role when management fails. Again, we have a partnership and it is a partnership recognised by progressive businesses as productive, necessary—even desirable. No sound business wants to return to battling with its workers. No good business today will tell any of its people that they are paid not to think but only to work. Good business wants all of its people to think all of the time. However, this government is willing to legislate in favour of poorly managed businesses. It is willing to exacerbate fear in the workplace. Who on the minimum wage, with a mortgage and a young family, is going to risk everything by raising concerns with their employer? What low skilled employee is going to be able to negotiate with their employer a pay rise or improvement in their working conditions? The answer is: very few. All bargaining power is with the employer. This is a very foolhardy approach by this government.

I gather there are a few modern historians in this government's ranks. They would know that this aggressive approach provokes a reciprocal response. The last conservative government in this country that attempted to embark upon such a radical program of worker bashing was the Bruce Nationalist government of the 1920s. S.M. Bruce, ironically, held the seat of Flinders. We all know in this chamber who now holds the seat of Flinders; it is held by the Hon. Peter Keaston Reith. Very interestingly, S.M. Bruce is still the only Prime Minister to have lost his seat—a direct consequence of his manic attempts to repress Australian workers.

This legislation is regressive. Days lost through disputes are very low. We have a system with the lowest level of industrial disputes in 80 years. Why? Because of the cooperative approach Labor put into place. We did not have ministers that blatantly took sides in disputes. We did not have ministers conspiring with an employer to breach their own legislation so as to sack an entire work force. The minister believes working Australians cannot be trusted—that they are shirkers, malingerers, a bunch of bolshies seeking world domination through collectivisation under trade unions—much like Bruce did. They think bosses need a firmer hand. This is retro stuff. It is a conspiracy theory fantasy which seems to be inherent in conservative ideology.

You see, Mr Deputy Speaker, Labor developed a value of trust in the workplace. Employers trusted their employees, and the other way around, more so than ever before. They have to because it is not economic or productive to employ goons with balaclavas and dogs. Indeed, you would be a pretty backward employer if you resorted to such measures.

talk.start.para: —The Liberal way; get in the rottweilers.
—The shadow minister is correct. What this government should be concerned about is the sorry situation which arose with the Cobars and the Oakdales, where employees' funds were not secured.
—Oh! What did you do? For 13 years, you did nothing.
—Order! I call the minister to order.

—The minister at the table does not like to hear the truth; you know it is true. There was no outrage and no sympathy at all from the Prime Minister or the workplace relations minister. It took talkback radio to get a change of mind after more than a month of sidestepping the issue. In regard to Oakdale, when decency and fairness demanded action, even the local member, the Minister for Finance and Administration, was out to lunch. And the Cobar workers are still in limbo today.
—For 13 years, what did you do? Nothing.
—This is an out-of-date mind-set.
—You've got a poor record on this.

—I am happy I am upsetting the minister at the table. This government takes the view that workers are the enemy, that the war between capital and labour has not been concluded, that unions are evil and should be crushed. Australians did not accept this rampant ideological obsession in the 1920s, so why would they accept this leading into the 21st century?

speech.para: In fact, employers are having a tough time with employee loyalty. They are having trouble keeping good people. There are many causes, but the major one is downsizing causing angst and job insecurity. This fear can be blamed on the decline of union member ship. What this government does not understand is that union membership provides a sense of belonging to an industry. Belonging to a union takes away the trepidation of employee-employer negotiations. Unions have a role in the modern workplace, as many employers will tell you.
