Just because there has been some market research showing unions have to lift their customer service standards to stay a major player in the game, it does not necessarily mean that the proportion of the work force with union membership is hugely dissatisfied or that the proportion without union membership is hostile.

I joined a trade union at the age of 16 and I am proud to still be a member of a trade union today. Young people today are not signing up with unions like I did when I was 16 years of age because this government has made them frightened to join a trade union. Who is going to join when they have to sneak behind the employer's back to join? You would have to be street smart and pretty game. We have the ludicrous proposal that a workplace is classified as a closed shop if 60 per cent are union members. The government calls that freedom of association. The government's deceit is there for all to see, with its present advertising campaign in favour of freedom of association.

talk.start.para: —What is wrong with that?

—What a joke! It is a joke, Minister. If you have to sneak around for an organisation to represent your basic rights, where is the freedom? The answer is there is no freedom at all for Australian workers. Anybody should have the right to withdraw his or her labour if the circumstances permit. Everyone in a democracy should have the right of assembly. Unions are a worker's cover against adverse circumstances. It makes sense to delegate. That is what unions are for. That is what the whole system has been developed for—protection for employees; independent conciliation and arbitration.
—How rich are the unions? How many shares do the unions own? What about their property portfolio?

—Minister, it is fairness for all. This legislation shows this government's unwillingness to understand the fundamentals of industrial relations. It is revenge for the independence of the courts in the docks dispute. The minister thinks you can achieve industrial relations reform with a crash or crash through approach. Those who follow this philosophy usually end up crashing with disastrous consequences. But this minister is an ideological zealot. He is driven to destroy the union movement. This has been tried before by greater and stronger people than this minister, and they have failed and they will continue to fail. Those who try will always fail. The Australian people will not put up with being bullied into submission.

speech.para: Even the Australian Industry Group is nervous about these amendments. The Director of Industrial Relations for the AIG, Mr Roger Boland, was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 June as saying:
. . . many employers . . . would be reluctant to "light a fire" under the issue because completely unionised sites did not necessarily impede business.
This is from a group that represents an industry that has undergone major reform in the last 15 years or so. The Master Builders of Australia agree.

This government is also attempting to destroy the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It is changing the name. It says that everything should be sorted out in the workplace. So if an employee has problems, approaches their employer and is told to take a hike, what happens then? The employee must give notice of representation by providing an invitation to their union—that is, if they have one. If they do not, where do they go? The answer is: they have nowhere to go. `Sort it out for yourself,' the government says.

As I stated at the beginning of my speech, the commission's impartiality is under threat. The introduction of limited seven-year terms is a blatant attempt to pressure the commission into making favourable decisions. We have already seen how the minister has no problem intervening in decisions he believes are not correct. Last year he lodged an application with the commission to review something like 35 awards that had been through the simplification process, because he believed that they had not met his legislative criteria. And he is constantly on the com mission's back, whether it be award simplification, the living wage decision or a number of other cases. The basis of our Westminster system is the principle of the separation of powers. The commission is a quasi-legal institution. It was formed to independently conciliate and, if need be, to arbitrate in settling industrial disputes. Can you imagine the furore if governments began appointing judges to the courts of the land for fixed terms?

Another provision is for the commission members to receive compulsory training through their terms. What does this imply? That some members of the commission are not qualified to provide the correct decisions? These people have had decades of experience in industrial relations, and most have had quite a number of years on the commission itself—and they need training? This is absolutely unbelievable.

In conclusion, this bill is the worst attempt to undermine the conditions of Australian workers in this country's history. This government's ideological obsession with the destruction of the union movement and the independent umpire will see the workers take revenge. And they will take revenge: they will take revenge at the ballot box at the next federal election.

talk.start.para: —I rise on behalf of the working people of the Corio electorate, which encompasses the great city of Geelong, to oppose the Howard government's Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 , and I do so with considerable political authority. I went to the last election strongly opposing the Howard government's industrial relations changes, and I increased my majority, which now stands at 61.5 per cent of the vote. I remind the minister at the table that the party which I represent polled, on a two-party preferred basis, more than the parties which now sit on the treasury bench. In my electorate recently, the workers of Geelong held a rally to oppose this legislation, and 15,000 workers in Victoria's largest provincial city took to the streets. That is the authority that I bring in opposing this legislation which the government has put before this House.

speech.para: The government has form in the industrial relations area, and its real objective in this legislation is unstated. Its real objective is to break down the ability of workers to collectively bargain for better wages and conditions. The positions that have been taken on this legislation by the opposition and by the government really reflect two views of the world. I guess we must go to the title of the bill to really see the reflection of those points of view. The government has entitled this bill `More Jobs, Better Pay' but, as the workers of Australia know, there are no new, real, secure jobs for them in this legislation. They also know the form of Liberal governments at the Victorian state level and at the federal level, which has led already to a significant assault on their level of wages and the conditions which they enjoy.

The two views of the world that are reflected in the debate on this legislation are simply this: on the one hand, you have an opposition that wants a highly skilled work force, an education system that gives opportunities and real skill development to the work force, significant investment in research and development and real growth in jobs and investment; and on the other hand, you have a conservative party that has as its basic premise, reflected in this legislation, that to get more investment and more jobs in this country all you have to do is simply screw down the level of wages and abolish the conditions that are enjoyed by the working people of this nation.

I want to reflect on what is involved in this legislation for working people. The workers of Australia must be very clear about what is at stake for them and their families in the Australian workplace under this legislation. It will lead to a long-term reduction in wages for many working people, and involves a dismantling of the conditions of employment which were won by their fathers, mothers and uncles in workplaces throughout this country over a long period of time. This legislation represents a reduction in the effectiveness of long established institutions to offer some form of protection in the workplace for workers and their children. It involves a reduction in resources to protect workers against unfair practices.

I think the ultimate obscenity is in the title of this bill—`More Jobs, Better Pay'. It is an insult to working families across this nation. The minister is treating the work force with the same arrogance that his counterpart—the person who will soon become the former Premier of the state of Victoria—treated electors with in Victoria. By glibly entitling this industrial relations legislation as `More Jobs, Better Pay' the minister seeks to treat Australian workers as fools, and for that—just like Jeff Kennett—he will pay a heavy political price for the assault that he is making in this legislation on the living standards of Australian working families.

While we are on the subject of the Victorian state election, I would like to remind the House of the Kennett legacy in the state of Victoria, which was overwhelmingly rejected by the people of Victoria in the poll which was held recently. It is worth reflecting on the form of the Victorian caretaker Premier on industrial relations matters and the part that that has played in his demise in the state of Victoria. It was Jeff Kennett who, on becoming Premier of Victoria, led the first conservative government assault on the wages and conditions of Victorian workers. It was an industrial relations regime born out of arrogance. It certainly was not born out of ignorance because Jeff Kennett knew exactly what he was doing to Victorian workers with the first wave of industrial relations legislation that was introduced when he came to power. He was arrogant, and he has paid dearly for that arrogance at the polls. When he sought to introduce industrial relations changes of the sort that we had seen introduced in New Zealand and in Thatcher's Britain, the Victorian electorate reacted dramatically and savagely and with a vengeance against that conservative government.

It was a federal Labor government that provided Victorian workers at the time with federal award protection—an award protection system the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, this government and this minister at the table have been intent on dismantling since they came to power. People in this nation will not be fooled by the title of this particular bill—`More Jobs, Better Pay'. A more apt title for the legislation should be `Less Jobs and Worse Pay'.

The coalition has the outmoded view with regard to job creation that simply by lowering the cost of labour there will be massive job creation in the Australian economy. The real way to create jobs in this society—real long-term, secure, meaningful, high-skilled jobs—is to encourage innovation and investment and to encourage education, training, research and development in our private enterprises and our public institutions. But here we have a government which has carved up the education and training expenditures in successive budgets. We have seen massive reductions in private sector research and development and an assault on the process of massive skilling that was initiated by Labor under Working Nation and dismantled by this coalition government.

As far as better pay is concerned, I say to the minister and the whole frontbench of the Howard government, come to my electorate in Geelong and talk to workers at the Geelong hospital and to the workers in some of the smaller engineering businesses. They will certainly tell you that, since the Howard government came to power, it has not been a better pay situation. What they have got from this government and from Liberal governments at the state level is more job insecurity, an assault on their conditions under which they work and a diminution of their wages. That is the reality for working people in Geelong today. If we allow this legislation to go through this parliament, then we are going to see a further diminution of the wages and conditions that are currently being enjoyed by workers in my electorate.

Let me now turn to major elements of this bill. I wish to examine in more detail several aspects of this bill because it is in the detail of the bill that the nefarious intent of this legislation and this minister can be fully appreciated. If we turn to the issue of awards—the central element that has maintained the wages and conditions of working people in my electorate—we see that this legislation continues the assault that was made in the first wave legislation introduced by the minister. This legislation will remove as allowable matters in awards skill based career paths, tallies and bonuses, long service leave, notice of termination, leave for jury service, superannuation, trade union training leave and union picnic days. You can argue with some elements of that, but when you go to the removal of incidental allowable matters you can appreciate the dimensions of the government's assault on the award system. This was the federal award system that gave protection and succour to Victorian workers when Jeff Kennett attempted to drive the boot into them in his first term as Premier of the state of Victoria.

This legislation makes it harder for workers under state award systems to achieve federal award coverage. That is, when a state government of the ilk of that on the verge of being turfed out in Victoria assaults the wages and conditions of working people, this legislation tries to take away from those workers their ability to seek protection under the federal award system. That is what Labor did in government: it gave Victorian workers the protection of the federal award system in the face of the assault that was being made by Jeff Kennett. Now this government wants to remove that particular protection from them.

If we go to the issue of workplace agreements, we find exactly what in practice and in detail this legislation means. It removes the requirement that the employer must offer the same AWA to all comparable employees and thus it allows a discriminatory approach to offering agreements in the workplace. Rather than offer a system that brings cohesion to the workplace, this one will divide it. And, of course, this legislation allows AWAs to be made that undercut a collective certified agreement even while the latter is in operation.

As far as industrial action goes, we see that this legislation is biased heavily in favour of the employers. Unprotected action for employers is only to include lockout action, but unprotected action for employee organisations is there to include all forms of industrial action. This is the fairness of this government's industrial relations system—a deliberate bias against working people and the organisations that seek to represent them. Of course, we have the assault on the entry and inspection of premises by legitimate organisations. This particular legislation limits a union's ability to enter an employer's premises to hold discussions with employees or to investigate award breaches where the union has a written invitation from its members.

What does this legislation mean in practice? It is more of the same that occurred when we had the first wave of industrial legislation under this minister. I want to mention here exactly what has happened under the government's legislation.

There have been many examples brought to me but none more insightful than the one I want to quote here today. It involves the CFMEU in Melbourne receiving information about workers at a company producing blinds who were working up to 40 hours of overtime and not receiving any penalty rates. They were concerned that machinery and chemical safety were not being adequately addressed by the company. After writing to the company to request the right of entry and being refused on numerous occasions, the union had the matter listed for hearing before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The request from the work force came on 9 December 1997 and it took until 13 July 1999 for heads of agreement to be reached between the union and the company over the matter. You might well ask what happened to the issues of chemical safety or the issues of machinery safety. I could go through the detail of this case: it makes for quite extraordinary reading regarding the time lines. The company refused the union right of entry to hold discussions in the lunchroom with the workers. Unions received notice from workers advising of exploitation and intimidation. All of these things were there in this instance, but of course the workers were not able to be represented by their elected representatives.

At Pivot, a company in my electorate, seven workers who had worked there for 25-plus years were called into the lunchroom by management one day and retrenched on the spot. They were handed their pay and told that contractors would be doing the work the very next day. When their union and their workmates tried to protect their jobs, the union found themselves in the courts for doing their job of protecting their members' rights—for no other reason than trying to protect the rights of their members. On a construction site in Geelong, the Employment Advocate made the building unions take down all union signs and remove union stickers promoting their union from the workers' helmets.

Here we have a structure that is really, at its nitpicking worst, aimed at trying to smash the union movement. Workers at Shell in Geelong, after 22 unsuccessful attempts to negotiate a decent agreement with their employer, removed their labour and found themselves and their union in court. When concerned Geelong citizens took the place of unionists on the peaceful picket lines, police on horseback, armed with batons, tried to break up the peaceful assembly. The reaction to all of this on the streets in Geelong was what I mentioned at the start of my discussion of this legislation: 15,000 workers out of the Geelong work force taking to the streets in Geelong to protest against this legislation.

In my portfolio area I have made a very strong issue of farm safety because there are too many farmers dying on farms throughout Australia at this point in time. I also have a concern for workers in rural and regional businesses. This legislation will add to their uncertainty because those workers will not have a sufficient degree of representation by unions in their workplaces or in their communities. They will be left without protection for their workers' entitlements. Occupational health and safety issues will be put at risk by this legislation.

The safety of farmhands, shearers and other workers in rural and remote areas will certainly be a concern with this legislation. We have had cases of young trainees in the dairy industry who were made to work 12 to 14 hours a day, seven days a week, without a break, for $5 an hour and with no appropriate training. If that is the promised land under this `More Pay, Better Jobs' legislation, then the Australian work force will most certainly reject it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 has nothing to do with creating more jobs or better pay. How could a bill that tips the scales further in favour of employers in bargaining with workers lead to better pay and conditions? The reason for the introduction of this second wave of industrial relations legislation has nothing do with good policy and everything to do with politics.

speech.para: The politics I speak of is internal Liberal Party politics, as various contenders and pretenders for the leadership jostle to get on the right side of the Prime Minister. But getting on the right side of the Prime Minister is easier said than done. I say that for two reasons. The first is that the Prime Minister is about as far to the right as you could possibly get for an Australian Prime Minister. I refer here to a declaration of the Prime Minister when he was Leader of the Opposition. This was on 2 March 1987 when he was trying to fend off the `Joh for PM' campaign. He told the John Laws program:
Everybody who knows me knows that I am the most conservative leader the Liberal Party has ever had.

He was right then, and it is truer today than it ever was. So getting on the right side of the Prime Minister is exceedingly difficult. At that time he was courting the New Right and the H.R. Nicholls Society. He was obsessed with the New Right agenda of smashing the union movement and moving to individual contracts. He purged the parliamentary Liberal Party of wets and replaced them with dries. At that time he was impressed with the lawyer who took on the Dollar Sweets case. That lawyer is now the Treasurer.

The second reason for it being hard to get on the right side of the Prime Minister is that it is pretty crowded over there. We have the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the greatest punisher and straightener since Governor Bligh. He knocked off that wet Ian Macphee for the preselection for Goldstein and he says, `Pick me, pick me.' But what are his credentials to be at the right hand of the Prime Minister? They are quite good, because he threatens to withdraw funding for disadvantaged schools that need it most.

Next there is the Treasurer, a self-declared income tax cut man, obsessed with cutting the top marginal rate for high income earners and opening up new tax avoidance opportunities for the wealthy—as if there weren't enough already.

Then there is the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. He will not be outdone in the Far Right stakes. He donned the balaclavas and unleashed the guard dogs in the waterfront dispute he manufactured and then denied all knowledge of involvement.

So far there are three starters in the `Far Right Stakes': Balaclava Pete, Governor Bligh and Lachlan's Boy. Next there is a lightweight entry—the Minister for Employment Services, that loyal monarchist, Lizzy's Lad. He is a bit of an outsider but he is in the race, I think at around 33 to 1. But he does have good recent form in weaker company. That form was demonstrated by his declaration that unemployed people are `job snobs'. That gives him real form in the `Far Right Stakes'. This is an employment minister who represents an electorate which has an unemployment rate of 2.3 per cent. The residents of Warringah can afford to be a bit choosy about the jobs that are offered to them, but for the minister for employment to label the disadvantaged job seekers in areas such as Woodridge and Kingston in Logan City in my own electorate as `job snobs', when there is 25 per cent unemployment, is completely outrageous. But it does help boost his credentials in the `Far Right Stakes'. He labels as `job snobs' the 12 Australians who are competing for each job vacancy in this country.

But language like labelling unemployed people `job snobs' would be impressive to that champion of the far Right, and here I refer to Ming's Dynasty. In the `Far Right Stakes' the pretenders and the contenders are going to have a lot of difficulty beating Ming's Dynasty, the current Prime Minister of Australia, but Balaclava Pete thinks he can give it a shake. He told a business lunch in Perth on 9 July last year:
Never forget the history of politics and never forget which side we're on. We're on the side of making profits. We're on the side of people owning private capital.

And that is the problem. The minister for workplace relations is on one side. He is on the employer's side, against the other side, the employees. That is his view of the world. That is the view of the far Right.

We cannot have decent industrial relations legislation when its architect sees his role as taking sides, taking the side of the bosses against the workers. That is a counterproductive approach—it is divisive and it cannot lead to more jobs and better pay. Australians do not want governments to take sides in industrial disputes. Australians want governments to facilitate the resolution of industrial disputes and to do everything they can effectively to avoid industrial disputes arising in the first place.

It is for that reason that Australians want an independent umpire in avoiding and in resolving disputes, an umpire who is free of government interference or intimidation. Yet this bill proposes to handicap the independent umpire, the Industrial Relations Commission. Under this bill the government wants commissioners to be beholden to it. It wants to achieve this through the mechanism of limiting their tenure to seven years, or in particular cases to 12 months. The purpose of this is that the government hopes that those commissioners will fall into line with government ideology and, with the government's view of particular industrial disputes, under pain of not being reappointed as commissioners. This is consistent with the minister's view of capital versus labour. He wants to limit the role of unions further in bargaining on behalf of their workers. He claims this will lead to better pay—that is inconceivable.

The minister wants to worsen working conditions even further than the first wave of industrial relations legislation by stripping awards. He wants to strip the awards most for the lowest paid workers. He does not want to give the lowest paid workers any pay rises until the awards are fully and effectively stripped. Finally, the minister wants to put workers onto individual contracts, regardless of whether the employees want that to happen or the employers want that to happen. This is just more ideological obsession.

This legislation must be the longest job application I have ever seen. It is a job application from the minister to be at the helm of the far Right. Increasingly, it is true that the policy of the Howard government is being driven not by what is good for the country but what is considered to be good for the ambitions of its leadership contenders and pretenders. This is not modern legislation aimed at facilitating the creation of more jobs and better pay in an evolving labour market. This legislation reveals no vision and it reveals no understanding of evolving workplaces in the information age. The legislation reflects a government desire to fight new battles—all along the front of the New Right. It is nothing but old-style class warfare. I remind you that its architect, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, said, `Never forget which side we're on. We're on the side of profits. We're on the side of people owning private capital.'

I am not going to get into trench warfare on a thousand clauses and have exhaustion by a thousand clauses, because this legislation should be thrown out. We should start again on a modern, visionary employment policy—that is the challenge for this parliament—and not argue the point about each and every clause. We should throw the legislation out. The secretary-elect of the ACTU, Greg Combet, is applying new thinking to the evolving work force. He is showing that he has a vision of the future of relations between workers and employers. He is showing that there is a vital role for the trade union movement in representing employees in bargaining over pay and conditions. He is demonstrating that the trade union movement can look forward, can have vision, and can understand that we have an evolving workplace and that there are new challenges to be met in forging good relationships between employers and employees in those workplaces. But the government lacks all vision. This bill should be abandoned. In its place should be a biparti san approach to reducing unemployment and continually boosting productivity as an investment in the nation's future prosperity.

The reforms of the 1980s undertaken by the Hawke and Keating governments are still producing good results for workers in Australia. They are producing more employment; they are producing higher wages. They were difficult reforms, but they were implemented with courage. So let us see a repetition of that approach. That approach was one of reforms based on cooperation and not conflict. Let us work out where the jobs of the future will be. Let us have a bit of forward thinking and planning in relation to these matters, and then let us build the nation's capacity to compete successfully for those jobs in the global economy, because that is where we are competing. That involves investing in the nation's people and providing incentives for unemployed people to move from welfare to work.

What incentive is there for unemployed people to work? From next year, under this so-called new tax system, an unemployed person who is offered a part-time or casual job paying around $10,000 to $15,000 a year will face an effective marginal tax rate of 87 cents in the dollar. That is, for every extra dollar earned that person will be able to keep only 13 cents in the dollar. And the government says that is incentive for the unemployed to get jobs! There is no incentive there. In addition, that unemployed person would need to take into account the cost of getting to and from work, clothes, child care and so on. So all incentive is removed. There is no incentive for the unemployed to move from welfare to work.

The Treasurer is preoccupied with one thing—that is, cutting the top marginal rate of income tax for high income earners, which is 48.5 cents in the dollar. That 48.5 cents in the dollar should be compared with the 87 cents in the dollar that unemployed people face. The Treasurer is not preoccupied—or even remotely interested—with the 87 cents in the dollar effective marginal tax rate. He is preoccupied with cutting the 48.5 cents in the dollar marginal tax rate for high income earners. Why? It is because he is ideologically obsessed with offering more benefits to high income earners and opening up more avoidance opportunities for them.

In the first job application of the minister for workplace relations—that is, his letter to the Prime Minister setting out his new draconian industrial relations agenda—he referred to Labor's tax credit plan to increase incentives to work. That is what it would do. It would address this problem of the high marginal tax rate effectively faced by unemployed people. But the minister said that the government was not interested in doing that. Why is that? It is because it is a Labor proposal. If the government were genuinely concerned about jobs, it would seek not only to improve those incentives to move from welfare to work but also to enhance the skills of young people in disadvantaged areas, because that is where the high unemployment rates are. Figures released recently by the New South Wales government show that in Broken Hill, Moree and Mount Druitt, one in four year 3 students are in the lowest band of reading. Yet in Hornsby, Ryde and the northern beaches of Sydney, the figure is less than one in 20.

talk.start.para: —I wonder why.

—I wonder why. The reason for that is that the government is unconcerned with dealing with the fundamental problem of disadvantage—that is, lifting the skills base of kids who live in disadvantaged areas. What is the government's response? It is to punish the students in these schools by threatening to withdraw funding under the literacy and numeracy program. Today, one in five children is growing up in a household where no-one has a job and one in three children is growing up in a household where there is no male working, no male role model for the boys as they grow up. These disadvantaged families are the families having children; the double income no kids families—or DINKS—are delaying having their children. They are doing all right in the information age and are having only one or two children. I have grave fears of rising inequality in Australia, but this government refuses even to recognise it as a problem. For it the exception proves the rule.

speech.para: We had a debate on this just the other day. Government members said, `Oh, look, of the 20 wealthiest Australians, seven arrived as penniless migrants.' So that solves the problem. There is no problem of disadvantage because seven of the 20 wealthiest Australians are the exception which proves the rule. That is the approach of this government to disadvantage.

The real difficulty facing us is that this widening inequality is masked by the Prime Minister's so-called `golden age economy'. If it is a golden age, it is not being shared by disadvantaged communities around Australia. The government has no policies to achieve equality of opportunity in Australia because it does not even see it as a problem.

What is desperately required is not a scramble to cut further the top marginal rates of income tax and to open up new avoidance opportunities for high income earners; what is needed is an investment in the nation's future and investment in children, in particular in children from disadvantaged areas who are suffering from a host of problems, including literacy and numeracy problems, which are leaving them behind in the race for jobs in the information age. That is the sort of approach that should be adopted by the government but, as I say, the government does not even recognise this as a problem.

As long as the government takes sides in legislation such as this, as long as the government talks of capital against labour and bosses against workers, it cannot address disadvantage. As long as leadership pretenders and contenders use policy development as a means of furthering their leadership ambitions, as long as they continue to ingratiate themselves with the Prime Minister by trying to position themselves to the right of him, we will get nowhere. They will deliver no good policies for the nation's future.

I say to the minister, `Tear up your job application. Abandon this iniquitous legislation and at least try to act like a statesman.' We need legislation that is designed specifically to create employment opportunities, to lift the skills base of the Australian economy and the Australian people, especially those in disadvantaged areas. We do not need more and more legislation designed to divide Australia. That is what this legislation seeks to do. It seeks to achieve some sort of political bonus or dividend on the part of the government by dividing Australians, by setting workers against employers. That is very old-style politics, but it is the traditional politics of the Liberal Party of Australia.

I say we should tear up the job application. Let us start again. I ask the government to join with Labor in developing genuine policies to improve job prospects in this country and to improve the working conditions of Australians and remove disadvantage. Then Australia could become a strong, prosperous and fair nation as we enter our second century of nationhood and Australians could be confident in our future as a decent, united and caring society.

talk.start.para: —It is interesting that commentators often say that we in this parliament are a grey lot and that there is not a lot distinguishing either side, but in a debate about industrial relations and inequality you will see the difference between those on this side and those on the other side. Five people on the other side spoke on this legislation, against something like 30 speeches on this side. That shows where the interest in this legislation is.

speech.para: Some of the comments that have been made were interesting. I listened to the honourable member for Longman last night. I must say it did stick in my throat when I heard him pretending to represent the working men and women of this country, and just how out of touch he is. I also listened to the honourable member for Hume. I have great respect for him and listened to what he said. In some respects, he made quite a good speech. In this place, people always try to outdo the working-classness of one another. The honourable member for Hume talked about starting work at 14. I started work at 14 in a sawmill. I had no chances of advancement. It was a labouring job and it was only as a unionist that I had any protection in that job.

I have been a trade unionist—and I make no apology for this—all my life. As someone who started their working life with no skills and no trade, there was only the protection that I got from the trade union movement. But then we have this minister in this House who has a pathological hatred of the trade union movement and a manic determination to smash the movement.

No-one in this place who follows these debates would have missed the interesting and timely article published in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, 7 August 1999, by its industrial correspondent Brad Norington. The headline reads `Reith moving in for the overkill' and the article adds to the flurry of other articles in the Australian Financial Review over the last 18 months which expose this minister, his office and his department of being up to their necks in the disgraceful sacking of an entire work force in April 1998. There are a couple of interesting observations that are worth recording for the public record from that article, specifically relating to the poor performance of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and the administration of the industrial relations policy. One is as follows:
He frequently changes direction, glossing over inconvenient facts or contradictions that obstruct his single-minded pursuit of winning a political point.
The article also says that the minister exposes himself:
. . . on the evidence, as someone who says one thing but means another.
From my perspective, there is no more worthy an observation than the following:
Close examination reveals that it is Reith's most ardent attempt yet to `get unions'.

This proposed legislation that we debate today is indeed the minister's most audacious attempt yet to further undermine workers and their legitimate representative organisation, the trade union movement. On reflection, the minister may have had very good reason to attempt to get square with the trade union movement. After all, despite his unsparing dedication to pumping every conceivable public resource into destroying the Maritime Union of Australia, the MUA actually used the government's own laws against it and, I might say, succeeded. It was only the Prime Minister's race to Government House in late August 1998 in search of an early election that spared this minister from being exposed as having misled this parliament. The minister would have been forced to resign on the basis of what he knew of the Patrick Stevedores chairman's intention to dismiss his entire waterfront work force.

Of course, this proposed legislation is designed to distinctly enhance the minister's credentials for the leadership of the coalition, setting his claim wide apart from his chief rival, the Treasurer. Why the ordinary Australian worker must be used as a pawn in such an awful power struggle escapes them and escapes me. This proposed legislation is dressed up in terms of choice, as are most policy positions from the government. But scrape away the choice overtones, strip the sections of this proposed legislation naked and we find there is not much choice for the workers.

The government faces the Australian worker with a loaded gun, smacks it down on the table and expects the worker to take the offer he or she cannot refuse. This is an unacceptable bias in this government's approach to industrial relations policy. It is an unacceptable swing of the pendulum to the extreme right in total favour of the employer. The Sydney Morning Herald article to which I have already referred puts it thus:

To give unfettered control to employers is dangerous. It places total trust in them to do the right thing by workers despite examples every day of companies under-paying workers, forcing impossible hours on them or denying entitlements when they go broke.

The Oakdale coalminers, their families and communities know about this dangerous control by employers. Last night in the adjournment debate I drew attention to another firm, Parrish Meat Supplies, in my own electorate where this is happening today. The coalminers have been left with a legacy of working long hours deep underground, risking their lives and helping to contribute to Australia's export capacity, many of them for 20, 30 or 40 years. Today, because of substantial public pressure and an unnecessary coal strike, provoked by the government's inaction, the Oakdale coalminers have finally achieved some peace of mind.

This government does not accept that the employer and worker relationship is different and always has been. The power established between employer and workers is always tipped towards the employer. That, like it or not, is an industrial relations fact. It is for this very reason that the Australian industrial relations system was established nearly a century ago—to try to redress this unequal power balance. It is for this very reason that successive Australian governments since 1904 have given significant powers and responsibilities to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission as it is known today but which soon, if this proposed legislation is passed, will be known as something else.

It is also for this reason that workers began to join collective organisations to protect their conditions and their pay. But this government has a high-minded belief that, if a worker has a job, this qualifies the worker to be on an equal footing with the employer. The relationship is equal and the power in the relationship is the same. Any negotiation between parties on conditions and pay can be settled amongst them. If only we lived in such a perfect world.

I have personally lost count of the number of times over the years where a worker has come into my office pleading with me to take on their case because their employer has either underpaid them, sacked them or abused the working relationship in some way. Two years ago a group of young workers approached me about the way they were treated by their Sydney based employer, who paid them when he felt like it but never at the right rate. When he did not want to pay any form of penalty rate, he sacked a whole lot of them on Christmas Eve and brought in another group at a lower rate of pay. This employer ensured that these young workers, the majority of whom were teenagers looking to obtain some extra money honestly through work, worked extremely long hours in rain or hot weather.

I took on their case and, with the assistance of the secretary of the South Coast Labour Council and a sympathetic media, including the A Current Affair program, managed to obtain for the young workers their back pay and other moneys owed to them. That Sydney based employer, I am pleased to say, no longer operates his trolley collecting business in any shopping centre in my electorate or in the Illawarra generally. I also want to emphasise that these young workers impressed me with their fighting spirit. They knew they were getting a raw deal from an unscrupulous, money hungry, bottom line boss—the very type of person those on the other side come into this parliament and spew out their support for day after day, especially when we are having a debate such as this. But the workers stuck together and won back what should have always been theirs. These young workers are now somewhat of a legend in my electorate, and are known as the `Shellharbour Square trolley boys'.

It is proposed that young workers be actively discriminated against in this bill that we are debating. It provides for the permanent maintenance of age based wages in awards and requires the extension of age related rates of pay to all awards. This flies in the face of the junior rates inquiry reported by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and tabled in this place prior to the recess. The commission's report outlines a very reasonable conclusion on this issue. The report did not conclude that the provisions of this proposed legislation be introduced. By the government ignoring the commission's conclusions it not only ignores young people but also confirms the contempt it holds for the commission.

The real intent of this proposed legislation is to assassinate trade unions and the trade union movement. For the first time we see a bureaucratic nightmare about to unfold in workplaces around the country as workers duck off to the crib room to issue written invitations to their union officials to visit their workplaces. The written invitations are valid for 28 days, after which the worker must write another invitation to the official. What will we have next—balloons, streamers, red carpet treatment and a brass band? If it were not so serious and inhibiting to the functioning of union activities, it would be very funny indeed.

The government needs reminding of the recent report Employee attitudes to workplace reform commissioned by the Labour Ministers Council. Workers have very definite views on the role of government and unions in the workplace. For instance, it records that:
. . . if a government is perceived to blatantly take sides on industrial relations matters, workers fear outcomes that are unfair . . .

Have you ever known a government in the history of Australia that has so blatantly taken sides in any industrial dispute? My colleague who will be speaking later in this debate could tell you about the sides the government has taken with regard to coalmines in her electorate. You have only to look at the waterfront dispute where the government sanctioned mad dogs and thugs in balaclavas coming onto the waterfront and praised those who were involved in this. The report, which must come as a shock to the government, also provides a rather positive response to the role of unions:

Security and self-esteem derive favourable attitudes towards unions . . . the role of unions is deemed to be important in enabling workers to make more money than would otherwise be the case, and to maintain their families' quality of life . . . To a lesser degree, unions are seen as a source of information . . .

But this is the primary reason for the attempt to assassinate trade unions. The government, like an elephant with a mouse at its feet, is scared that a humble union official may impart information to workers about the agenda of their employer and that workers will earn more if they join a union. This too is an industrial relations fact, like it or not. Government members should understand these facts. Union members earn on average 15 per cent more than their fellow workers not in a trade union. Union members are also more likely to have better working conditions and also achieve wage increases more often. No wonder the government is trying to lessen the power of the union movement.

This leads to another of the anti-union measures contained in the proposed legislation—the imposition of a secret ballot regime for industrial action. The government will interfere in freedom of association, and that has already been condemned by the Interna tional Labour Organisation, and it will also render useless the only remaining bargaining tool workers have—the right to take industrial action. The proposed legislation establishes a snakes and ladders paper trail for workers to take industrial action, but after a fortnight the employer can legally seek to have the strike ended. No worker takes industrial action lightly. Industrial action has loss attached to it, and it is always taken as a last resort. The ABS figures confirm this. Indeed, the minister needs no excuse to parade the fact that industrial disputation is at an all-time historic low. So why the provisions to make industrial action harder?

The trend of low industrial disputation began under the Hawke and Keating governments. There was a 13-year period of incredible and unapologetic cooperation between the industrial and political wings of the labour movement. One need only examine the achievements: incredible increases in productivity, impressive coverage of superannuation, child-care service increases, improvements in occupational health and safety, protection from unfair dismissal and employment growth. These achievements have not just happened since the 1996 election; they happened under Labor governments since 1983. The government can try all it likes to malign and demonise this significant period, but it cannot escape from these significant Labor reforms.

This proposed legislation is not the second wave; it is a tidal wave. The provisions and measures—unjust, unfair and so many just plain unnecessary—swamp the original Workplace Relations Act 1996. This is Margaret Thatcher's agenda more than a decade and a half on. The minister thinks he is Thatcher but without the handbag. Australian industrial relations have always been about balance—fair and independent—and about standards and protection. With all of the concentration over recent weeks on the fall in union membership, it is important to remember that the trade union movement still represents over two million Australian workers.

I joined with over 3,000 workers in the Illawarra at a public rally in Wollongong a few weeks back. The honourable member for Longman in his speech last night asked, `Where were the women in these rallies?' Let me tell you that the women from the clothing and footwear industries in the Illawarra were there speaking from the rostrum along with me and some other males, condemning the actions of this government and this proposed legislation. I do not know where the honourable member for Longman gets his facts, but if he wants to see a decent industrial rally at some time I invite him to come down to the Illawarra with me and address some of the workers at Port Kembla and Wollongong and spew out some of the nonsense he spewed out here last night and see what sort of reception he gets from the workers there.

This rally a few weeks back in the Illawarra, which over 3,000 people attended—no-one forced them to attend—was one of the most impressive, well-attended public rallies Wollongong has seen in many years. Over 3,000 workers were determined to defeat this government's tidal wave attack on their conditions of work, their pay and trade union rights. Conservative governments, try as they might, will never destroy the workers and the trade union movement. This is legislation for the boardroom, ignoring and attacking the crib room, and I am pleased to absolutely oppose it. I think every working person in Australia must oppose this legislation. I am pleased that the shadow minister has moved an amendment, and I will be supporting that amendment and opposing the bill.

It is very important that we do have good industrial relations in this country. No-one on this side of the chamber would argue against good industrial relations, but we have to ask ourselves how we achieve those good industrial relations. We have to look at the record of this government and its attack on workers and workers' conditions. We have to ask ourselves whether the waterfront dispute that was pictured around the world is the way you go about good industrial relations. Do you collude with the bosses to sack an entire work force? Do you move in balaclava-wearing thugs and savage dogs in the middle of the night? Is that the way you create good industrial relations? Do you strip all conditions away from coalminers? Do you bring scabs through picket lines? Is that the way to achieve good industrial relations, or is the way to sit down and negotiate and work through these issues?

That is the Labor Party approach. We sit down and negotiate. We do not always agree with the trade union movement. Those of us who have been around for a few years have no real illusions. We know it is difficult and tough. It is sometimes difficult to negotiate, but the end result is a better industrial relations policy which is better for the workers, better for the bosses and better for the whole country. That is what we are about, rather than this manic, pathological hatred of the trade union movement and this pathological determination to destroy the trade union movement that the minister opposite has.

talk.start.para: —I am not sure that I will be able to prosecute my case with quite as much visible passion as the member for Throsby, but that certainly would be no indication of how strongly I feel about this bill, the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 , and this issue of industrial relations in our country. I have long been a strong supporter of workers and the union movement in this country because I see the two as being inextricably linked. Since becoming the member for Capricornia, I have gone beyond that to make the strongest representations on behalf of the workers in my electorate, and I intend to do that in this debate. For that reason, I am opposing in its entirety the bill before the House.

speech.para: I am speaking in support, however, of the second reading amendment that was moved by the shadow minister for industrial relations, the member for Brisbane. The amendment proposed by the shadow minister reflects very well the concerns that the Labor Party has about the government's bill and about the government's whole approach to industrial relations in this country. The amendment identifies the key deficiencies in the government's bill. Not surprisingly, there are quite a number of deficiencies. Some of the key ones are that the bill proposed by the government further entrenches unfairness and bias in the existing industrial relations system; that it ensures that the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is further restricted and that the independence of the commission is compromised; and that through further award stripping it reduces the minimum conditions available to all Australian workers by further undermining the award system as a dynamic framework for the protection and advancement of wages and conditions.

The shadow minister's amendment also calls for the government to actually do its job in the area of industrial relations. Instead of this piece of ideological rhetoric that a year 12 economics student would be ashamed of, we would like to see a bill that delivers fair and equitable outcomes for Australian workers, preserves basic conditions for all Australian workers, provides for an independent commission with the appropriate power to conciliate fairly and settle disputes and provides jobs and income security. Wouldn't that be a novelty? The reality is that the industrial relations agenda in this country is totally divorced from the real issues facing us if we want to build a modern nation with a competitive work force. If you sat down and set out to design a strategy for achieving what is necessary for Australia to prosper in the future, as a whole country and also the individual workers and families within it, wouldn't you be talking about things like encouraging investment and research into developing of industries, giving workers the skill to lead those industries and promoting stable employment with an emphasis on training and an increase in skills?

That is not what this government proposes. The measures in this bill are completely out of date. More than that, these sorts of things have been a proven failure in other countries that have gone down the route of lower wages and less protection for workers, countries like our neighbour New Zealand. Surely the government can do better than this. According to this bill, the only hope it can hold out to Australian companies that are looking for opportunities to succeed in the future is the option of paying their employees less.

The opposition's amendment talks about the things that workers are really concerned about, things like job security, decent wages and conditions and the recovery of their legal entitlements in the event of company insolvency—a situation that we are seeing more and more in this country, whether it is real or engineered for a bit of corporate manoeuvring and a bit of sport with their employees. The amendment also lays the foundation for what this country needs to achieve in the future, that is, a highly skilled work force secure enough in their employment to focus on improving their skills and to work cooperatively with their employers to maximise productivity and opportunities.

The government's bill, on the other hand, has none of these things. This is purely and simply a product of the minister's ideological obsessions. It has nothing to do with what is really happening in workplaces or what will really achieve the outcomes that workers need and want so that they can have a bit of certainty about their futures. Really, you would laugh if it was not so serious. On the one hand, you have workers saying quite clearly what they want and what their concerns are; on the other, the government completely flies in the face of that and gives them this bill, which cuts down all the existing entitlements that workers have and does nothing to improve their security. It is a bit back to front: the workers are the ones doing the jobs, paying the bills and trying to juggle their work and family responsibilities, but the government sees fit to ignore the workers, who are really in the best position to say what would be helpful to them in their workplace.

This government's con job on workers has been going on for four years. We all remember that it started with the famous line by the Prime Minister that `no worker will be worse off under this government'. Well, we gave up on that a long time ago. Then we saw what the government really meant by its promise that we would all be relaxed and comfortable. We saw that when dogs and security guards invaded the Australian docks last year. Sadly, the con job continues with this bill. Looking at the bill, I do not know what is worse: the continual kicking of workers by this government or the insistence on insulting their intelligence by pretending to have workers' interests at heart. Why doesn't the government just come out and say, `We are antiworker; we are against workers having any sort of a fair go'? I say to the government: just admit it and call in the dogs and thugs; spare us the window-dressing of lies like `more jobs, better pay'.

If you want the truth about what is happening in workplaces in this country, you would certainly not waste your time asking the minister. Instead, I am more than happy to tell him what I have seen in my electorate over the past few years. It is actually getting quite rare to hear what workers really think these days, because of the culture of intimidation and game playing that goes on in so many workplaces. I could be charitable to the minister and suggest that it is happening only because some employers are being a bit overzealous, but of course workers know that the riding instructions come straight from the top: the minister himself is promoting this new industrial relations agenda.

Nowhere has this been more obvious than in the coal industry in my electorate. I will spend a few minutes talking about the impact of the government's first wave of industrial relations changes on the coalmining towns that make up a significant proportion of Capricornia. I have seen first-hand that the coalminers in Capricornia have borne the brunt of the minister's attacks on workers. I have seen that through the increased job insecurity, the stress that the families of these coalminers are feeling as their partners and husbands—often long-term and very experienced miners—constantly have to wonder what the future holds: will they hold on to their job or will they see yet another corporate restructure that will give the company an excuse to sack them all wholesale?

Instead of having their skills recognised and valued, they are subject to threats and insecurity. We are seeing more and more the use of contractors in the mining industry in my area. The use of contractors is a double-edged sword: on the one hand, it threatens the security of long-term employees in the mining industry but, on the other hand, the contractors are not getting a rosy deal out of it either. People on contract work are telling me all the time that they cannot really plan for the future, they cannot live a proper life and they find it very difficult to get loans for a house, a car or their children's education. So the long-term miners are living in limbo and so too are the contractors. That is having a severe effect on the small mining towns in my electorate as families can no longer spend freely, cannot buy the luxuries that they used to be able to buy and are forced to really pull back on their investment and their plans for the future.

Safety is becoming a much lower priority in these workplaces. That is the result of a few things. Because the long-term permanent workers are often being replaced by casual workers or contractors, you are losing the depth of experience of those miners. Accidents are starting to happen on a much more regular basis within the industry and some very serious and quite horrifying accidents have occurred this year in the Bowen Basin.

The effect on the families is worth noting. I am often finding in the mining towns that the workers themselves are quite reticent about letting me know what is going on. They are scared of losing their job and they are scared of rocking the boat in any way. More often their families are comfortable about coming to see me and saying, `Look, this is what is really going on here.' We might have a husband or a partner who can spend no time with their kids. They are on 12-hour shifts and they are dead tired when they are going off to work. They are working in an environment that is dangerous and involves heavy machinery and they really need to be on top of their game when they are underground on the long wall. But you have miners who are working 12-hour shifts, five and six days a week.

An example worth mentioning to the House of safety being used as a weapon against coalminers is where a company wants to insist on drug and alcohol testing for the miners when they start their shifts. The miners have said, `That's great. Let's have fitness for duty testing. Let's test the fatigue that miners are suffering,' but the company has backed away from that at a million miles an hour. So, if this were really about safety and not about targeting workers, I think the company would be a bit more fair dinkum about that kind of fitness for duty testing.

The workers' union, the CFMEU, is accused all the time by the minister of being militant and unreasonable, but have a look at the sorts of issues that it has been taking up for its members over the last couple of years: the question of workers' legal entitlements at the Oakdale mine, its insistence on rigorous safety standards like that fitness for duty testing at the particular mine that I mentioned, and protecting its members against the gross unfairness of mass sackings at places like the Blair Athol and Gordonstone mines. Is this simple pursuit of a fair go really such a threat to this government?

Closer to home, in my town of Rockhampton, the biggest workplaces that will be affected by the government's bill are the meatworks, and of course we know that is another industry high on the minister's hit list for no good reason other than the efforts of the meaties union to stay in there fighting for its members. It is the same story for workers at the meatworks as for workers at the mines, one of insecurity and of constant undermining of their working conditions. There is no respect whatsoever under this government for their skills as workers and as contributors to a company's performance. It is all give and no take.

Aside from the question of what this bill will do to the wages and conditions of the meatworkers, the biggest concern is the decreasing emphasis on safety in the workplace. A similar theme is emerging here. It is not so much in terms of large-scale accidents—I do not want to get dramatic about it—but it is more the treatment of workers who have been injured as a result of work practices that put production ahead of the health and long-term working capacity of these employees.

In question time over the last couple of days, we have heard some answers to questions where the government has been crowing about the abolition of the tally system within the meat industry. That is turning out to be a bit of a double-edged sword as well. The tally system actually remains in at least one of the enterprise agreements in the Rockhampton meatworks. But the employees are worried that it is an open-ended tally. So the pressure is on employees to work at an unsustainable pace and produce at rates above what is sensible for their long-term health and working life. A few years ago the government in Queensland implemented an audit across the industry looking at workplace health and safety measures. It recommended that, instead of working on a continuous chain, the chain stop and the workers work with the carcase in front of them. That was not taken up by the industry. It really is production over the health and safety issues at all costs.

With at least one of the meatworks—and it is happening in the mining industry as well—when workers are injured because of the work practices in place, the company says, `Look, according to the workplace health and safety laws we have a duty of care to you to provide a safe working environment. We are really looking out for you here. With your injury, we do not think that we can guarantee that you can work safely within this industry, so we are going to have to let you go.' Instead of worrying about the duty of care before the injury happens there is much care and concern afterwards, but it is not in the worker's best interests. It is really just an excuse to let that worker go. In these types of dangerous industries, workers have to have some protection and they should not be punished because they seek that protection from their union.

I mention one other thing that is affected in the meatworks in Rockhampton. Safety is an important issue, and wages and conditions are really the key part of this. But one of the things that comes into this bill is the taking out of allowable matters from awards. Union picnic days is one of those things that has been taken out. We have a union picnic day for the meatworkers in Rockhampton. It is a very longstanding tradition in our town, going back to the beginning of this century. It has traditionally been time for the workers to spend with their families on the school holidays. The `butchers picnic', as it is known, is on this Friday at Emu Park in my electorate. When I mentioned to one of the workers there that this was one of the things that was going out of the award, he said, `Oh well, that's the end of that.' But the end of what? It is a century-old tradition in our town. I find it quite ironic that, for a government that is so hung up on tradition, it is very quick to judge what is a worthwhile tradition and what is not. I would love to suggest to the beautiful people on the way to the Melbourne Cup in a month's time that maybe their tradition was not worth while. For the poor old meatworkers in Rockhampton who want to spend a bit of time with their kids during the school holidays, it is not good enough. It is a very interesting contrast to draw.

I spent a few minutes at the start saying what is not in the bill—that is, the things that are important to workers—but let us have a look at what is in the bill. Underpinning every part of this bill is its essential bias. There is nothing subtle about this bill. In fact, there is nothing subtle about the minister. The bill is unashamedly biased towards employers and against workers and their representatives in the union movement. One of the main examples of the lack of balance, or even any pretence at balance, in this bill is the change in the role of the Industrial Relations Commission.

The minister wants nothing to stand in the way of his political agenda. We have seen over and over again that he has no respect for fairness, proper process or natural justice—all the things that have traditionally existed in our industrial relations system in this country, thanks to the responsible watchdog role adopted by the Industrial Relations Commission. Thanks to this bill, the IRC is now going to be shut out of any meaningful role in industrial relations. It is workers with the least power, especially those low paid workers, casuals and predominantly female workers, who will suffer as a result. The IRC will no longer have the power to vet agreements or AWAs. Right now, if there is any doubt about whether an individual agreement is any good, there is scope to go to the commission to have the commission check it for the impact it will have on workers. Under this bill, all the power lies with the Office of the Employment Advocate, and we all know that is really an advocate for Mr Reith's agenda. At least, the workers in the Office of the Employment Advocate would want to be doing that, because if they want to hang around for long that will be an unspoken part of their job contract, I am sure.

Another part of the attack on the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission is seen in the way commissioners are now going to be appointed. It is unprecedented in this country to suggest that commissioners who are to play the role of adjudicators—of objective arbitrators—in a very important element of our country's workplace structure are going to be appointed for seven-year terms. That is just unheard of. Another point is that acting commissioners are to have 12-month appointments. You can see where that is heading. Clearly, if the full-time commissioners are not doing the job that the minister wants and he cannot wait out the seven years to get what he wants done, he can call in some hired guns for a 12-month appointment. I suppose that at least this time the hired guns will probably not be wearing balaclavas.

We have already seen, under the 1996 act, that the powers of the commission to get involved in disputes have been cut back, and the consequences of that have been totally negative and counterproductive. The thing about the commission is that its charter was about outcomes, about getting people back to work. Basically, it was to call the parties in, knock their heads together and get them back to work on some agreed set of terms and conditions. Under the new system that we have seen with the courts, that is just not happening. Courts have a completely different emphasis, a completely different charter. It is about winners and losers, not about outcomes. It is about technicalities—although I guess that a complex, technical legal system is certainly much better than what is being proposed under this bill, which is to take away all forms of protection and all forms of independence of the Industrial Relations Commission to protect workers in this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My colleague has made a number of observations which I will reinforce. I will start with one of them in terms of minimum conditions and stripping away of award conditions. One of the things that is prominent on the Darwin agenda and calendar is union picnic day. As we have heard from my colleague, the same is true in her electorate. As it happens, the union picnic day in Darwin is also Darwin Cup Day, which brings over $20 million to the Darwin economy and is regarded by everyone as almost a religious holiday. Any attack on Darwin Cup Day will not be well received. Yet this government is proposing through the proposition before us that, under this second wave, that holiday would go. I say to the minister that that would be unpopular not only with the workers but with the Northern Territory community.

speech.para: Another issue which my colleague spoke about was meatworks. Living in the Northern Territory as I do, I well remember the Mudginberri saga, and I well remember the debate that took place about Mudginberri and the role of various persons who are currently serving in this House. We were led to believe that somehow or other this would be a magnificent result for the Mudginberri meatworks. It was not long after the Mudginberri fiasco played itself out that the Mudginberri meatworks closed. The person who was at the front of this exercise in attempting to belt the unions was Jay Pendarvis—who, I am told, is no longer involved in the industry. I am not sure what his circumstances are, but I do not think he has profited too well out of the exercise that he was involved in with the support of the conservative elements in this government.

We need to comprehend absolutely what this legislation is about. What it expresses is the absurdity and malevolence of the government's ideological obsession with undermining the collective rights of workers, doing everything possible to attack the right of trade unions to properly represent the rights of their members, and imposing undemocratic restrictions on their ability to operate. It is also their obsession and desire to diminish the role of, and undermine the independence of, the Industrial Relations Commission.

To paraphrase the observations made in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 August, the legislation reveals the malevolence of the minister. It has got nothing to do with fairness. It is an attempt to get unions and it is a desire to give unfettered control to employers—which is obviously very dangerous. To go to the opinion of the 80 leading industrial barristers and solicitors, they have said that the government proposal will upset the balance and deliberately tip it in favour of the employers and that the fundamental and independent role of the commission has been attacked.

We need to comprehend, Acting Deputy Speaker Andrews—as I am sure you do, sitting where you do in the context of the coalition party room—what this is all about. This is not about fairness. It is not about dealing with employees in Australian workplaces as people who have rights which they can choose to use collectively in the form of working within a trade union structure. It is about trying to administer to them in a way which takes away their rights to work collectively, and trying to put a preponderance of power in the hands of the employer and to undermine the independence of the umpire.

My colleague, the previous speaker, talked about the independence of the umpire, about the proposal to put the commissioners on term contracts and about the ability of the minister to employ people on shorter term contracts. To enlighten the House, this of course is part of the ideological obsession within the conservative side of politics in this country, and it is not new. The former Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who is now President of the Liberal Party of Australia, proposed to put magistrates under the Northern Territory judiciary on the same sorts of contracts.

It seems to me that this question is not about justice, fairness and the ability of people to make independent decisions, provide independent advice and make recommendations to bring people back to work, in this instance; it is about political interference in the processes of the courts and, in this case, of the commission. I do not think it is fooling anyone. I do not think that there is anyone in Australia who cannot see through what the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is on about. We know because his record speaks for itself: other members have already spoken about the balaclavas and dogs, and I will not go into that any further.

But we need to know and the community of Australia needs to know that, if this legislation is passed through this parliament, there will be a dramatic and further reduction in the protection of entitlements of employees, Australian workers, including award protection for superannuation, paid maternity leave and long service leave. It will reduce the bargaining choices available to employees. It will deliver worse results for members through the increased use of individual employment contracts or AWAs instead of collective bargaining, and it will make employers less accountable for their actions. As I have said, it will erode the role of the Industrial Relations Commission as an independent tribunal and will dramatically diminish—and undermine, indeed—the capacity of unions to effectively represent their members.

What we need to comprehend here is that this proposal by the government focuses on individual workers negotiating their conditions as if they were a standard commercial contract. It pretends that each has the same bargaining power in the negotiations. That, to all of us, is patent nonsense. It is a throwback to the conservative views of 90 years ago. Indeed, in my former life as a school teacher and as a student of history, one of the things that I observed—and something which is obvious to anyone who has read any modern European history or Australian history or, more importantly, economic history—is the conditions that people worked under 90 to 100 years ago, before the formation of unions, and the roles and the relationships between employers and employees. I do not think it is stretching it too far to say that what the minister is on about here is taking us back to those dim, dark days of the past. I do not believe that there is any worker or any fair-minded employer in Australia who believes that this legislation will bring us fair and equitable outcomes, that it will do any justice to the relationships between employers and employees generally, particularly in small business, or that it will produce the sorts of economic outcomes that we as a community have a right to demand.

We need to understand that the commission serves a multipurpose role in discharging its functions. Its function is to be an independent and impartial tribunal and to establish fair minimum wages and conditions as well as dealing with industrial disputes. That is what we need to comprehend, and that is what this minister is trying to change. In the context of the observations I made previously about the desire of the government to change the method of appointment of commissioners, if you understand it in the context of the judicial system and the separation of powers, it is absolutely fundamental to the Westminster system of government and the independence of the commission that the government not proceed with this proposal.

All Australians should be concerned about the progressive threat to the very nature of our system of government that is implied in this proposal by the government. We have already heard and seen through the debate so far, and in observations which have been made, that Australian workers have, through their trade unions, been able to provide themselves with a voice and a capacity to gain improved conditions for themselves and their families, to produce remarkable increases in productivity, and to make an enormous contribution to the wealth of this nation. Now we have a proposal which would undermine the independence of the very persons who are charged with oversighting the awards system and industrial relations generally.
