It is worth while understanding that in the Northern Territory we have one commissioner—all the awards in the Northern Territory are federal awards; there is no territory industrial relations act; we work under the federal act—looking after about 100,000 workers. If the powers of the commission are further reduced, and if, as proposed by this legislation, $500 is required before a dispute can be conciliated, there will be a significant increase in both bastardry by bosses and in wildcat industrial action by workers. Of that there is no doubt. And that of course is a recipe for industrial disaster.

Before coming to a central matter in relation to defence issues—which is a byproduct of what is being proposed by this legislation—I want to raise briefly a range of other issues which reflect particularly on the Northern Territory. In terms of the question of deferral of safety net increases, in 1998 the Northern Territory unions reached consent positions with the local chamber of industry and commerce on all awards in relation to the award-stripping process of the first wave. The agreed document was sent to Melbourne for approval and it was rejected—knocked back by the minister's underlings. This was a document which was agreed on by the employers, represented by the chamber and the trade unions. As a result, the awards are still in limbo, not because the locals cannot agree but because of the ideological fixation of the minister in dealing with trade unions and the awards system. He says that, because he cannot agree with the employers and the workers of the Northern Territory as represented by their unions, there will be no more pay increases.

In relation to AWAs in the Northern Territory, we have a common rule system. There is a need to ensure that both employers and workers survive. AWAs have not been a success in the Territory. Even employers who do not want unions do not want AWAs. In remote areas, if automatic operation of AWAs upon signature is introduced without the ratification of a third party, we will see an increase in coercion and bullying tactics from bosses who know already that there are no other jobs around. The people who will be most adversely affected by this move will be indigenous Australians in the Northern Territory and people of a non-English speaking background. They will most certainly be worse off.

The other issue which I think is relevant to discuss in terms of the Northern Territory is the union right of entry. Workplace visits by union officials are already made very difficult in the Northern Territory by the joint tyrannies of distance and size. It is not unusual for a union official to visit half a dozen workplaces in one day and cover 1,000 kilometres in the process. At present, most of these visits are organised well in advance but loosely structured to allow maximum flexibility in arrival times. If the boss can restrict access at his or her own discretion, many workers will not see an organiser for many months at a time.

What we need to comprehend is the nature of isolation and the remoteness from the scrutiny of even the Employment Advocate. When union officials have the opportunity to visit these communities—whether it is a mining community, a small town or a pastoral lease—they should have the right of entry and they should have a right to meet with the workers. But under the proposals which this government is putting forward they will have no right. That severely jeopardises and potentially harms the conditions under which people who live in remote and rural Australia work. I do not believe that it is an exaggeration to say that there will be some people—I hope not many but there will certainly be some—who will see this as an opportunity to severely erode the conditions under which people are employed.

The other issue that I want to refer to briefly in relation to the Northern Territory is unfair dismissal. The Territory is a relatively small economy. The largest employer is the Northern Territory Public Service with around 1,400 employees. In the private sector, most workers are employed in small business. Per capita, we have one of the highest rates of unfair dismissal in this country. If the under-15 rule is introduced, most of these workers will lose the right to protection from unfair dismissal. This includes workers in the childcare industry, the hairdressing industry, large parts of the hospitality industry—particularly restaurants and cafes—and the light manufacturing sector. Many of the employees in these areas are women or people from non-English speaking backgrounds.

A further disturbing aspect of current employment practices in the Northern Territory is the high number of unfair dismissal applications involving Aboriginal corporations in the Territory. I understand that around 23 per cent of all unfair dismissal and conciliation matters brought before the Darwin Registry involve Aboriginal organisations. Madam Deputy Speaker, I am sure you would agree that this is a staggering figure when one considers that these employers make up less than five per cent of the employers in the Territory.

Clearly, there is a real need to bring employer-employee relations up to a functional level of operation before access to such remedies is cut off. Indeed, on these figures, there may be an arguable case to say that any restrictions to access to unfair dismissal processes would amount to indirect discrimination against Aboriginal employees and employees of Aboriginal corporations. I think that is an issue which should be taken very seriously by this government.

Finally, I want to refer briefly to a nonsense element that has emerged as a result of the first wave of changes. It is that leave for defence purposes is no longer an allowable matter. You do not have to be Einstein to work out that, in the context of what is happening to our near north—certainly just north of Darwin—and because of the nature of our defence force preparedness, in all likelihood there will be a desire by the government to increase the use of defence reservists. We are now in the ridiculous situation—the absurd situation—where leave for defence purposes is no longer an allowable matter. One would have to say to the government, `Here's an opportunity to fix that little problem amongst a greater problem.' But I know what we will be doing: we will be voting against this legislation. I hope we will be supported by the other parties in the Senate to ensure that this government does not get its way to deal so ruthlessly and unfairly with the workers of Australia.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to stand here today and speak on the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 . I believe that this bill contravenes the rights of Australian workers in the most insidious ways. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has placed before this House a bill that is inherently unfair and creates bias against employees right across Australia. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has once again obsessively employed union busting tactics in this bill in an attempt to destroy the rights of the ordinary worker in Australia for no other reason than ideology.

speech.para: There are several facets to this bill which concern me greatly and which concern many of my colleagues on this side of the House. The bill works to confine the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's powers to a few areas. The bill will undermine the independence and the role of the AIRC in several ways. Firstly, it will change the name of the AIRC to the Australian Workplace Relations Commission. This will work to reduce the commission's broad responsibility and sphere of influence. This is based on the government's ideology rather than on any practical considerations.

Secondly, it introduces to the AIRC seven-year appointments and acting appointments. This limitation of terms presents to governments greater opportunity to make political appointments. If we are to allow the AIRC independence to mediate on industrial issues, appointments should not be on the basis of short-term, contract or acting appointments for the commission. Thirdly, it introduces independent mediators as competition for the AIRC. There will be a national accreditation scheme for workplace relations mediators and a new mediation adviser to oversee the process, and parties wanting to stay with the AIRC will now have to pay $500 per application.

Before the Howard government was elected, the AIRC was known as an impartial and balanced organisation which had the wide respect of both employee and employer advocates. It is now reduced through legislation to an arena where employees have very few rights. It is not the fault of the commissioners that the election of an arch-conservative government has caused a huge policy shift and, therefore, threatened the independence and impartiality of the commission.

Another area of the bill which is inherently unfair is that of the changes to the award systems. In 1996, the government stripped allowances such as the provision in the workplace of first aid kits, staff dressing rooms, meal areas, adequate toilets, lockers, heating and cooling devices. In 1999, the Howard government is attempting to blatantly remove allowable matters from awards such as skill based career paths, tallies and bonuses, long service leave, notice of termination, leave for jury service, superannuation, trade union training leave and union picnic days. To also remove the other incidental allowable matters such as accident make-up pay, union representation for dispute settling procedures and union picnic days is shameful, to say the least.

In fact, the section which removes jury duty as an allowable matter will mean the downfall of the legal system to be able to produce juries to hear cases. This bill directly contradicts section 69 of the New South Wales Jury Act 1997, which states:

(1) An employer shall not dismiss a person in his or her employment or injure the person in his or her employment or alter his or her position to his or her prejudice by reason of the fact that the person is summoned to serve as a juror.

Although to remove jury service as an allowable matter is not illegal under Commonwealth law, acts similar to the New South Wales Jury Act 1977 exist in Queensland and the ACT. This is one allowable matter that should not, at any cost, be eroded. It is not in the public interest in terms both of workplace relations and of ensuring fair and impartial trials with diversity of people as jurors in the court system.

I note that in his speech to the House on 2 September 1999 the member for Brisbane and shadow minister, the Hon. Arch Bevis, referred to the award stripping which occurred in the first wave of industrial relations change, in particular removing the leave of those members of our reserve defence forces. In light of the crisis in East Timor at the moment, what happens if our reserve defence forces are called up for duty? Quite obviously, under this bill, those who are prepared to protect our country have fewer rights.

This stripping of allowances in awards will make life only harder for those who are on low awards and who are already doing it tough. In this bill, workplace agreements are to take effect from the date of signing rather than from the date of approval by the Em ployment Advocate. Discriminatory approaches are also allowed under the provisions where employers no longer have to offer the same AWA to all comparable employees. The Employment Advocate will also not have to refer an AWA to the commission if unsure whether or not it disadvantages employees. The unfair advantage this gives employers is utterly disgraceful. It is for no reason other than the dogmatic beliefs of this government. It is wrong to put the interests of the employer before those of the employee.

I now turn to the freedom of association provisions. This bill prohibits the establishment or maintenance of union closed shops at workplaces and businesses, and defines a closed shop as a workplace or business with 60 per cent or more of workers in one union. In fact, it requires employers to take action against closed shops, and it sets limits on a union's ability to enter an employer's premises to hold discussions with employees or to investigate award breaches. That is disgraceful. This change is an extremely alarming attack on the union movement—as the member for Braddon, who is sitting here today behind me, knows only too well. It is going to adversely affect larger companies such as Kmart and Woolworths which have high levels of union membership. It is going to affect industries which have a particularly high level of union membership. I believe that this sort of change will decrease rather than increase the productivity of workers. These sorts of changes are going to adversely affect the occupational health and safety of employees who work in highly unionised occupations.
I will quote Brad Norington in the 7 August edition of the Sydney Morning Herald in his article entitled `Reith moving in for the overkill'. Mr Norington says inter alia:
The list of anti-union measures is long and nasty. In an attempt to wipe out compulsory unionism workplaces with as few as 60% of employees in one union could be ruled an illegal closed shop . . .

To give unfettered control to employers is dangerous. It places total trust in them to do the right thing by workers despite everyday examples of companies under-paying workers, forcing impos sible hours on them or denying entitlements when they go broke . . .
The article goes on. Brad Norington is absolutely right. The implications of this bill are extremely dangerous for the ordinary Australian worker.

I move now to the issue of industrial action. This bill introduces secret ballots for protected industrial action. As well as this, the legislation extends the notice period for industrial action from three working days to five working days. The notice of pending industrial action also needs to provide the precise nature and form of the intended action, the day or days when the action would take place and how long the action would take place for. These provisions will certainly make it almost impossible to take industrial action against employers. Under this legislation the AIRC will also be required to suspend a bargaining period for 14 days after protected action has been taken. This will also work in favour of employers rather than employees.

This bill is unfair, it is unjust and it is un-Australian. The government has based this piece of legislation on pure ideology, as I said earlier. This legislation will not create more jobs. It certainly will not cause an improvement in the wages of workers across this country. The legislation leaves the way wide open for employers to strip conditions from awards and generally make life worse for Australian workers.

According to a submission made by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to the Senate inquiry into the workplace relations legislation, the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 had very little impact on wage growth. The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 has had little impact on job creation. Notwithstanding a decrease in the level of unemployment, there has been an increase in casual and part-time work. The trends have nothing to do with workplace relations legislation. This Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 will not have any positive effects at all in job creation or improvement in awards.

talk.start.para: —It is a cruel name.

—Yes, it is a cruel name, as the member for Braddon has just reminded me this afternoon. He is correct. According to the National Council of Churches in Australia in its September 1999 position paper A covenant for employment , the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 does not provide adequate or appropriate solutions to the problem of unemployment. Further, on page 17 of the paper, the National Council of Churches believes that Australia under the current policy proposals is `heading to a large class of working poor'. The National Council of Churches in Australia has legitimate concerns. I also quote from this paper:

speech.para: The International Labour Organisation has ruled that the current Workplace Relations Act is in breach of two IL0 conventions, those related to collective bargaining and the right to organise and strike. Legislation in breach of human rights is unacceptable . . .

I conclude by stressing my total opposition to this disgraceful bill and its assault on ordinary Australians in its present form. I support overwhelmingly the amendment by the shadow minister for industrial relations, the Hon. Arch Bevis, that works to restore some fairness to the employee.

talk.start.para: —If the titles of legislation were subject to the Trade Practices Act, we might perhaps have a case for false advertising in the title of this bill. It would be more correctly titled `Less pay, worse jobs'. The bill title should actually reflect the intent of the bill. The intent of this bill is to sideline the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and make it irrelevant, to attack unions and make them irrelevant if possible and to leave workers to negotiate their own conditions individually through AWAs. Pay increases are to be made contingent upon award stripping so that award employees will be required to give up their superannuation, long service leave and all of the other entitlements covered by awards to get their pay rises.

speech.para: It is a disaster for working people all over Australia and especially for women. It represents a thinly veiled attack on the union movement and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It reverses the fundamental premises of the legal system such as independent umpires and the onus on applicants in the injunction process. It is the work of a minister and a government intent on destroying the balance between employers and employees, which has been the defining feature of Australia's successful industrial relations system. We should not be fooled by the suggestions of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business that the bill represents evolutionary and incremental reform. It is a radical and destructive attack on workers and tilts the balance even further against them than the 1996 amendments.

I would like to speak first of all about the particular effects of this bill on women. Women will be disproportionately affected by this legislation, because, of course, as you know, Madam Deputy Speaker, they are concentrated in casual employment, in part-time employment, in lower paid work and in industries where their bargaining power is less. Often they also have less union coverage. So this legislation will affect women disproportionately.

The changes to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission mean that the bill limits conciliation to certain allowable matters. It means that the Industrial Relations Commission cannot be called upon to help workers and employers negotiate equal opportunity and sexual harassment conditions. More generally, in the past the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has helped women achieve better working conditions, including maternity entitlements and equal remuneration for work of equal value. The stripping of the Industrial Relations Commission's powers is disastrous for women workers who have in the past been able to negotiate these vital entitlements.

Award stripping particularly affects women workers. The ACTU estimates that over 50 per cent of women working part time are on awards. That is more than 800,000 workers. Twenty per cent of full-time working women are also dependent on awards—an additional 420,000 workers. The minister is stripping the awards and entitlements of over 1.2 million Australian women. These women have depended on these awards, in particular for pay increases, in the past because, as I said, they are often concentrated in industries where their bargaining power is substantially lower than some of the more male dominated industries. The move towards bargaining is bad for women. Women have not done as well in the bargaining process as men, due to their weaker bargaining power. As I said, that is because of the concentration in part-time and casual employment, their concentration in lower status jobs and occupations and lower union membership.

All of the reports over many years have shown that Australia has comparatively good levels of pay equity. They are certainly not the best in the OECD, but the advances that we have made have been based on the fact that in the past we have had a centralised bargaining system which has allowed workers in weaker bargaining positions to gain the benefits of the industrial activity of workers in stronger sectors.

In fact, Geoffrey Crockett and Alison Preston in an article titled `The future is bleak: Enterprise bargaining and gender wage equity', which was written this year, show that moving employment negotiations from the public sphere into the private sphere will certainly not advance the struggle of women workers. They suggest that decentralised bargaining will adversely impact on female earnings. They say that this has already been proved in Western Australia, which has implemented many of the reforms proposed by this bill. We can look at the future of the federal legislation by examining the effects of the Western Australian legislation—and that, of course, is not just true in the issue of equity between men's and women's wages but also relates to the issue of accessing workplaces with the required notice.

Crockett and Preston show, for example, that between 1991 and 1998 the wage gap in Western Australia rose 5½ percentage points from 17½ per cent to 23 per cent. That is a very significant increase over a seven-year period, and is certainly not a situation we should be proud of. Australia, as a country that has in the past led in many areas of wage equity and other gender equity issues, is in fact now introducing legislation that is proven in Western Australia to have increased the wage gap between men's and women's earnings. Census data shows that this change was entirely brought about by adverse wage structure effects and not because of changes in productivity between men and women. I think that is a very serious issue. There has been in the past an argument that the wages gap is based on the fact that men are stronger or working in heavier industries, but really this research by Crockett and Preston shows that the increase in the gender wage gap has just been because of women's lower bargaining power in the wages bargaining process. In fact, Western Australian women have improved what the academics would call their relative human capital endowments—they are referring to education, work skills and so on—but these gains have not offset the detrimental effects of the legislative changes.

An analysis of these workplace agreements show that equal opportunity provisions have been weakened and that the beneficiaries of the new system are managers rather than workers. So people in situations where they have strong bargaining power are able to bargain their wages up, but for the majority of workers that is certainly not the case.

I will make some more general comments about the legislation as well. The bill confines the Industrial Relations Commission's compulsory arbitration powers. It removes matters which the Industrial Relations Commission can include in awards such as long service leave, notice of termination, skills based classifications, training and education provisions. The award stripping that is proposed will remove all but the most basic minimum conditions. This is a shameful situation, given how many generations Australian workers have fought to have these types of provisions included in their awards, for the very good reason that they are the sorts of rights and entitlements that workers should expect—not just for themselves but for all of their colleagues; not just for workers who are in strong bargaining positions but also for the majority of workers who on their own cannot win such conditions and who rely on collective action to achieve these sorts of conditions.

The bill makes industrial action illegal except in the most meagre set of circumstances. In this respect we are actually embarrassing ourselves in the international community when we reach a situation where Australia is saying in the international context that we no longer believe that workers have the right to withhold their labour—their only real bargaining power. I think that this certainly sets us back decades in having an advanced industrial relations system.

Sympathy and political action, of course, is unprotected under the allowable circumstances for industrial action. The Industrial Relations Commission must authorise a ballot to take place. That requires an application with signatures from five per cent of the work force. That is terrific news. If you are in a work force where you are very sackable and where you are very vulnerable, you are hardly likely to put your name to a petition suggesting industrial action.

This also applies to the rights of entry provisions included in this bill whereby unions can enter workplaces only if they have a written invitation from a union member and if 24-hours written notice is provided to the employer. There are provisions for an official to obtain a certificate from the registrar to protect the identity of the union member requesting a visit, but it is not clear how onerous this process might be or whether workers will be prepared to use it.

Just imagine being the one worker on the shop floor—perhaps a migrant worker sewing clothes for a few dollars an hour—who is brave enough to invite the union in to inspect the premises, to inspect the working conditions or to inspect the pay records if you believe you have been underpaid. It would certainly take a lot of strength of character and bravery to be the one to risk your job and risk retaliation from the employer. To be brave enough to be the one who will do that would certainly be an achievement. The most vulnerable workers, of course, are the ones least able to negotiate on their own behalf, but they will also be the ones least likely to invite their union into the workplace because they will be the ones most fearful of retaliation, having been identified by the employer as the person who is the troublemaker.

I believe that the bill will also lead to greater not less industrial disputation because of the onerous requirements relating to allowable industrial disputation. A situation is created here where there is no incentive for goodwill between employers and unions. In fact, unions, by and large, see these requirements as so onerous and so unreasonable that they are more likely to behave illegally if this bill is passed—so in fact increasing the level of disputation. The Assistant Secretary of the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union, Dave Oliver, told Workforce magazine last month:
If they tighten it up too much, then we will have to defy the law. The unions have always taken industrial action and we always will.

And of course it is the unions' responsibility to defend the interests of their workers in the most effective way possible. If the government gives them no room to move and no possibility of reaching any sort of reasonable accommodation, they are forced into a situation where conflict is increased.

Unprotected action occurs in any situations other than those specifically described in the bill. For example, when workers protest against the loss of jobs through restructuring, the Industrial Relations Commission is obliged to issue orders to stop or prevent industrial action within 48 hours of an application being made. The bill's definition of industrial action covers only unions. It is significant that when the minister implies that this is a bill that promotes a level playing field, that is fair to both workers and employers, it is plain to see that the intention of this bill is certainly not to be even-handed. The definition of industrial action used to cover both employers and unions with a broad definition that included any change to normal work arrangements.

The Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union, in particular, has been successful at having actions by employers defined as industrial action and therefore making those actions illegal. The fact that the CFMEU was able to use the provisions of the previous legislation obviously irritated the minister so much that he has now changed the legislation to make sure that employers are no longer covered by this legislation. An analysis of the bill provided by leading industrial lawyers suggests:

Perhaps the most glaring example of the distinct lack of even handedness on the Minister's proposals is that which seeks to expand the scope of s127 to ensure that orders may be made against unions and their officials, while at the same time confining the grounds on which an order may be made against an employer to just one, unprotected lockout action.

Secondly, there is also a requirement that the Federal Court must act promptly in enforcing section 127 orders. The court has demonstrated a willingness not only to prioritise section 127 orders but to sit outside normal sitting hours for these matters. An analysis of the minister's proposals by 80 leading industrial barristers and solicitors suggests that the provision:
. . . may have something to do with the Minister's desire to get even with the Federal Court because of the decisions made by the Court during the course of the waterfront dispute.
It is hardly a good basis for making public policy, is it? A hurt ego and a desire for revenge are hardly a good basis for public policy.
In these provisions the government is seeking to limit the discretion of the courts. Even the Industrial Relations and Management Newsletter in July this year said:

. . . there is a concern that by limiting Court discretion so much, genuine cases may not get the special attention they need. Employers are not always in the right—nor are unions and employees always in the wrong.
You would never guess that from reading this legislation; you would never guess that there is any chance that the employer would ever be in the wrong.

I return briefly to right of entry. This has certainly been a problem in Western Australia. I will not go into too much detail, but the CFMEU is a union that has experienced a lot of difficulty with this. It has led to a number of injuries, and indeed deaths, on construction sites in Western Australia where safety re quirements have not been adhered to. Because of the onerous conditions of rights of entry in Western Australia, union officials have not been able to enter those sites and inspect them. This has certainly led to injury and, I think it is fair to say, a number of deaths in the construction industry in Western Australia. I am very concerned that this legislation will indeed lead to an extension of that problem around the country. I think it is also fair to say that there is no way in which this legislation is fair to Australian workers; there is no way in which it meets the suggestion in its title that it will provide more jobs and better pay—in fact, it will be just the reverse.

talk.start.para: —Once again I am standing in this House to oppose a bill of parliament which is aimed at reducing the bargaining position of workers in gaining fair and equitable wages and conditions. In proposing these amendments, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business seeks to implement further attacks on the industrial relations system of this country. In fact, these so-called reforms will do nothing but raise the profit margins for the employers and lower the living standards of the people whom the minister suggests he is assisting—the workers.

speech.para: I find it hard to contain my anger and disappointment at the government's flagrant attempts to destroy the trade union movement and reduce the ability of workers to defend themselves against provocative employers. What is proposed is a further stripping back of awards. It will mean that awards will be stripped back so that they can contain only basic minimum wages and conditions. This will remove conditions such as skill based classifications, accident make-up pay, long service leave, superannuation, training and education provisions—the list goes on and on. Awards must be stripped back before any safety net increase can be applied, preventing access to arbitration in the Industrial Relations Commission for workers covered by a paid rates award, a large chunk of which are in the public sector. The fact is that the minister does not believe the protection of workers' entitlements is necessary because he does not want those entitlements to be awarded at all. The minister said on Meet the Press on Sunday, 8 August:
It would be consistent with our policy of workplace relations policy to have a system which is seen as a safety net rather than necessarily guaranteeing every last entitlement.

This shows his total disregard for workers' entitlements—which have been earned—and is a clear indication that he wants these to be removed and abolished. He wants these entitlements removed because they hinder the ability of employers to create wealth without having to pass on anything to those who created it—the workers. In terms of individual agreements, the government will make it easier for employers to force workers into secret individual contracts, which may result in substandard wages and conditions. The Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 does away with the cooling-off period that allows the AWA to be implemented as soon as it is signed. This will lock workers into an intimidating situation where the employer can stand over the workers—who will not have any proper representation—in order to make them sign to get employment. The bill allows for selective discriminatory offering of individual contracts by removing the requirement that an AWA must be offered to all comparable employees. It also undercuts an existing agreement by allowing an AWA to be offered whilst that agreement is still in force.

The bill also makes it far easier for employers to unfairly sack their employees. It does this by removing the right of remedy for workers who work for a company with 15 employees or less, who have been employed for less than six months or who are employed on a casual basis. It does it by requiring the commission at conciliation stage to issue an opinion as to whether a claim would succeed or not. The commission will also have the power to cease conciliation and refuse to arbitrate if it deems the claim to be a potential failure. And it does it by broadening the circumstances where costs can be awarded against the workers, and allowing a system where a worker may be required to pay some form of bond before the case goes ahead. This will have the desired effect for the govern ment, as very few workers or unions will be able to afford such an imposition.

The bill also seeks to diminish the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. This body, the independent umpire of the industrial relations system, is something that the government simply does not support. The minister has said very openly that he is on the side of capital, whereas a decent minister for industrial relations should be promoting harmony in the workplace. This bill would remove certain powers of the commission in respect of industrial disputes. It would limit the compulsory conciliation to disputes about allowable matters. It would introduce private mediation providers as an alternative, with no real indication as to who will pay for this mediation, and it would introduce a user-pays system, by charging the parties $500 for the privilege of voluntary conciliation in the commission. Perhaps, though, the biggest threat to the independence of the commission would be the plan to introduce seven-year terms for the members and one-year terms for acting commissioners. This may have the effect of influencing the members of the commission, whose tenure and future will solely depend on their appointment by the government through the Governor-General. It will also give the government the opportunity to control the workings of the commission by the use of successive acting commissioners. Independence of courts and tribunals is absolutely critical to the Westminster style of government and the separation of powers that are contained within the Australian Constitution.

On the issue of young workers, this bill proposes to ensure all awards contain age related rates of pay and to permanently maintain those youth wages and awards. First, the government tries to pre-empt the inquiry by the Industrial Relations Commission, exposing the situation, and then it goes about these measures. The government simply is about slashing the wages of some of the most vulnerable in our community. The Senate have rejected this proposal once before. I am positive they will do it again.

Perhaps the most repugnant aspect of the bill is the further attempt to destroy the union movement and prevent them from effectively representing the members who choose to belong to trade unions. This bill seeks to force employers to reduce union power where over 60 per cent of their employees are members of one particular union. How absurd and ideologically driven is that proposition. It suggests it is inappropriate in any workplace for 60 per cent of members to choose to belong to a particular union, whereas in most of those workplaces, if not all, it makes absolute sense. It makes sense to have a commonality of interest, which is why they choose to belong to that trade union as it is. But this government is about creating confusion and division and destroying the rights of workers to collectively bargain for their interests.

This bill also seeks to prohibit clauses encouraging union membership from being included in certified agreements. The fact is that employers who have a bit of vision, who care about their workplace and who care about their particular corporation, understand that by having a cooperative relationship with their work force through collective negotiation, discussion and dialogue they can actually improve the way their company operates and improve their profit ratios as well. Workers should not be treated simply as the ones on the other side of the fence; they should be treated as the core part of any corporation. To be successful, a cooperative relationship beats a relationship of conflict every single time.

But this bill seeks to undermine that. It also seeks to limit the ability of a union to enter the employer's premises even when there is a written invitation from an employee. A new invitation would be required every 28 days, and the employer can even direct the place where the meeting can occur. This story really is bordering on George Orwell in its attempt to control from the top what is occurring. It has disastrous implications for issues such as occupational health and safety if an employer can stop a trade union representative from coming into a workplace, even when invited by one or a group of the employees, and stop their ability to actually examine what is occurring there. This is at a time when industrial accidents still cause more injury than motor vehicle accidents, more loss to the company, more loss to the economy and, most importantly, more human suffering to those workers whose employers choose to cut costs rather than look after the interests of their work force.

I suspect it does not really matter to this minister that those workers wish to be in a union, choose to insert encouragement clauses for union membership into agreements and wish to meet their union official in private—free from the possibility of intimidation for seeking to defend their own and their fellow work mates' industrial interests. Proposals such as this will ensure that the ultimate power will rest in the hands of the employer.

To complement that, the bill also intends to remove the cooling-off period for conciliation, in which unions are protected from legal action by an employer, and allowing a choice between the Federal Court and a state Supreme Court—shopping, if you like, for a sympathetic court to hear particular cases. It would also impose a requirement that the union must apply to the commission for an order to allow a cumbersome and expensive secret postal ballot. The commission must issue an order for protected industrial action to take place. This radically restricts workers' ability to take appropriate action to advance their aims for fair and equitable wages and to protect their conditions. How extraordinary. When workers take industrial action, it actually costs them money. They forgo their wage when they do that, and they do it for their long-term interests. People do not take industrial action lightly; people do not do it without proper consideration of other dispute mechanisms which are in place. It is, of course, a last resort. When we are talking about workers taking industrial action, we are talking about them withdrawing their labour.

To suggest that they not have that right is to suggest that, in 1999, it is appropriate to have legislation to force people to give of their labour. That might be all right for some of the spivs who sit on the front bench opposite, with their family trusts, their avenues of capital and the interest and money they get from other sources—most of which is untaxed. But for workers who rely on their wage for shelter, food and clothing for their families, it is outrageous to suggest—on the part of this uncaring, unsympathetic, anti-worker government—that they take lightly an action to withdraw their labour.

The title says it all—more jobs, better pay. This is a government which is about rhetoric. It is not called the `smash the trade union movement bill', which would be more appropriate. This government has a childish, student politic-like stunt in the way that it is naming its bills. This is the biggest joke since it called the GST bills `a new tax system' without referring to GST in the title. The reality is that these proposed amendments ensure that the real meaning translates to `more jobs for lawyers and accountants, and better pay for the managers and employers'.

The ILO's Committee of Experts, which is made up of 20 eminent legal experts, found that the Workplace Relations Act in its current form breached several ILO conventions, most notably freedom of association and collective bargaining. They found that the laws do not promote collective bargaining by giving favourable treatment to individual contracts and are restrictive on negotiating agreements with more than one employer. So after being told that laws introduced by the federal coalition contravene conventions that Australia has ratified, the federal coalition go one step further and reduce a worker's ability to bargain collectively and gain protection.

Even the employers are reluctant to provoke the trade union movement without cause. Roger Boland from the Australian Industry Group, the peak employer body in Australia, stated in the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 July this year that employers would be reluctant to `light a fire' in their workplace because unionised shops did not necessarily impede business. So you have a large employer group that is by no means a friend of the union movement saying that these proposed amendments are provocative and damaging to workplaces.

Reith the wrecker just will not listen! He will not even pay heed to his own supporters in the boardrooms. By speaking out, the employer groups, in acting as the minister's industrial jackboot squad, took issue by overtly provoking the trade union movement into conflict purely for the benefit of the leadership ambitions of the minister for workplace relations. The minister has done the Prime Minister's bidding by derailing the republican issue, and now he is out to wreck workers' lives by doing the bidding of his mates in the boardrooms across the country. I can picture him now sitting in his office, devising plans on how he can thwart the latest attempt by workers to obtain a fair, livable wage.

The fundamental aspect to this whole debate still remains the government's promise that no worker will be worse off as a result of the reforms over the last three years. This promise has proven to be worthless on countless occasions over those years: ask the workers who are unfairly dismissed and who are unable to gain a remedy due to the lack of financial assistance or who are denied access to the federal and state industrial tribunals; ask the workers who are coerced into signing individual agreements against their better judgment but who have no real option otherwise.

I call on all members to reject these provocative policies—members of the House who represent hundreds of thousands of workers throughout Australia who will be adversely affected by this bill. We should be doing the right thing by our constituents and protect their wages and conditions from being eroded which will jeopardise them, their families and our economy into the future.

talk.start.para: —In this debate on the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 I am happy to join my colleagues on the Labor side who are arguing against the key provisions of this bill and arguing for the amendment which the shadow minister for industrial relations has put forward. This bill is of a piece with the government's approach not only to industrial relations but also to the management of this economy and the outcomes of that management, particularly in terms of the social conditions for people in Australia, that they have exhibited since they came to office in 1996.

speech.para: This workplace relations act is an extension of the first act that this minister brought into this place. It is of a piece with the youth employment provisions that they have attempted to adopt and it is also of a piece with the broad changes that they have attempted to make and have had to back-pedal on in terms of Public Service employment.

If this bill goes through in its original government form, if the government does not agree to the amendment the opposition is putting forward, its impact will be extremely deleterious to the people who live in my electorate of Blaxland. The city of Bankstown of which Blaxland is half has been directly impacted on by this government in a number of ways.

In particular, I want to point out the related issues of what happens to people who are working in government employment in Bankstown. Since 1996, over 440 local employees in the Australian Taxation Office in Bankstown have been moved to Hurstville or Parramatta. There are 220 left. The government cannot move them because the other facilities are already overstocked with employees. This government is wasting $22 million in dead rent on the Bankstown Taxation Office and will do so until 2002. Just in this last week, the staff at Bankstown Immigration have been informed that all of them—all 90—will be moved either to the central business district or to Parramatta. So 440 plus 90 more jobs are to be lost in Bankstown in direct government employ. That means there is less ballast in the area.

Directly in terms of the broader industrial relations changes that the minister for workplace relations has initiated already, at De Havilland in Bankstown there has been a broad cut in the work force. The management of De Havilland determined to make the changes that Peter Reith has already brought into place in this parliament and would be supportive of the model that is in the government's bill before us right now. In the past couple of weeks, a large number of workers have been made redundant from that facility—workers who have worked at De Havilland for a long time and been productive and efficient. In the dispute between the workers and the management at De Havilland they got special help from outside counsel—special help provided by the minister for workplace relations sent in to be the leading edge of these sorts of changes. There was direct intervention in Bankstown which resulted in the loss of jobs.

I turn to what this government has done in this bill and in a series of others. In particular, the member for Grayndler mentioned the tax bills before the House—for a new tax system—and those being misnamed. I would point to the charter of budget honesty as another outlandish misnaming of legislation in this House. I have spoken previously, dealing with that bill, about how the reality in the bill does not match up with the names.

This is a government of doublespeak, this is a government of newspeak, this is a government where less is more. There is no place where that is evident more than this bill. Less is more from the coalition government led by John Howard, the member for Bennelong, in which the minister for workplace relations promises more jobs and better pay as a result of the measures contained in this bill.

Everyone in Australia who is not utterly biased and not a complete supporter of this minister knows, slightly at least, that when this government speaks and when it uses flowery language or evocative language—like `more jobs, better pay'—you start to worry. You start to worry because there are already indications of doublespeak, there are already indications of an Orwellian 1984 approach from this government. We have seen it before in other bills. It knows, in this area in particular, that more jobs and better pay emanate from a more productive and efficient work force. They also emanate directly from better relations between employers and employees.

Those in the Australian population at large who can cast their minds back to the period of the Labor government will have in their memory that over 13 years Labor moved progressively from the centralised award system to a modified system in which there were workplace agreements where the work force and the employers joined with the work force's representatives, the unions, in conjunc tion with the Industrial Relations Commission, to bring about a more productive and more efficient workplace. During all the time that we were in government, and particularly the period in which Labor undertook a progressive set of changes in regard to that, the then opposition and now government tried to push the pedal harder.

This government not only believes that less is more, that you can con the Australian people by using rhetorical phrases in regard to what has been provided, but also centrally believes that it is not just enough to con people: it is centrally important on the factory floor and in the community to drive towards this one central, key view, that there should be a master-servant relationship between employers and employees in this country. From 1996 onwards, this government, under this minister for industrial relations, has sought time after time in the legislation that he has put forward and in his actual conduct in the field—and the best example of that is what he did in relation to the waterfront fiasco—to take Australia back to the place that is safe for the coalition, and that place that is safe is a 19th century industrial system where the master-servant relationship operates.

If there is any doubt about that, which there is expressed from the government side, all they have to do is look at the provisions of this bill. The provisions of this bill take away what protections there still are after the minister's previous bills. They strip away award provisions; they take protections out of the hands of the industrial commission, an industrial commission that has had a central place in determining the relationship between workers and employers ever since the Harvester decision, I think, in 1905 or 1906. Then really progressive elements—a combination of the High Court sitting in relation to the Harvester judgment, the Australian Labor Party in this federal parliament and the progressive Deakinite Liberals who came just after that in 1907 but were there at that time—initiated an industrial relations system that has served this country well since 1906.

But for this government, this Prime Minister, this minister for workplace relations, less is more. Cutting away people's award conditions, slicing into a productive relationship between employers and people at the workplace—that is a key to what they see as reform. We see it as a change that is deleterious not just to the country as a whole but to every individual who works either for this federal government or out in private industry. I have seen it in the last couple of weeks in De Havilland in Bankstown, where workers have been made redundant on the model put forward by the minister for workplace relations. They were assisted in that, directly, by one of the advisers, one of the people who was closely associated with the member for Flinders.

This bill is about doublespeak; this bill argues that less is more; this bill is a further concentration of power in the hands of the employers. It is not about an equal or fair balance between employers and employees. It is about readjusting that balance, and the actions of this ideologically driven government—and in no place more than workplace relations—are directly aimed at the reinstitution of a master-servant relationship that existed in the 19th century, actions that this minister and Prime Minister seek to push forward as hard and fast as they can. This is not about more jobs, better pay; that is newspeak for cutting workers to the bone.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and when the debate is resumed the member for Blaxland will have leave to continue speaking.

—I inform the House that the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry will be absent from question time today and tomorrow. He is travelling to Montreal to attend the Quint Forum of agriculture ministers from the United States, the European Union, Japan, Canada and Australia, followed by a series of official meetings in Canada and the US which will focus on the forthcoming World Trade Organisation agricultural negotiations. The Minister for Forestry and Conservation will act as Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry during the other minister's absence.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. Do you recall on 9 September saying that you would be seeking from President Clinton a US combat force contribution to an East Timor multinational force? Do you recall saying, `We want boots on the ground'? Have you seen the interview on this morning's Today show where US Secretary of Defense, William Cohen, categorically stated that `Australia has not at any time requested a contribution of combat troops from the United States' for the INTERFET operation? Prime Minister, can you explain why you did not request combat troops from the United States when you said you would?

—I have seen the interview on television with Mr Cohen, and it is important to remind the House that what he said was, `The answer is no, no formal request for such a commitment.' As I am sure the Leader of the Opposition knows, in a relationship such as that between Australia and the United States a formal request that is made is of those assets that you know you are going to get. The reality is that it was made very clear to us in discussions between me and President Clinton—and there were three such discussions—and also in discussions between Mr Moore and Mr Cohen that, although the United States would provide significant assets, the United States—for domestic political and other reasons—was very reluctant and in fact felt unable to provide combat troops. That was the position that was made clear to me.

answer.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is a serious issue and it deserves a careful answer, and if the Leader of the Opposition has any further questions I would be very happy to respond because I want to make it very clear that we regard the American contribution that has been made as very effective. The American support is very effective, it is very welcome, and I am in no way critical of the contribution that the Americans are making. It is very valuable indeed, and it is being provided to the complete satisfaction of the Australian Defence Force.

answer.para: I should make it clear that when I first discussed this matter with President Clinton on 6 September I indicated to him that the Australian government and the Australian people expected an American involvement. He immediately made it clear to me that that involvement to the extent of involving combat troops would be extremely difficult. He pointed out that the Americans already had 14,000 troops in Kosovo, that the Congress was unsympathetic and that, although he would take on board all of the requests that we had made, that that would be difficult. In a subsequent conversation between me and the President an exchange to a similar effect took place and, in discussions between Mr Cohen and Mr Moore, Mr Moore canvassed the possibility of an American troop contribution, and a similar response was given.

So the situation very plainly is that there was no doubt at all in the discussions that took place between the President and me and between the defense secretary and the defence minister that an American troop contribution was canvassed. But it was made equally clear to us by the Americans that, for a combination of reasons, they felt unable to provide combat troops on this occasion but would provide a large number of other assets.

There were discussions between the military of the two countries and the assets ultimately provided and ultimately contained on the list that was sent to the Americans were to the complete satisfaction of the Australian Defence Force. That is why, Mr Speaker, you will note the secretary has used the expression `no formal request for such a commitment'. The reality is that in a situation such as this you have a lot of discussions in advance. You formally request what you know you will actually get. You do not formally request something which you know from earlier discussions, for a combination of reasons, is simply not going to be available.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Would the Prime Minister outline any plans by the government to examine further reform of welfare and social policy, building on reforms already implemented and reflecting the government's commitment to maintaining a strong social safety net?

—I thank the honourable member for Moreton. Like many colleagues on this side of the House, the honourable member has a very deep interest in intelligent, long-term reform of Australia's social welfare system—the sort of reform that protects the weak and the vulnerable and also provides incentives for people to get off welfare and to break the cycle of welfare dependency.

answer.para: My colleague the Minister for Family and Community Services announced at the National Press Club today that the government proposed to establish a reference group to develop a green paper on further welfare reform. I know that this announcement will be very widely welcomed by many in the opposition—the member for Lilley, the member for Werriwa and many others—who have spoken very regularly over recent months of the importance of fundamental reform to Australia's welfare system: a reform, I repeat, that continues to keep in place the safety net, a reform that continues to protect the weak and the vulnerable but a reform that recognises the need to break welfare dependency, that recognises the need to entrench the principle of mutual obligation in our society.

I am pleased to announce that the chairmanship of the reference group has been accepted by Mr Patrick McClure of Mission Australia. Mr McClure is a well-known and respected figure in one of the major welfare organisations of this country. Mr McClure, along with officers from Senator Newman's department and others, will provide a marvellous reference group for the development of this white paper. The preliminary findings will be delivered to the government by early in the year 2000, with a final report in June of next year.

The reference group has been asked to consider reform proposals against a number of principles. They include maintaining a strong social safety net where those who are in genuine help will always be supported, the principle of mutual obligation, prevention and early intervention, reducing welfare dependency, encouraging self-reliance and capacity building, establishing better incentives, and maintaining current budget policy. The group will seek submissions from interested groups and the broader community. In this way the broader community will be part of the social coalition examining further reform of the welfare system.

This government has already trailblazed many welfare reforms. We have put an end to excessive rorting of the welfare system. We have provided additional benefits to Australian families. We have reduced the withdrawal rate applying to many low income families. We have reversed the previous incentive for people to remain welfare dependent rather than go back to work. That is one of the great advantages of the taxation package that was passed in the teeth of opposition from the Australian Labor Party a few months ago. It is now time, on the eve of the new millennium, to move on to a newer and better debate about the future of welfare in this country, a debate that does not argue for a moment that the poor and the vulnerable need help and assistance but a debate which is designed to reduce the debilitating impact of welfare dependency within the Australian community generally. That has been recently recognised by leaders of the Aboriginal community such as Senator Aden Ridgeway and Mr Noel Pearson, both of whom have spoken eloquently and feelingly of the impact of welfare dependency on indigenous Australians. Their words apply with equal force to other sections of the Australian community. It is a forward looking debate. It is one the community needs to have. I hope all sections of the Australian community join it enthusiastically.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, can you give the House a categorical assurance that Senator Newman's suppressed welfare policy discussion paper contains no options to cut benefits, including those which form the compensation package for the GST, either in terms of cuts to the rates of benefits or in terms of reduction of access to benefits?
—It doesn't exist.
—The one in the bottom drawer.

—That is a wasted question, Wayne. What a wasted question. I will tell you what I will do: I will categorically assure the House that the compassion this government has displayed over the last 3½ years will continue.

—My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the minister advise the House of progress towards achieving the government's waterfront reform objectives? Are there any obstacles which may prevent the achieving of these objectives?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. He comes from one of those electorates that is very dependent on having an efficient capacity to export. So the jobs and so forth that they need to continue to promote in places like New England are very dependent upon us having an effective waterfront. Despite the opposition's consistent opposition to everything that we have sought to achieve, from the establishment and achievement of the seven benchmarks that were laid down in April of 1998 through to the general objectives of a highly competitive waterfront, the reality is that the government, the stevedores and their employees have pushed ahead with the reform.

answer.para: Today we see that we have managed the elimination of overmanning and restrictive work practices, with the voluntary reduction of 1,400 people. We have seen sustained and real improvements in waterfront reliability, with the statistics for the March and June quarters 1999 showing that berths were available within four hours for more than 90 per cent of the vessels that arrived here. Those who remember such things as the `Wran navy', they called it, off Sydney Heads and for months off Newcastle, will realise what an incredible turnaround over time that is. We have seen record average rates for container movements as well.

Just today, the June quarter 1999 Waterline edition has been released. It provides some very important further evidence of the progress we have made. It shows that the five port crane rate has again reached a new record high. The June quarter is the highest ever recorded in Waterline. It breaks the record set in March. The rate is now over 20 movements per hour, up from 19.9 in the March quarter and 18.9 in the December 1998 quarter. These are always a long way in front of anything that was managed when the ALP was in power. In fact, it is the first time that the rate has exceeded 20 movements per hour, and those champions of the working class regard it—all those jobs that depend upon us having an efficient waterfront—as something to guffaw about.

The reality is that, having laid the foundation in a very substantial way, the future rates, particularly from P&O, who are just completing their redundancy program, will show a significant improvement from now on. It is all up from here. The opposition seems to be unable to grasp the simple reality—that to be successful exporters need to enjoy an established reputation for being reliable suppliers. Reliability on the waterfront is something that was never achieved by Labor. Despite having achieved these very desirable ends, we now find the Labor Party is into continuing its opposition. We now find that it seeks to cut in half the additional funding required by MIFCo, from $100 million to $50 million.

The fact is that the government's waterfront package embraces a range of elements, not just redundancies. We believe that there is scope for further improvement in a range of areas, from occupational health, which the opposition would surely support, to safety regimes, new technology and improved training. That is one of the reasons that we seek an extension of around $100 million. The opposition wants to cut it in half. I would have thought that it would have recognised the value of pursuing those objectives and the essential correctness of the principle that the waterfront industry ought to pay for it, rather than the taxpayer.

The government have always made it plain that we would deal with redundancies first— in the approach laid down by my colleague, the minister right behind me—and would then move on to implement other worthwhile reforms. That is what we continue to seek to do. The fact is that the opposition's proposal to reduce the appropriation by $50 million will create administrative uncertainty. It may very well create uncertainty for the financiers of the Maritime Industry Finance Company—MIFCo—and it may also mean that the government would have to come back for a further appropriation. That is not in the interests of anyone—least of all the people in this country, the workers across this nation, who depend upon an efficient waterfront for their future prosperity.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that the minister table the documents from which he was so copiously quoting.
—Was the minister reading from confidential notes? The minister was reading from confidential notes.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, yesterday you advised the House that our commitment of 2,000 troops in East Timor `for six months or so' would cost more than $500 million. Will you now confirm that we have committed 4,500 troops to INTERFET in East Timor and that this commitment is likely to be for longer than six months, as confirmed yesterday by your defence minister? What is the cost? Do you agree with Access Economics that the cost could be up to as much as $2 billion per year?

—The situation, as the member for Cunningham said, is that the commitment is for up to 4,500 troops. The deployment at the moment is in the order of 2,000 and, depending on circumstances, it could rise. I indicated yesterday, so the House was in no way misinformed, that the original figure of $500 million was on the basis of about a six-month deployment. If the 2,000 goes on longer than six months, obviously the $500 million will be higher, and if the number increases for a longer period, that will be higher again.

answer.para: What is happening at the moment is that I am having work done by the Department of Defence and the Department of Finance and Administration about the precise projections on future costs. I do not have those figures ready yet, and I do not think there is any reason why we should. We are dealing with a situation that was not reasonably contemplated with the degree of precision that would be required to answer your question now when the budget was put together. It would be quite unreasonable for the government to be able to produce that figure out of thin air. We are working on it and, as soon as we are in a position to inform not only the parliament but also the Australian public of the likely cost scenarios, given possible outcomes and levels of troop deployment, we will certainly do it—and also how it relates to other areas of government spending and revenue, to the extent that we can. That would certainly be something that would at least have to await the context of the mid-year financial and economic assessment.

It is no secret that this troop deployment will cost this country a lot of money. We are perfectly happy to acknowledge what it will cost when we know the full extent of it. We are perfectly happy to explain the relationship of that to the other obligations of the government. There will not be any reluctance on the part of this government to do that. I note that the opposition has already indicated its support for increased defence spending, and I welcome that. We will try to do this thing in a constructive, open fashion. I am the last person in this country who wants to hide from the Australian people the reality that our involvement in a very important issue in this region is going to cost us money. I am pleased that the accounts of the Commonwealth are strong and in surplus. I would hate to have Timor on my lap with a $10½ billion deficit.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, does the federal government support the proposal by the New South Wales unions and government that employees who choose not to join unions be required to pay $200 to $500 each year to a trade union? What do these proposals demonstrate about the industrial relations and political priorities of the advocates of such a policy? Can federal laws provide security to non-unionists from the impact of these proposals?

—I thank the member for her question. We have today released details of one of the most partisan and ideological policy proposals coming out of a state Labor administration and its bosses in the state labour council.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The proposal—I deduce, from the heckling, that it is clearly supported by the frontbench of the Labor Party—is that people in New South Wales who have elected not to be a member of a union will be required to pay a fee of $250 to $500 a year to the trade union movement in New South Wales. People who have exercised their basic right to decide whether or not they will be a member of a union will be penalised as a means of gathering up a huge slush fund for the Labor Party and the unions in New South Wales. It makes a mockery of the Labor Party—who talk about concern for the battlers and in circumstances where a person is required to pay $500—that with one stroke of the pen, pushed by a trade union leader, they would take close to the entire benefit of the safety net living wage increases which they have had under the federal coalition government. It is an absolute outrage. This morning, when referring to the government's Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 , the member for Paterson said this about a $500 charge:

answer.para: . . . to the breadwinner of a family $500 can be a month's repayment of the mortgage. It can mean being able to eat that month or not, it can mean the family having a holiday at Christmas or not and it can mean having something in the Christmas stocking or not.

Yet his party is proposing a charge which could bring to the coffers of the unions in New South Wales between $400 and $500 million a year. Not only would we see this charge imposed on more than a million workers in New South Wales but also they had the incredible audacity to put up a proposal which would see the same charge being placed on people running small businesses as independent contractors. You might ask: was this proposal put to the people of New South Wales before the last state election by the Labor government? Of course, the answer is no, it was not. What was their policy? Their policy was to have a review of industrial relations policy after the election. That is exactly the same deceptive tactic that is their policy position today; that is, slug millions of workers with a new charge which will fill the slush funds of the ALP and the unions.

I can assure the New South Wales Labor government—as I have already done—that the federal government is totally opposed to this particular measure. We will take all necessary steps to prevent the implementation of such a measure. I say to workers in New South Wales who have exercised their basic democratic right to decide not to be in a union that, if they want some relief from this onerous obligation which is about to be put on them by the New South Wales Labor government, if they are within the federal law they are of course safe from such heavy-handed practices by the Labor Party and the trade unions. If the Leader of the Opposition has the guts to stand up to the trade unions, we would like him to give this parliament an assurance that it will never be part of Labor's federal policy to impose this new tax on people for exercising their basic freedoms.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of media reports that Portugal is willing to spend up to $100 million per annum on the cost of reconstructing East Timor? Do you stand by your statement on CNN Asia this morning that Australia would be prepared to do `quite a lot' towards the cost of East Timor's reconstruction? Given that the Treasurer is presently overseas seeking contributions from other nations towards this cost, will you now advise the House how much Australia will commit to East Timor's reconstruction?

—It is true that I did say on television this morning something which I have said frequently in the past—it is something which I imagine everyone in this House would agree with—that is, that Australia should contribute a significant amount to East Timor's future. After all, it is hardly reasonable to support a country's aspiration for freedom and then run away from it when it has an appalling living standard.
—Have you got a figure?

—I do not have a precise figure and I am not going to just grab one out of the air. What we are going to do, bearing in mind that East Timor is in a state of political transition at the present time—it is still part of Indonesian sovereignty and will be until the act of separation from the Indonesian state occurs—is, in consultation with the United Nations, Australia will join in an international effort. There will need to be an assessment made of the needs of East Timor. On the basis of what I have been told, I can say that the infrastructure has virtually gone and the living standard is very low. When it does become independent, it will have one of the lowest living standards of any country in the world. The number of professional people there in the nature of doctors and teachers will be very low indeed. Overall, the territory will need a great deal of support and a large volume of resources. It will take some time before an intelligent figure can be compiled through international collaboration.

answer.para: Flowing from that, it will also take some time before the precise size of a contribution from Australia can be calculated. But I can assure the House that just as soon as we are able to say what that figure is and what the government is willing to contribute, we will make that figure public. If what the honourable member is getting at is that this will have budgetary implications, the answer is yes, it will. I am not going to disguise that for a moment, but I do not know what those implications are. I do not think it is reasonable for the government to be required now to nominate a figure. What is reasonable is that the government should be asked whether we remain committed to helping an independent East Timor and the answer is yes, we are. We made it clear months ago that we were willing to do that and I have made that clear to the Secretary-General of the United Nations.

Just as this country was prepared to play a major role in the multinational force, we are prepared to play a major role in the reconstruction of East Timor. But we are not going to play a solo role in the reconstruction of East Timor; we will expect the rest of the world to make healthy contributions as well. To ask me now to nominate precisely what that figure is, with great respect, is wasting a question.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment Services. Minister, would you inform the House of measures available to assist workers affected by the imminent closure of BHP's steel making facility in Newcastle?

—I thank the member for Robertson for his concern for the retrenchees of BHP, some of whom live in his electorate. When BHP announced two years ago that it was finishing up steel making in Newcastle, it marked the end of an era. But was it a portent of Newcastle's industrial decline, or was it more a sign that the Hunter was joining the information and service economy, as a former Labor member of this place suggested that it might? As the furnaces have finally closed, there is nostalgia, there is sorrow and there is some anger—but there is also some appraisal of where the Hunter goes from here. This is not the first economic blow or the heaviest that Newcastle has suffered: BHP shed 9,000 jobs in the 1980s. But these job losses are acutely felt because they come at a time when much of the country is enjoying very buoyant economic conditions.

answer.para: I am advised that just under 1,500 workers will leave BHP this week, and BHP expects that 900 of these will be looking for other work. BHP expects between 300 and 400 subcontractor employees to be affected.

talk.start.para: —What about all the other contractors?
—The member for Shortland!

—Many of these work for large businesses with the capacity to redeploy staff.
