The area consultative committee of my department has advised that there are eight subcontracting firms with 105 staff largely dependent on BHP. The government has just approved a $100,000 package to provide the mentoring that these firms need to readjust.
—What about jobs?

—Ever since the BHP shutdown announcement the government has been working closely with the Newcastle community and with the state government. The Prime Minister has made four trips to Newcastle to meet with the social task force chaired by Mr Rob Chenery and by Mr Kevin Maher of the Australian Workers Union. We established a $10 million fund to support employment in Newcastle and the Hunter, and over $9 million has been committed so far: $1½ million to upgrading Newcastle Airport, half a million dollars for the Lower Hunter water pipeline, $1½ million to a transport and distribution centre in Maitland, $2 million in principle to upgrade Forgacs Shipyard and $2½ million towards the Impulse Airlines reservations centre.

answer.para: In some ways this is a sad ending for BHP, but it is also a new beginning for the Hunter. In April the Prime Minister opened a British Aerospace fighter support facility at Williamtown, which will directly employ 250, with 200 support jobs. The Prime Minister has also announced that Williamtown will host the Air Force's early warning aircraft from 2004, which means an extra 280 RAAF and support jobs. The Huon minehunter project and the refurbishment of two amphibious support ships are a further $1 billion boost to the Hunter economy. The government has also provided a $30 million tax break to assist the Redbank power station, which will employ 1,000 people in the construction phase and 250 workers and contractors once completed.
I just want to make two final points. The first is that BHP has handled this closure like a truly model corporate citizen. On this matter the Big Australian has been the Big Hearted Australian.
Ms Hall interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Shortland!
—I am advised that total payments to the BHP retrenchees are in the order of half a billion dollars, which is obviously a massive cash injection for the local economy.
—But they've got no jobs.
—To aid job matching services available under the Job Network, BHP has set up for its workers an in-house, on-site employment centre which will operate until December next year.
—Give us something other than rhetoric.
—The member for Shortland has been persistently reminded by the chair of the obligation she has to be courteous in the House. I warn her.
—The final point I would make is that Newcastle is bigger than BHP. It is a town with a tough reputation.
—And it's got a lot of unemployed workers. It's about time you helped them.

—The people of Newcastle are tough enough to rise to this challenge, as they have to so many in the past. Janet Murray, one of the BHP retrenchees who is going on to start up her own business, said this morning:

answer.para: Newcastle is well equipped to meet the challenge this time round.
The government has played its part to help.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, my question is to the Prime Minister. I refer to the government's acknowledgment that the business tax package is currently not revenue neutral. In light of the significant new cost to the budget arising from Australia's commitment to peacekeeping and aid for East Timor, will you ensure that the business tax package is revenue neutral by guaranteeing to implement all of the deferred measures, including the anti-avoidance measures?

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will be aware of the commitments that have been made by the Treasurer on behalf of the government in relation to the fullness or the amplitude of the business tax package, and I support what the Treasurer has said—it represents a statement of government policy. As to the other matters that the honourable gentleman raises, of course the House will get more information from the government in relation to the additional defence costs as and when it becomes available. That is our position. I have made it clear twice, and I will say it again: whenever more information about the costs is available I will be very happy to make it available to the House.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Will the minister advise the House of actions the government is taking to ensure that the views of young Australians are heard? What are the government's expectations of the meeting of the National Youth Roundtable?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Blair for his question, and I acknowledge his great interest in young people in his electorate and in ensuring that they have appropriate educational opportunities. The National Youth Roundtable is currently meeting in Parliament House and I am pleased that a number of members from both sides of the chamber have attended presentations by the roundtable. This generation of young Australians is probably the best educated generation that this country has yet seen. Young Australians want the opportunity to put their views to government. They believe they have something to contribute, and they do have something to contribute. The government, through the National Youth Roundtable, is providing an unprecedented opportunity for the coming generation of young Australians to put their views directly to government. The Youth Roundtable consists of 50 young Australians aged 15 to 24 years who are selected from almost 1,000 applicants. They come from all states and territories, they span the age group 15 to 24 and they include a wide mix of young people, many of whom have overcome barriers to success, such as disabilities, homelessness and unemployment.

answer.para: Since March this year, the members of the Youth Roundtable have been consulting widely in their communities and they have now returned to Parliament House to present the results of their consultations with young people around Australia. The members of the Youth Roundtable have unprecedented access to government—the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister, senior ministers, parliamentary secretaries, government advisers and officials from many Commonwealth departments. The result of this, as I am sure any member of the House who was present this morning at the presentations by the roundtable will recognise, is the extraordinary quality of the work that has been done by the members. The roundtable has already made a significant contribution. It drafted a preamble to the Constitution, which the government took into account in putting forward its proposed preamble.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! I warn the member for Batman and I warn the member for Grayndler.

—The members of the roundtable are very conscious of the fact that young Australians have very often been in the front line in defending the democratic and humanitarian values for which this country stands. We were very pleased to see in the statement issued by the roundtable that it was strongly supportive of Australia's peacekeeping operation in East Timor. They recognise that young people over there might well have been members of the youth roundtable themselves. I take it as a matter of great credit to the members of the roundtable that they have been very conscious of the responsibilities that they carry. As I said, the members of the roundtable are currently presenting the results of their consultations around Australia, and members on both sides of the House are welcome to attend.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Insurance Premiums

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration, representing the Treasurer. Do you stand by the Treasurer's claim last year that the GST package will increase insurance costs by only 0.8 per cent? If so, how do you explain the fact that many Australians are being asked to pay insurance premiums now, for the period after 1 July 2000, where the GST has increased the cost by close to 10 per cent, not 0.8 per cent?

—I note that in the question that has been put to me a number of assumptions and assertions have been made which have been attributed to the Treasurer's statement last year. I cannot recollect that statement. I have no reason to believe that it is not correct, but I will check that first to see whether those figures that were stated to me, which do not immediately come to me as being the figures I was aware of, are correct. In response to the honourable member, it is easy for the opposition to come in here and fire figures around to try to support a particular claim that they might want to make at this time or any other time. In the process of so doing they want to ignore at all times the beneficial impact of the new tax system. There are significant beneficial impacts of the new tax system, which clearly the Leader of the Opposition does not want to hear about.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question was specifically related to the fact that the government has said there would be a 0.8 per cent impact on the cost of insurance premiums, and there has been a 10 per cent impact. It is not alone in its failure to achieve what was predicted by the government, but it is a specific—

—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. He cannot argue the point of order. The Minister for Finance and Administration was responding to a question about the cost impact of the GST, and is in order.

—As I indicated on numerous occasions, on isolated instances they will come in and they will raise assertions. The point of order taken by the Leader of the Opposition clearly demonstrated that. I will repeat that the new tax system which this government and this parliament supported will bring significant benefits to all Australians, more affordability for insurance and more affordability for many other areas in the community.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The question was explicitly, after it canvassed the 0.8 per cent, `If so, how do you explain the fact that many Australians are being asked to pay insurance premiums where the GST has increased the cost by close to 10 per cent?' That is it; end of question. How does he explain it?
—The Leader of the Opposition has raised a point of order that had already been dealt with. I call the Minister for Finance and Administration.

—Again, I repeat that I will look at those figures and see whether there is accuracy or otherwise in them. I repeat that it is all very fine for the Labor opposition to talk about any particular figures and to ignore the significant boost to the economy that the new tax system will provide.

—My question is to the Minister for Sport and Tourism. In the light of the importance of the tourism industry as a generator of jobs and economic activity, particularly in regional Australia, can the minister inform the House of recent government initiatives which will help maximise growth prospects in this sector?

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Sport and Tourism; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Cook for his question. I know that he comes to this House with enormous experience in tourism, being the former CEO of Tourism Council Australia. We have with us in the House today the current CEO of Tourism Council Australia, Phil Young. Both Phil Young and I are today hosting a tourism leaders forum here in Parliament House. This is a reflection of how seriously this government takes tourism as an industry.

answer.para: The tourism forum is looking for ways to grow tourism in a sustainable manner that will generate wealth and jobs not just for those in our tourism centres but also out into regional Australia. With that in mind, it is with great delight that I announce today the release of our Regional Online Tourism program, which is a way of boosting the promotion of tourism to our regions. In accordance with govern ment policy, it was published on the web in the first instance. The Internet is revolutionising the way that tourism does business. While much of the tourism industry has recognised the potential of this technology, it is important that our regions are not left behind with this technology. This particular initiative joins our $350 million over four years to the ATC, as well as our doubling of the regional tourism program and our contribution of $8 million to the domestic tourism initiative. There are many great things to come with our tourism leaders forum here in Australia and from this Howard government.

talk.start.para: —We could have learned about the increase in air fares from the GST. My question—
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition does not have the call. If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition wishes to ask a question, he will go straight to the question.

—My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration, again representing the Treasurer. With the GST impact on products such as insurance premiums, advertising, petrol, car prices and air travel—just to repeat the point—set to increase well beyond your predictions, how can you continue to claim that your GST calculations are valid? Have you received advice on the inflation impact of the revised GST package? What is that impact? Do you now expect the CPI to increase by more than the 1.9 per cent you originally promised?

question.para: Mrs Irwin —Page 10, paragraph 2.

talk.start.para: —The member for Fowler!
—The member for Fowler is warned. I call the Minister for Finance and Administration.
—The member for Fowler has been warned. I will tolerate no further interjections.

—There was adequate information and data provided by the government accompanying A New Tax System at the time of its release and adequate further information given as to the modelling that was done in terms of the inflationary impact on that new tax system. The government has continually supported the inflationary impact that it has asserted in respect of a new tax system, and that, of course, is a complete system of which the GST is in fact one component. The government stands by the inflationary impact that it has stated will flow from the new tax system. Any attempts on the part of the opposition to suggest—
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. It goes to relevance.

—The chair has deliberately allowed all members to elaborate on the question of relevance. I will allow the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to do so, but it is very difficult for me to imagine any area in which in the last 50 seconds the minister has said anything other than something relevant to the question.

—The member for Lyons is warned. I have had quite enough of the behaviour of members on both sides of the House in this question time. I will now extend a good deal more leniency to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition than is obliged by the standing orders, and I expect that courtesy to be reciprocated.
—My question said, `Has he received any revised advice from Treasury on the inflation impact?' So it is not what you are standing by but whether there has been advice received from Treasury.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

—I repeat again that the government stands by its statements in respect of the inflationary impact of A New Tax System. As far as I am aware, no further information has been provided to suggest that what we have stated previously is not the situation at this point in time.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Today is national remembrance day for police officers killed on duty. Attorney-General, will you inform the House whether any steps are being taken to mark this occasion?

—I thank the member for Wentworth for the question. Today is a day on which we remember men and women of our police forces who have given their lives in the line of duty. Police are sometimes not accorded the acknowledgment they deserve—some of us tend to take safety, security and wellbeing for granted—yet police live and deal with danger, violence and tragedy on a daily basis. Sadly, members of the police force often become victims of violence themselves. The recent tragic slaying in Darwin of Sergeant Glen Huitson and the equally tragic death of Constable Ty Bennett in southern Tasmania, as well as the deaths of Senior Constable Simon De Winne in Victoria and Senior Constable Gordon Patrick in Western Australia, are graphic illustrations of this reality. These deaths all occurred in the last 12 months. Today the honour roll for those police officers killed in the exercise of their duty was read as part of a National Police Remembrance Day service held here in Canberra. The service provided the opportunity for reflection on those lives cut short during community service.

answer.para: Police fight a war on a day-by-day basis against those who bring violence to society. The Australian people should consider police who risk their lives in the course of their duty with a similar sense of pride and thanks to that accorded to the men and women who have served this country during times of war. I am sure all members of this House will agree that it is fitting that on this day we take time to reflect on the debt we owe for the sacrifices of members of our police forces.

talk.start.para: —Hear! Hear!

—My question is again to the Minister for Finance and Administration representing the Treasurer. Can you confirm that the ABS is currently working on a new CPI measure that removes the impact of tax increases? If so, will you guarantee that this measure will not be used to hide the real impact of the GST on the inflation rate?
—No, I cannot confirm, but I will make an inquiry. The second question is irrelevant until such time as I ascertain whether there is any veracity in the first question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. In view of the minister's forthcoming visit to Singapore and Japan, could you inform the House of developments in our export markets and opportunities for pork in those important markets?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. Obviously, as a member who represents an area that exports a lot of agricultural commodities, he is interested in the discussions that will take place in Singapore on Friday between CER and AFTA, as we export some $10.4 billion worth of exports to the ASEAN countries. Of course Japan is Australia's largest trading partner, at around 20 per cent of our exports, but I might just focus on a particular area of export in answering this question. That is the excellent performance of Australia's pork industry, and we will be making an announcement at the launch and promotion of Australian chilled pork in Singapore on Friday, organised by the Confederation of Australian Pork Exporters. It is interesting to note that Australian exports of pork have more than doubled—from 6,674 tonnes, worth $33 million in 1996-97, to over 16,350 tonnes, worth $70 million last year.

answer.para: Japan has accounted for most of this growth, with exports rising from 747 tonnes to 4,429 tonnes. Exports to Singapore have absolutely boomed. In January exports to Singapore stood at $8,000 a month; in July they amounted to $6.4 million worth. The market for air freight fresh chilled pork from Australia to Singapore now accounts for approximately 6,000 pigs a week.

Members will recall last year the difficult circumstances that were being confronted by Australia's pork industry. The government made a decision to assist the producers in that industry and it is paying dividends in spades. It was interesting that in last week's Queensland Country Life the editorial, `Pork industry kicking goals', read:

A remarkable transformation is taking place in Australia's pork industry. Only a year ago the industry was in crisis. Knives were out for the then Agriculture Minister, John Anderson, who was being accused of destroying the domestic industry by allowing imported pork to compete on the domestic market. Today, prices are at a three-year high and climbing, export markets have been established and the industry is entering a growth phase firmly aimed at supplying the massive and nearby Asian market.

Australia's export pork industry is one of Australia's great export stories of the last six to 12 months—with the assistance and guidance of our government and the policy that we have pursued in this area—and I am going to reinforce that in Singapore and Japan at the end of this week.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. It is now 15 months since the minister called for statutory declarations to test the validity of the suspect MRI contracts and 10 months since the Health Insurance Commission started its investigation of allegations of backdating. Why is this investigation still incomplete? When will the minister table the promised report? As there is nothing in the Health Insurance Act which prevents the minister releasing the dates on which these contracts were signed, will he now disclose the dates or will he continue to keep them secret to cover up his own role in the budget leak?

—At the outset, on Monday I tabled, along with a statutory declaration, a statement from my former staff member. That statement has now been provided to me in the form of a statutory declaration and I make it available to honourable members.

answer.para: Let me start with the end of the question first. There has been absolutely no evidence whatsoever to confirm that there was a budget leak. What happened—and I was informed of this only on Monday—was that as early as February 1998 one of the companies that sells MRIs went around a conference in Sydney saying, `You'd better sign up now. It's coming in the budget and the government is going to have a supply measure.' I do not quite know how they knew this, as we first considered the supply measure in the first week of May, so there was considerable speculation in the industry that there would be a supply measure months ahead of when we did it. That is the first point.

The second point is that this was not a secret negotiation. The Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee said in October 1997 that the government should fund MRI. I had said publicly that we would try to find a way to fund MRI. I began formal negotiations with the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists in February 1998, as I recollect, with the express authority of the expenditure review committee to discuss with them the full possibilities of a budget measure. This was necessary because the whole budget measure led to savings of $80 million over a three-year period, and this could not be done without the cooperation of the College of Radiologists. So there was a great deal of speculation.

We did not make our decision to have a supply measure until the first week of May—I think I was first told about it on 5 May, so I do not concede there was a budget leak. I do concede that some people in the College of Radiologists knew about it. I do not know how those people behaved, and I do not know whether or not they ordered machines. If they did I think it is quite improper, but I do not want to speculate on that; they will be found out through the investigation process that we have put in place. I concede that the investigation has taken a long time. I have asked the Health Insurance Commission to finish it as fast as possible, but I have not attempted to interfere with the investigation because it does need to be at arms-length from government. I can assure the honourable member that, as soon as it becomes available, I will make the report itself available.

Finally, this whole measure has made a new imaging technology dramatically more available than it ever was under the Labor Party. When I came to government there was not one of these machines available anywhere in rural Australia. Today there are 19 of these machines in rural and non-metropolitan areas and we have an $80 million budget saving to boot.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Minister, what are you doing to ensure that East Timorese evacuees who were brought to Darwin are appropriately settled as a matter of urgency in safe havens?

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I am sure members of the House are interested in what is happening in relation to the East Timorese who have been evacuated to Australia. Some 1,500 people were evacuated from East Timor to Darwin and have been resident in a camp under canvas in a situation of some vulnerability as we approach the wet season. For that reason, we have been anxious to move people to sites that will provide more secure accommodation, albeit temporary. A total of 813 people have been moved to Puckapunyal, which is a safe haven in Victoria, and 402 people have been moved to the Leeuwin safe haven site in Western Australia. To achieve this outcome, these sites had to be vacated by Kosovars, who either were intent on returning to Kosovo or had to move to other safe haven centres. I make that point because there are a further group of East Timorese in the reception centre in Darwin who have been identified for placement in a haven centre, but they cannot be moved until Kosovo evacuees are consolidated into a smaller number of havens. Of the 3,900 Kosovars who came to Australia, 2,600, or two-thirds, have now returned home. A further 600 have indicated to us a desire to do so by the end of October. That leaves us with around 700 who, at this stage, have not indicated a desire to return and who may seek to stay on until such time as the UNHCR says they can be moved home in a way which is not voluntary. But, up to the moment, it has been a voluntary repatriation.

answer.para: It is important for the House to know that this morning I visited the East Hills haven site in Sydney because it has been identified as necessary to accommodate the East Timorese. I told them that the East Hills Kosovars who are leaving Australia on the next charter flight on 6 October can stay until the flight goes, but of all the others I have said that, unless they have the strongest medical reasons for staying at East Hills—independently corroborated—there will be a requirement for them to move to the other safe havens before then. You will appreciate that there has been some indication to me that, unlike the situation at Leeuwin and Puckapunyal, people are intent on not moving on. For that reason, I have indicated that access to the living allowance, phone cards and the haven facilities will be available for former East Hills residents only at the havens that we have identified Those havens are at Bandiana and Portsea in Victoria and Brighton in Tasmania. Similar arrangements will be made for the Hampstead and Singleton residents, where we need also to have the sites available. There are very good and substantial reasons for this. I am disappointed that, although the Australian community has a desire to accommodate the East Timorese appropriately—we have numbers waiting in Darwin for that accommodation now—the capacity to respond, if there are any further requests, is being jeopardised by a lack of cooperation.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister advise the outcome of his inquiries into what form of notes was made at his late evening meeting with the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists on 6 May 1998? Has the minister been able to confirm how many of the 31 suspect MRI contracts were taken out by members of the executive and negotiating task force of the Royal Australian College of Radiologists?
—I did ask the department again yesterday after question time, and they informed me that no minutes or notes were taken, which is the reason why I have tabled two statutory declarations.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The meeting was an informal meeting, largely to say thanks to the College of Radiologists. I know that the shadow minister is interjecting that this is unbelievable, but that shows that she does not understand the way health works nor the way that government works. It is not routine or normal to take minutes of every meeting. It does not happen and it did not happen in this case. But you have two statutory declarations there from two staff members who were at the meeting.

answer.para: The second thing she raised was whether I have confirmed how many machines were ordered by members of the executive. No, I have not, because I have not sought to interfere in any way with the investigation of the Health Insurance Commission. It is possible that there were machines ordered by members of the executive of the College of Radiologists. I would think that, had they done so, it would be highly improper. But it is possible that they did it. They were part of a negotiation which was specifically authorised by ERC.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the new, highly competitive interest rates offered by Aussie Home Loans on a new Aussie Card? Could the minister inform the House of the benefits of this new credit card? What opposition is there to future regulatory reform?

—I would like to thank the member for Page for his question. I know, certainly from past experience, that the member for Page has always taken a very keen interest in issues relating to consumers—particularly in his electorate, I might say. I thank the member for Page for drawing to my attention recent reports that Aussie Home Loans have now entered the credit card market. I am informed that they have entered the market with a 6.35 per cent honeymoon credit card rate in a transactional deal with American Express. That initiative is welcomed by the government. We encourage competition and we certainly encourage competition that involves new entrants coming to Australia—in the case of American Express, it has been here for a long time—in partnership with a local venture such as Aussie Home Loans, to provide to everyday Australians credit cards and credit facilities that are highly competitive.

answer.para: Honeymoon rates are a new product in credit cards. I do urge consumers to think very carefully and have look at the details of credit cards before they sign up. But I know that members such as the member for Parramatta, who is always in my ear about his local headquarters of Aussie Home Loans, are certainly strong advocates for greater competition. This new product adds to the already 200 organisations in Australia that supply 70 different credit cards—70 cards from 200 organisations. That sort of competition has come about because of the structural reform we have undertaken as a government. They are the sorts of reforms such as the Wallis reform or, as the Prime Minister said yesterday, some of the reforms that the Labor Party initiated when it was in government. But, in terms of the Labor Party, they were supported by the opposition. I need to ask a question: why is it that the opposition keep opposing every major reform that we try to undertake? They opposed us on retail tax reform, such as ANTS; they opposed us on industrial relations reforms; and, when it comes to corporate law reform, they oppose us there as well.

Why does the Labor Party keep opposing us on the structural reform which Alan Greenspan said is making a huge difference to Australia's competitiveness—not only in the Asian region but globally? We have got people around the world praising Australia for its regulatory reform; but let it be on the record that at every stage the Labor Party has opposed us in all of our reforms. We are still waiting for your response on Ralph, but we are not holding our breath.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Mr Speaker, by way of addition to the answer I gave to the mem ber for Cunningham, I mentioned that, as he would be aware, the original deployment of ADF personnel in Timor was to be in the order of 2,000. I am told that, as of today, there has been quite a rapid build-up and that the total number there now is 3,077.
—Mr Speaker, I would like to ask you to exercise standing order 150 and write to the Treasurer and ask him for my answers to questions 786, 787 and 788.
—I will follow up on the matter raised by the member for Stirling.
—Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members earlier today. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings .

debate.para: That today being National Remembrance Day for Police Officers Killed on Duty, this House remember the men and women of our police forces who have given their lives in the line of duty and acknowledge the debt we owe for the sacrifices of the members of our police forces.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports the motion.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Crean) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The uncertainty surrounding the government's ability to deliver its tax packages, particularly its GST compensation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —This matter of public importance is proposed today because, as the House has learned during question time, there are three significant emerging factors which are adding great uncertainty in terms of where the government is going. These three factors will add up to a pincer movement on low and middle income earners, who are already hit by the imposition of the GST. We have seen today the government acknowledging that there will have to be significant increased expenditure on defence—expenditure increase that we support because it is necessary to support our troops. But they have not been able to indicate to us how much, even though they must be becoming increasingly aware, as indicated by the Prime Minister's supplementary answer today, what the call-up on Australian troops will be.

speech.para: We have also seen today the government ducking and weaving on the CPI impact of the GST—a government that says it is still standing by its 1.9 per cent inflation effect of the GST, when everyone knows that to be a ludicrous figure. Of course if it is the wrong figure, not only is it bad for the economy but it impacts upon the compensation package that this government has been forced to introduce to coincide with the GST. We have argued before that this compensation package is already inadequate for low and middle income earners, but it will be further eroded with the higher CPI.

We have also had the Treasurer, on his overseas visit, talking about financing the increased defence expenditure through further expenditure cuts. The lesson is this: if as a government you are forced to dip into the surplus to the tune of $20 billion over three budgets to buy the GST—if you are going to do that off the budget to buy an unfair tax—then, when you run into budgetary difficulties, you will have to look at cutting the outlays. This of course is what we warned of when the GST was being introduced. We warned that the GST, once introduced, was there forever, but the compensation package could be eroded over time by the whim of the government. That was the experience in New Zealand. What we are now seeing is the repositioning by the government around its commitment in defence expenditure. We are seeing the Treasurer in Washington sowing the seeds for further cuts to outlays—and we can all speculate on what they would be.

Before I go to the individual points, the fundamental point I want to make is this: we always argued that the ordinary people of Australia did not get their fair share out of the government's tax packages. They did not get their fair share, but now it would seem they will have to pay more. They will have to bear more in terms of the cuts and they will have to bear more of the unfairness of these packages.

We know that we are going to have a much bigger defence corps. Access Economics has indicated today that it could be as high as $2 billion per year, and we await with interest what the Prime Minister has to say, because he has committed to coming back into this House to indicate the extent of expenditure. We have got another tax package—with legislation still to be introduced before this parliament—which does not pay for itself. That is the business tax package, which comes off the Ralph recommendations. That package is $3.8 billion short, on the government's own figuring.

talk.start.para: —We are not listening, Simon.

—There are plenty of people who are listening to this, Joe! And I will tell you what: as the responsible minister at the table, you should be listening, because you are leading this government further into fiscal profligacy.
—Order! The deputy leader will ignore the minister at the table and direct his remarks through the chair, and the minister at the table will be silent.

—Tell the overblown at the table to keep quiet, then. So you have got another business tax package which falls short to the tune of $3.8 billion, and you have got the Treasurer saying, `We are going to have to fund the defence expenditure out of expenditure cuts,' but he will not nominate them.

speech.para: Today's revelation that the need to increase expenditure on defence could cost up to $2 billion a year puts enormous additional strain on the budget. It is a necessary increase in defence spending which we support because we do have to back our troops, but the magnitude of it is sobering indeed. It ought to be another wake-up call for this government, because it not only has bungled the Timor incident in terms of where our troops are getting their support but also clearly did not foresee that this expenditure, if it were needed, would have great difficulty being met. The point that I want to repeat is that, if what you are doing is dipping into the surplus for matters that leave you no flexibility, when that flexibility is required what comes again is the harshness through the cuts.

But it is the fiscal loosening to date that really has left us exposed. It exposes the folly of dipping so massively into the surplus to fund the GST package—a package which is already in itself unfair; a package which costs $20 billion over three years. Now, with respect to the additional $3.8 billion that I have alluded to, the government will not give any firm commitments to reduce the next stage of fiscal loosening. The fact is that the business tax package does not pay for itself, and it is the minister at the table's figures that shows that it is short by $3.8 billion. That can be retrieved if the government is prepared to commit to implement the deferred items—the items that appear below the line in its announcements on Ralph. Those announcements involve significant crackdowns in certain areas of tax avoidance. But it is this area that the government will not act on. If it does not act on it, it means the business community is going to get, again out of the surplus, another $3.8 billion. How is that fair? Against the background of the $20 billion in GST compensation, half of which goes to the top 20 per cent of income earners in this country, how is that fair?

talk.start.para: —So you are opposing Ralph?
—Minister, that is not a legitimate question.

—How is the additional expenditure going to be met? That is what we want to hear from the minister. Will it come out of expenditure cuts? If so, in what areas? Or will the increased surplus be capable of paying for it in its own right? This is the question the Prime Minister will not answer but should answer. If we do not have that answer, we know that the inevitability is that people who can least afford it are going to be hurt.

speech.para: We have the Treasurer saying that he will not be dipping into his surplus and that it will have to come from expenditure cuts—this from a man who talks of the need to maintain surpluses but himself erodes them. Where are the expenditure cuts to be made—in the areas of health, education, employment programs? I would like to hear an answer to that question from the minister. Will it come from the compensation that was in the GST package or the access to benefits? These are the little leaks that we are starting to see emerge.

Jocelyn Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services, stood up and said, `We're going to make sure that we have another scheme that gets people off benefits and into reciprocal obligation.' In other words, we can read that as denying access to benefits for the disabled in our community. Why do you think she has been gagged today? Here was the build-up to her great presentation at the Press Club. There was supposed to be a white paper presented by her today. Instead we got a speech—a set of words on some white paper but no white paper. That has been hidden, and we want to know what is in that white paper.

The Prime Minister was stung into coming into this parliament to say that he was not going to cut these things, but we do not believe him. He is the same Prime Minister who said that pensioner compensation in the GST package would not erode to zero. We had to spend months in the Senate inquiry to prove that it would, but prove it we did. In the end, it was the Treasury itself that was forced to admit it, not the government. It was the constant pressuring and questioning by the Labor Party that demonstrated that the government was about dudding pensioners through the GST. So this mob has form in terms of whittling away and eroding the benefits. The government would like you to believe that it has all the bases covered, but the truth is that it does not. The government's hidden agenda is about eroding those benefits and stripping back the compensation. That was the New Zealand experience.

Again today the minister representing the Treasurer was not able to answer the question as to whether work is being done to take out from the CPI the impact of tax increases. What a convenience! I bet we will find that this little joy and this little trick will actually come in about the middle of next year, just when the GST bites. Not only is it a deceit in the same way as you refused amendments on the GST to disclose on receipts what the impact of the GST would be but this is another deceit to try to hide the full impact of the GST on inflation. Not only does it artificially indicate what the inflation figure is, but just think about all those measures that are geared to the CPI. If you are taking out this component, this is the back door to whittling away the compensation.

As I say, this government has got its problems on the budget because what it has tried to do is to engineer a massive redistribution in this community through two tax packages. Let there be no mistake about the unfairness of the GST package: 50 per cent of the tax cuts go to the top 20 per cent of income earners. What is fair about that, Minister? What is fair about that when you are imposing a 10 per cent tax on just about everything and when that hits those people on low and middle incomes hardest? That is what is wrong about a GST—it is regressive. So the $20 billion—half of it going to the top 20 per cent—is inherently unfair.

It now becomes essential for the government to bite the bullet on tax avoidance and anti-avoidance mechanisms if it wants to implement its business tax reforms—measures that are essential. What this government has done in halving the capital gains tax rate is open up a huge incentive for people who have the means to do it—and we know who they are; they are at the wealthier end of town—to convert their income into capital gains and end up paying a lower tax rate. This is what John Ralph himself has warned about. What we therefore want to see is the government commit to the revenue neutrality test and commit to implement those items which are below the line.

Labor is not prepared to endorse the package as it currently stands. We need to be satisfied on the two fundamentals: firstly, that the business tax reforms meet the revenue neutrality test and, secondly, that the government is serious about anti-avoidance measures. The revenue neutrality test can be met if all of the deferred measures are adopted, if the assumptions made and the costings are realistic and if there are no additional calls on the budget from Ralph. These are the answers that we need. Labor is not prepared to commit sight unseen. The community and the Australian public have been dudded already. They do not deserve to be dudded again. The government should end the uncertainty and come clean in this parliament. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—It is good to hear the Labor Party backbench giving the shadow Treasurer a big cheer at the end of his speech because they were paying no attention whatsoever during the speech. Half of them had left the building, obviously, and were not interested in hearing what the shadow Treasurer had to say.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Calm down, Simon; calm down. Mogadon. I now understand what the pain of opposition is all about. It is painful to listen to the opposition; it is painful to be part of the opposition. The only part of the AAP report of the words of Access Economics director Chris Richardson that the shadow Treasurer left out were:

speech.para: . . . and we are lucky enough that we are running a surplus at the moment . . .

Otherwise, the matter of public importance today has been a mantra from the shadow Treasurer about the direction of the budget. He has quoted almost verbatim from Access Economics director Chris Richardson. What he left out were the words:
. . . and we are lucky enough that we are running a surplus at the moment . . .

Why would he leave out those crucial words? Why would he leave out the words that summarise our budgetary position? I will tell you why. Because he has got form. The Labor Party have form. They have a history on this issue. They have a history when it comes to budget surpluses, or lack thereof, that they cannot run away from. We are not going to let them run away from their history. I am sure that the Australian public is not going to let them run away from their history. And why is that? Because over an extended period of time the Labor Party kept reassuring the Australian people in 1996 that the budget was in surplus.

The current Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley—who at that time was Minister for Finance and therefore knew the state of the budget—said to the Australian Pensioners and Investments Conference on 29 January 1996:
This strategy—
of fiscal consolidation—
has led to a small budget surplus in 1995-96 and growing surpluses forecast over our forward estimates period.

That was the Leader of the Opposition on 29 January 1996, three months before the federal election, who said, `We're running a surplus with growing surpluses over the next few years.' He was supported of course by the Prime Minister of the time, Paul Keating, who in his usual Keatingesque way said—and this had to be on AM —to Fran Kelly:
But again, let me remind you, Fran, we have the Budget in surplus. I mean, how many governments around the world have got a Budget in surplus?
Paul Keating—a great Keatingism—saying `Oh, come on, Fran, you know what we think. We have got a budget in surplus.' Again, Paul Keating was reported in February on AAP:
The budget is in surplus. At source, we don't have an underlying problem.
With that typical Keating arrogance, he repeated the words, this time on 14 February 1996—you could call it the budgetary Valentine's Day massacre—in the Australian Financial Review :
The budget, for God's sake, is in surplus for this year in the middle of the year. We have surpluses in prospect for the next three years.

We came into government 1½ months after that great Keating line—`For God's sake, it's in surplus, and we've got them in the out years.' We came into government, and the current Leader of the Opposition, who we have just been told has no position on business tax—what a surprise, the Labor Party has no position on business tax—had no position on the budget other than to say it was in surplus in February 1996. We came in to find a $10.3 billion deficit. As every Australian knows, if they have not got money in their pockets they have no flexibility—particularly flexibility to meet the crises of tomorrow.

And so it was disappointing that the shadow Treasurer came into this House, holier than thou, asking us to take a position on issues which he plainly knows we cannot take a position on which will give confidence and certainty to the Australian people. We have just put troops into East Timor as part of a peacekeeping force. We do not know how many troops will have to be committed over the next six to 12 months. We are doing what we can to strengthen the resources of the Australian Defence Force in their peacekeeping role, we are doing what we can to help the people of East Timor and we are doing what we can to put in place a system that will with the rest of the region and the rest of the world help to rebuild the infrastructure in East Timor, yet all the Labor Party can do is come into this House and, in a very non-bipartisan way, challenge everything we do in regard to East Timor to the extent that they are now challenging us about individual budget estimates of how much we will have to commit. We have never said we will not tell you. Why? Because on this side of the House we are honest. On this side of the House we introduced and passed through this parliament legislation called the Charter of Budget Honesty. We did that in response to everything I have talked about to this moment, including the misleading statements of the Labor Party to the Australian people about the state of the budget.

The Labor Party comes in here and says: `How are you going to pay for this? How are you going to pay for everything that you are pledging to do in East Timor?' I will tell you how we are going to pay. We are going to pay out of our surplus. If we have to replenish that surplus spent on East Timor by budget cuts, by expenditure cuts in other areas or by other forms of fiscal change, then you will find out about it in due course. But the fundamental fact is that we have a surplus, we have money available, and that is in stark contrast to absolutely everything the Labor Party has ever said about the budget. You can only compare the Labor Party's performance in this area with our performance—

talk.start.para: —Member for Grayndler, your deposit in the bank of tolerance is out. You are warned.
—No, don't come back at me. You were warned earlier this afternoon. The minister has the call.
—I was responding to him.
—I warn the honourable member for Grayndler.
—I am disappointed in the lack of discipline of members of the opposition, not only when it comes to economics but also when it comes to their attitude in this House.
—That is going a bit far.

—If the Labor Party were in government today, we can say with absolute certainty that the budget would be $7.5 billion worse than it is. We are currently projecting a significant budget deficit for the next financial year. We are projecting a deficit that will give us, over 2000-01, a surplus of $7.2 billion. That $7.2 billion surplus can cope with the demands placed on it by East Timor and Australia's commitment to East Timor. We can cope. So it is not a case of: where do you get the money from? If we want to maintain a budget surplus, we are going to maintain a budget surplus with measures that you will find out about in due course. But that is our current commitment outside of our expenditure commitments to East Timor.

speech.para: In contrast, the Labor Party would be in a far more difficult position because they would have no surplus. They would be over $7 billion worse off than we are today. With all the difficulties that we go through in this House and in the Senate trying to get the budget in order, every single measure the Labor Party oppose. We all remember the 1996 budget vividly. The Labor Party opposed every single measure in that budget, which was trying to fix a $10.3 billion legacy that they left us. It is no surprise. They oppose us on just about everything: industrial relations reform, corporate law reform, all the tax measures.

Today we had a revelation. The shadow Treasurer came into this House and said, `We have a position on Ralph. Our position is we don't have a position.' That is what he said; tell me if I am wrong. The shadow Treasurer came into this House and said, `We haven't got a position on Ralph.' I know what is happening. All the mutterings around the Labor Party back bench are coming to the fore. They are talking about whether they are going to support the capital gains tax cuts. I heard a couple of frontbenchers from the Labor Party talking about the equity measures. That was a very interesting little revelation to me. Suddenly the Labor Party is talking about equity, after foisting on the battlers of Australia a $10.3 billion deficit, after foisting on the battlers of Australia a wholesale sales tax regime which is moribund and which they sought to defend during the entire GST debate and after foisting on the people of Australia tax increases that they never compensated everyday Australians for. We remember the 1993 tax increases. They were meant to be the l-a-w tax cuts. That is the tradition of the Labor Party.

The Labor Party have this great tradition. They will tell you one thing and they will do the opposite. They are like an athlete who goes around wearing a T-shirt saying `I am drug free' and then is caught with steroids. What they tell the Australian people they do the opposite of, and they take pride in that. So when they come into this House and talk about equity we on this side of the House know full well that they are wondering how their mates can get ahead. And who are their mates? The union movement are their mates. Why don't we ask this question? I will just shoot this across the bow to let you know it is out there.

talk.start.para: —Order! Minister, before you shoot anything across anybody's bow, I might remind you that, although I am cognisant of the fact that you are addressing your remarks through the chair, a consistent and constant view of your back is somewhat less than entertaining.
—It is a whole lot better than my front.
—That is arguable.

—I would like to shoot something across the bow of the Labor Party. We on this side of the House know how many share portfolios the union movement has. We on this side of the House know, for example, that the unions in New South Wales pay no payroll tax, no land tax and no stamp duty on the transfer of shares. So when it comes to the Labor Party defending self-interest in the Ralph reforms, think very carefully. And when it comes to whom you seek advice from in relation to Ralph, we know the form. Paul Keating's biographer talked about it, Graham Richardson talked about it and Peter Walsh, a former finance minister, talked about it. They all said that the primary source of policy advice on tax for the Labor Party is the ACTU. When you have a good look at the Ralph reforms and when you think of self-interest, as only the Labor Party does, ask yourself these questions: how much tax are your mates in the union movement that fund your election campaigns paying? How big are their share portfolios? How many shares do they own? How many different portfolios do they cut across?

speech.para: Mr Albanese interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Labor Party do not have clean hands in relation to budget surpluses; they never have. Why? It is because they deliberately misled the Australian people about the state of the budgets when they were in government. So what position are they in, in opposition, to start lecturing us about surpluses? They are in no position, which is a position that they are most familiar with—a position of no position. They take no position; they make themselves a small target. That is good because they are going to stay in opposition for a very long time.
—Mr Deputy Speaker—

speech.para: Mr Albanese interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Grayndler! This is it. One more and you will not be here for the rest of this debate. The honourable member for Gellibrand has the call and the member for Grayndler should be silent.

—It is certainly hard for us on this side of the House to contain ourselves after hearing such a ridiculous response by the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. It is extraordinary to me, as a new member, that we can debate a matter of such importance—raised by our side of the House—about the government's ability to be able to deliver its tax package and in a 15-minute speech the minister cannot mention at all the government's capacity to be able to deliver on those changes. This debate is extremely important. It is a matter that goes to the very heart of how we are governed and it is about the priorities that are being set by the government of our country. It should deal with our priorities for spending and our priorities for the community that needs our help most.

speech.para: I was very concerned to hear in the minister's response that there are measures that we will find out about that will be taken in order to deal with the expenditure—and cuts that we will find out about. Unfortunately for the people in my electorate of Gellibrand, each decision made by this government on tax issues is a further blow to the area. Reform after reform means that the government keeps putting its hand out time after time, expecting low and middle income families in Australia to bear the burden for its bungled priorities and its determination to reform the tax system, even if it is actually at great cost to our community. I was also very concerned when I heard the Prime Minister, in question time today, categorically assuring the House that the compassion—to use the Prime Minister's words—of this government will continue with any further measures to be taken in welfare. I am absolutely at a loss as to what the Prime Minister could be referring to when he said `this government's compassion'.

When you put together the government's agenda in different portfolio areas, it paints a canvas of a pretty ugly picture. When you put together the workplace relations reforms, which drive down wages and make jobs less secure, then if you are able to hang on to a job, despite the workplace relations reform that this government is pushing for, the money that you do earn is going to be worth much less because the GST is going to hit low income families. Low income families are going to have more and more of their income eaten up just on basic needs. The GST is being applied to most of those. Not only will you pay more, but also your job will be insecure. You are also going to pay more if you can hang on to your job. In addition, the government is going to raid the surplus to pay for its huge GST bribe, which means that less money is going to be available for community services.

This combination obviously puts more and more pressure on families and it puts more and more people into the welfare dependent categories. We can be very disappointed, as a House, to know that the principal source of income of one in three families is from welfare. That is directly related to this government's agenda of constantly pushing people down. As I say, the workplace relations reforms will drive down wages and people's jobs will become more insecure. If they keep their jobs, they are going to earn less money. With a GST, that money is not going to go as far as it used to. As well, we are going to use some of the remaining surplus to compensate high income earners—those that least need it—for the GST. That is obviously going to affect our community services.

Add to all of this, as if that were not enough, the revelation that the government does not intend to meet its own parameters of revenue neutrality as part of the response to the Ralph review on business tax. This is a significant change and it threatens the expenditure that is needed for vital community services. Of course, we need to be aware of the significant costs of our troops in East Timor. That does not mean that we do not support them being there, but it is something that the government cannot run away from. We need to be concerned that it will not mean that services in our community are going to be cut. On top of all of these things, there are comments from the Treasurer that he is not going to use the surplus. He may be interested to find out on his return to the country that the minister for financial services has promised that the money to finance our troops in East Timor will come from the surplus. I am not sure that is an issue that he has talked to the Treasurer about.

So the great concern on this side of the House is: where is the money going to come from? It is not going to come from increasing tax avoidance measures, which should have been part of the government's response to the Ralph review; it is not going to come from their treatment of trusts; and it is not even going to come from some consideration of winding back the tax cuts that are extremely generous to high income earners as a result of the introduction of the GST package. My fear—and I think you can see it is well justified—is that the government intend to walk away from the people who need them most. The funding allocated to vital services will be further reduced and ordinary workers and their families will continue to carry the tax burden of this country, but they will get less and less to support them in return.

In my electorate there have already been significant cuts to vital services as a combination of cuts from the federal and state coalition governments. Our Medicare office in Footscray has closed and our Centrelink offices have had a large number of staff cut from them. With an unemployment rate of around 10 per cent—and a youth unemployment rate of about 28 per cent—we rely very heavily on these sorts of community services and cannot afford to countenance further cuts in this area.

In January 1999, there were difficulties in processing Centrelink claims and, as with a lot of other members in this House, Newstart claimants in my electorate waited up to nine working days to be able to get their payments. All of this is in the context of the government saying that they do not know where the extra money is going to come from for their business tax reform. They have not stuck to their promise of revenue neutrality.

We need to go back and look at what we had been saying for a long time in relation to the GST; that is, that low income families are going to be hit hardest by this measure. Most of the workers in my electorate and most of the workers in the country—about 80 per cent of PAYE taxpayers—earn less than $50,000. It is probably more than 80 per cent in my electorate, but that is a figure we can work from. The package that they will receive in compensation for the GST is all based on the prediction of an inflation rate of 1.9 per cent, but we know that even the Reserve Bank is talking about it being possibly as high as five per cent. The people in our community will be worse off immediately.

Let me just remind the House, if members have forgotten, of the differentials in this area. A single income family with two children aged between five and 13 that earns $25,000 a year will receive compensation to the level of $22.30 a week. But if the family earns $75,000 a year, the tax package is worth $79.15 a week, more than three times as much. It is just as bad if we use examples in the double income area, if there are more children, if the families are single income and if they are couples without children. Time and time again we see that the high income earners are going to receive the highest compensation.

PAYE taxpayers get hit in other ways as well. They do not have the scope that some of the more creative members of the community have who avoid paying their taxes by having corporate structures. They do not have the scope to invest capital to be taxed in a different way from the taxes that are charged on people who earn income through their own efforts or hard labour. To add insult to injury, as has already been mentioned by the Deputy Leader, the Treasurer will not bite the bullet on trusts or the implementation of anti-avoidance measures. The people in my electorate of Gellibrand, and I know in many other members' electorates, really are saying to the government and to the Treasurer, `We need you to take these issues seriously. We need to make sure that our vital services are going to continue to be funded. We need to make sure that the government is providing for those issues.'

I would like to look quickly at the example of two retiree constituents who came to visit me in my electorate office this month. Mr Spiteri and Mr Bottigliri were both Commonwealth public servants for over 20 years. Through the good and fairly generous—in terms of the rest of the community—Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, they receive between $16,000 and $17,000 per year in their retirement income. That income is clearly fixed. Their retirement income comes from their contributions made over many years of work and set aside for security in their retirement. Both men carefully planned the use of their money to provide for themselves and their families. They are also entitled to a small part-pension of about $3,000 to $4,000, bringing their income to about $20,000.

With the introduction of the GST, both men will be hit hard. Their income is fixed and, even if they do not increase their consumption, their expenditure will increase. They will receive only a paltry part of the compensation to pensioners because they have a part-pension, and they will receive negligible income tax cuts because of the level of their income. These men are just two examples of the ordinary Australians who are being left out by this government.

With the passing of the GST package and the government's avoidance of dealing with some serious expenditure issues in response to the Ralph review, they see the value of their hard-earned money diminished, and that leaves the rest of the community's dependence on services at risk. It is of great concern to us that the government does not even, in the response to this discussion of a matter of public importance, seem to take this issue seriously. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The subject of today's MPI, as I read it, is the uncertainty surrounding the government's ability to deliver its tax packages, particularly GST compensation. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition strayed very widely in his 15-minute ramble. He ranged from the 1.9 per cent inflationary effect of the GST to the cost of the East Timor incident, albeit that he quoted Access Economics in a very selective way.

speech.para: Implicit in the opposition's matter of public importance today are the fundamental questions: has the government got the financial capacity, the economic framework or the management skills to deliver on its programs? Let me dispel any doubts with a brief comparison of the last three years of the Keating government with the first four years of the Howard-Fischer-Anderson governments. In the last three years of the Keating government, we had successive budget deficits of $17.1 billion—

talk.start.para: —How much?

—Successive deficits of $17.1 billion, $13.2 billion and $10.3 billion—that is, over $40 billion. Let me ask the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the member for Gellibrand and the rest of the opposition this fundamental question: how would you have funded East Timor over the last three years of your government with a $40 billion deficit? Just tell me that.
—Bankcard.

—Just like everything else was funded, with Bankcard. By comparison, the first Costello budget halved the infamous $10.3 billion down to $5.6 billion. Then for the following three years we had budget surpluses of $1.3 billion for 1997-98, $2.9 billion for 1998-99 and an estimated $5.2 billion for 1999-2000. From that position, we are much better able to fund the East Timor incident and the rebuilding program that might be necessary in East Timor than from the position of being in deficit.

speech.para: On the basis of that alone, which of the two governments would be in a position to pay a compensation package to pensioners and low income earners? Clearly it would be the current government. It is an undeniable fact of economics that if you can run budget surpluses then you can pay modest economic compensation packages. Let us look at the management skills of the 13 years from 1983 to 1996. The national debt under Labor's management went up from $16.3 billion to $95.8 billion. That is an absolute outrage.

This year the Howard government has cut that down to $71.6 billion and next year, with surpluses and from the sale of the second tranche of Telstra, it should go down to about $51.1 billion. We will be better off in terms of interest payments on our debt to the extent of something around $5 billion. That is another thing. Not only are we running budget surpluses but we are reducing the debt and, in reducing the debt, we are also lowering the interest payments that the government has to fork out. Therefore we are doubly in a position to fund those emergencies that occur.

What a stupid, silly and inane argument that, because East Timor has come on the horizon, suddenly our whole economic fabric is in ruins. What a nonsensical sort of an argument. That could have happened under any government. That could have happened under a Labor government, it could have happened under a coalition government and it could have happened under a minority government. Any government at that time would have had to have taken measures to make sure that Australia was funded. The Prime Minister was perfectly open in question time today. He said it would be half a billion dollars if we got out in six months, or more if we had to go for 12 months. It would be more still if we had to commit the whole 4,500. No-one said anything different from that. But you are in a much better position to fund those sorts of things when you are running a surplus of $5 billion or better than if you are not in a position to run any surpluses at all.

I think what worries Labor about the GST is that deep down they know—and they knew even as early as 1985—that Australia needed a consumption tax. We needed something that was equitable but that had a growth factor in it. I could quote Keating, I could quote Hawke, I could quote Beazley and I could even quote Wayne Goss. An interesting quote comes from Bob Hawke in November 1984, when he said:

para.inline: Unless there is a source of income in the consumption area, then the mass of Australians—

speech.para: the ordinary taxpayers, the ones that the member for Gellibrand was talking about—

para.inline: are not going to be able to get the substantial cuts in personal direct taxes to which they are entitled.

speech.para: From 1984 to 1996—in 12 years—what did they do about it?

talk.start.para: —Nothing. They put them up.

—Nothing. Better still, they offer them l-a-w tax cuts. Nothing ever happened with it. It is lovely just to pick up the Sydney Morning Herald of that date. On 18 August, the day after their infamous 1993 budget, do you know what they were going to do? A bottle of wine was going to go up by a dollar and cigarettes were going up by 14c a packet. It was going to cost $180 more for the family car. There were extra charges for undergraduate degrees. They are always talking about education. It was going to be $42 for eye tests because they were removing that from Medicare and $2.60 for prescriptions. All of these charges that they criticise today had their genesis in that time.

speech.para: Worse than that, knowing that that wholesale sales tax was flawed, they put it up from 10 to 11 per cent, 20 to 21 per cent and 30 to 31 per cent in the first year. In the following year it went up from 11 to 12 per cent, 21 to 22 per cent and 30 to 32 per cent and, for good measure, they put the family car up from 15 to 22 per cent. It gets better. They added excise of 2c a litre over two years to leaded petrol. In fact, they were actually going to put it up by another 6c a litre but their own backbench went into revolt. I remember it. I sat over there and I can remember that, after the budget, there was not a smiling face. Normally when you bring down a good budget there are smiling faces. I was a new boy here, so I was looking for the reaction. It was glum. They had a caucus meeting the next morning and all of a sudden the 6c disappeared from the budget speech of the night before. But who did that 2c a litre hit most? It hit the guy with the old car—the battler, the one least able to pay it.

Let me come back to another thing. Having put the wholesale sales tax in that three-year term of parliament up from $9 billion to $13 billion, having put excise up 2c a litre, all the CPI increases, having put the HECS up and having taken a lot of benefits in health, what compensation package was offered to the battlers, the pensioners and the Mr Spiteris from Gellibrand? What was offered to them? Not a brass razoo—not one cent.

It is very instructive to compare that with our package. There is going to be no GST on health, no GST on education, no GST on domestic household rates, no GST on religion, no GST on charitable activities and no GST for businesses turning over up to $50,000. With the revised tax package of early June this year, it is also instructive to look at some of the prices. (Time expired)
