debateinfo.title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (MORE JOBS, BETTER PAY) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —This sideshow alley of a government, led in this debate on the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 by their chief spruiker, Mr Reith, the member for Flinders, has the temerity to name this bill `More Jobs, Better Pay'. As I indicated previously, this is pure doublespeak. This is about a government which is promising that, when they give you less, it is actually more. When they rip away all of the defences that used to be available to every Australian worker, that loss will give workers more. What is the aim of this? I said previously that this was to reduce the relationship between employers and their employees to the master-servant relationship that prevailed in the 19th century.

speech.para: The aim of this legislation is to reduce the conditions of Australian workers to a point where they are standing alone, unaided and effectively powerless against both the government and employers. It is creating an entirely unequal situation for the lone employee, and the atomisation of the work force and of the workers in their workplace. The intent of that is to deprive them of all of the reforms that have been made over the last hundred years in the industrial relations area so that they are in a position of not being able to defend themselves adequately and not having the protection of either their unions or the Industrial Relations Commission, which has done such sterling work in this area for so long. Its intent and aim is to leave every individual worker in Australia pinned and wriggling against the wall of this legislation so that they have no escape from the government's intent.

The amendment moved by the shadow minster, and there are a number of elements to it, goes to the critical elements that are lacking in this bill. He moved that we should condemn this government for introducing a bill which, inter alia, would do the following things: first, further entrench unfairness and bias in the existing industrial relations system. Does it do that? The answer is absolutely yes. Second, it would restrict the role of the Industrial Relations Commission and compromise its independence. That is utterly true. Third, it would further undermine the award system, as it has been in the past, as the dynamic framework for the protection and advancement of wages and conditions through the process of award stripping. Fourth, it would put Australia's lowest paid workers in a position where they would have to trade off a wage increase against having all their award entitlements that still exist stripped of basic entitlements such as long service leave, superannuation and paid jury leave. Inter alia also is the critical condition that this emphasises punishment and prevention of industrial action rather than its resolution. It flies completely in the face of past industrial practice and it is a recipe for further mayhem and for further punishment of Australian workers.
I finish on this positive note. The opposition recommends in its amendment:
(3) recommends that a new bill be introduced which:
(a) delivers fair and equitable outcomes for Australian workers;
(b) preserves basic conditions for all Australian workers;
(c) provides for an independent commission with the appropriate power to conciliate fairly and settle disputes; and
(d) provides jobs and income security.

I recommend this course of action to the House and, along with all of my colleagues, utterly condemn the bill presently before us which is a disgrace in the context of Australian industrial relations practice for almost a century.

talk.start.para: —I support the remarks just made by the member for Blaxland in stating his opposition to the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 . I rise to speak on the bill because it goes to the very heart of the industrial relations system of the country. It also goes to the very heart of fairness in this country—fairness not just in the management of relations between employers and employees but also fairness in the distribution of the national taxation burden and fairness in the allocation of national public resources to those who are in greatest need. In fact, what is on trial in this bill today in this parliament is fairness itself and whether this government, beyond rhetoric, gives any passing attention to the notion of fairness itself. Fairness is not simply some political construct of the Australian Labor Party; fairness goes to the very core of our national ethos as Australians. And it is that ethos which is under fundamental threat and challenge in the legislation before us.

speech.para: The government has its own view of fairness. When you strip it all away, its concept of fairness is this: it should be arbitrated and determined by markets alone. In this context, the only function of government is to ensure that those markets operate competitively. This is the core of the Liberal capitalism which this government stands for. It is neoclassical economics, it is Hayek, it is John Howard, it is Peter Reith and it is Peter Costello; but it is not us. We stand for something completely different.

Let us look briefly at the overarching government philosophy that lies at the heart of this legislation before the House. Let us look at it as it reflects itself through the clauses of the industrial relations bill before us. Let us also see how it has been reflected in the other tenets of government policy, in its consideration of both consumption tax and currently business tax. These legislative initiatives of the government are not a series of random events. They are linked by a common philosophy, and that common philosophy has as its core organising principle this very simple proposition: a redistribution of wealth and power in our economy and in our society away from the poor and towards the rich, away from the weak and towards the strong.

Those opposite have asked why we have opposed the consumption tax. It is very simple: because the consumption tax, the goods and services tax, is a redistribution of wealth tax which redistributes wealth away from poor people to rich people. It is a $32 billion redistribution tax. You ask why we have reservations about certain aspects of the business tax proposals currently before us as well. The reason for that is that once again there are certain elements of that package which give rise to concern on the part of a number of us in terms of yet a further redistribution of wealth away from the poor to the rich, away from the weak towards the strong. Not to mention, in the case of the business tax proposals, the ultimate impact which they will have on the overall integrity of the taxation base and the capacity of the nation at large, through the budget sector, to deliver social programs to those most in need. And today you ask us again in this place why we oppose this bill. The reason again is equally simple, and that is that what we have before us is a naked redistribution of power away from the weak and towards the strong.

One of the disturbing elements of all of this revolution in taxation and all of this revolution in industrial relations is the two personalities driving it, P1 and P2. Sitting on this side of the chamber, you get the distinct impression that what Mr Costello and Mr Reith are busy doing all the time is out- Ramboing each other in order to achieve the most dramatic headlines out there in the newspapers the following day. What we have on the other side of the chamber at the moment is an undeclared leadership dispute. What we have is Mr Costello, the Treasurer, already declaring his hand in the article published the other day in the Australian Financial Review under Peter Hartcher's name. What we have is an equally displeased Peter Reith concerned that his own leadership prospects might at some stage be threatened by Mr Costello's own ambition. What we have as a consequence of this is a process of almost permanent policy one-upmanship, a competition you can see on a daily basis here as they compete one against the other for who is going to get the most questions on what.

What is all this about at the end of the day? It is about who ends up being the top dog in the show represented by those opposite. But who are the casualties of this political competitive process, the casualties of this race of naked political ambition? Who are the victims of this process? They are those who at the end of the day suffer the consequences of this redistribution of wealth and power through the tax system and through the industrial relations system—the poor and the weak. They are the casualties of this leadership dispute which seems to be driving so much of the government's policy agenda as we speak.

When we go to this bill and we go to its title, the title itself sums everything up: More Jobs, Better Pay. It is as if we have taken leave of ourselves and this place and we have entered into the world of Lewis Carroll and Alice in Wonderland, the land where everything is in fact upside down. Or, more sinisterly, I think it is more likely to be the world of George Orwell and Nineteen Eighty-four. Remember that in George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-four the Ministry of Truth was the ministry which told the lies and the Ministry for Peace was the ministry which made war. What we have now is a government which says, `We are going to give you a piece of legislation which delivers more jobs and better pay.' For that, read `less jobs and less pay'. What we have now is a set of political protocols on the part of those opposite which simply has as its organising principle: tell them one thing, deliver the other; pretend something is one thing while in fact doing quite the reverse. When they say `fairness', in fact the enduring reality is unfairness.

When we go to the substantial provisions of the bill, we see that a large part of it goes to the emasculation of the powers of the trade union movement. What is it about those opposite that they have such an experience and such an attitude towards trade unions and trade unionists? Have you all had bad experiences in childhood somewhere with trade unions? I fail to grasp the level of animosity, anxiety and vitriol which we see pour forth from those opposite almost on a daily basis when one simply mentions the words `trade union', as if trade unions, in the history of our country and in the history of the broader civilisation of which we are part, have not played a positive role. Have you all forgotten the role of trade unions in the 19th century and the early 20th century in the basic conditions of safety in the mines and in the basic conditions in the workplaces? Those most elementary conditions of safety and entitlements, as far as the wages and the like that were guaranteed, were delivered through the trade union movement.

The challenge which those opposite have never answered in this debate or in their daily outpourings of vitriol against the trade union movement is this: has human nature changed? Do those opposite genuinely believe that, as a consequence of this legislation, mystically human nature will change and that employers in the future will be a permanently virtuous set of humanity, never once again in the future doing anything nasty or negative to any employee in any workplace across the country? Dickensian England lies in the 19th century. It could never recur. If you went to visit some of the sweatshops of suburban Melbourne, you would find it is alive and well in this country—not just in Melbourne but right across this country—and the only force that working people have working for them at the end of the day to defend their conditions against exploitative employers where they exist is an active and vibrant trade union movement.

I am proud of the Australian trade union movement, in its history and its current practice. I have never worked for a trade union in my life, but I recognise, through everything that I have experienced in work and in my dealings with friends and fellows, the impact which they have on underpinning basic conditions in our life and in our workplace. It strikes me as passing strange that we had in this place for months on end this vitriol and this diatribe, particularly by Mr Reith, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, as he sought to name, one by one, those on this side of the chamber who at some stage of their life had worked for a trade union, as if that were some crime against humanity. I would regard such employment as in fact being a badge of honour, given the role which trade unions have played in the life, the work and the social equity of this country.

There are also the substantive changes to the powers of trade unions themselves contained in this bill. Removed from trade unions is their ability to inspect records. Removed from trade unions is their ability to visit workplaces unmolested. They must now seek a written application from a member of a trade union in a particular workplace, forgetting that such a process is almost impossible given the fact that so many employees in industrial workplaces do not have English as their first language, let alone any passing familiarity with the industrial laws of this country. Then we have the sheer impracticality of going to the commission registrar in order to obtain a certificate to gain access to a workplace if such a letter of invitation cannot be obtained from a member of a trade union in the first place.

What we have in this bill is an attack on the powers of trade unions. We also have an attack on awards and what they contain. We see the continuation in effect of award stripping. We see changes in terms of what awards are capable of providing for casual workers. We see no longer any protection offered for workers who would normally have been in receipt of notice pay when a business folds. We see no protection for workers when companies go into insolvency. We see no protection for workers when there is a corporate restructure. We see no protection for workers when we have a transfer of business, as in fact once was the case.

Finally, we have through this bill the further emasculation of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. If there is anything that goes to the core of our national sense of fairness in this country, it is an independent umpire, be it in sport or any field of life but most particularly in the workplace where so much of our basic earning of income and most of our basic conditions are so much at stake. Strip away the power of the Industrial Relations Commission, remove from it the ability to perform the independent function that it has performed in years gone by, and what you are left with at the end of the day is employers pitted singly against employees. We have proposals here which say that there will now be fee-for-service arrangements for certain functions historically performed by the commission free of charge. We have in fact the privatisation of certain other functions of the commission: for example, in mediation.

We now have greater recourse to the courts. When individual workers are forced to go to the courts, how many of them can afford to pay the extraordinary fees which are levied on them when they go through the formal legal process? What we have under challenge in this bill is a total attack on the cost of industrial justice itself, placing it beyond the reach of individual workers. In conclusion, what we have in the bill is a fundamental assault on the Australian traditions and practices of fairness. We see that reflected in the bill's attack on the powers of unions. We see that in its attack on the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission and we see that in its further emasculation of awards. For these reasons, the bill in its present shape should be opposed and the amendment moved by the honourable member for Brisbane should be supported.

talk.start.para: —I fully endorse the comments made by the member for Griffith and the other members on this side of the House who have spoken today and who spoke yesterday on the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 . Before I begin my comments, I want to inform the House of my background in industrial relations—to declare my interests, as it were. I was a union organiser for the Miscellaneous Workers Union for some years. During that time I worked with members who did not have strong bargaining positions. They were cleaners and groundkeepers—people in those sorts of professions—who do not have the might that this government assumes. I worked with people who were desperate for their jobs and who relied heavily on the existence of a strong framework of industrial regulation, because without it they were and would be severely disadvantaged. I have seen the lengths to which some employers will go to avoid fair conditions. The framework is there primarily to stop them.

speech.para: I have found that it is only those who seek to undermine conditions who really wish to remove the safety net. I hasten to add that in my time I have also met employers who recognised the value of the system and always operated within it in a fair manner and who enjoyed productive relationships with workers and their unions. I wonder if they will be able to afford to operate at that level now. To do the right thing by employees may seriously put them out of the commercial market.

The bill before the House today is a vitally important one because it is about working lives. People's livelihood will depend on good policy. Where policy is driven purely by ideology and not the reality of average working life, then its proponents ill-serve working Australians. This minister is one such ideologically driven person who does not serve working people well. The bill before the House seeks to undermine the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, to attack workers through their unions, to significantly reduce workers' negotiating power and to strip away basic conditions whilst hiding behind a spurious claim of short-term gain. All of this is under the misleading title of `More Jobs, Better Pay.' What a horrible joke is being played upon the Australian people. Perhaps the minister thinks that by giving his bill an innocuous title people might not really see what is going on. The minister can call it what he wants, but he cannot change what it is. It is still a vicious attack on workers and has the foul stench of every other piece of legislation that this minister has touched.

Let me take a moment of the time allotted to me to put the minister into some kind of industrial relations context. In order to fully comprehend the intent of this bill, one must understand the intent and belief structure of this minister. I think his attitude to industrial relations was summed up in his infamous secret paper entitled Waterfront strategy which, as the title suggests, laid out the minister's secret plans for waterfront reform. This paper suggested a course of action to create a waterfront dispute. We all remember the cost of that action. It says:
In the meantime, we need to further develop plans to involve the MUA in a dispute, on an issue and at a time of our choosing.
It goes on:
. . . a stevedoring issue could be used to sack stevedores.
Further work will need to be undertaken on possible triggers, in the meantime, no action should be taken that will neutralise any such possible triggers.
In terms of timing it is important not to engage the MUA until both stevedoring firms are in a position to commence re-starting operations without the existing workforce.

The minister planned to create that dispute for his own ideological purpose, just as he plans now to destroy the workers' safety net. The minister even recognised that in the area of the maritime industry community support was against him. The paper says:
Our research suggests that the general public does not yet appreciate the need for major reform. . . . It is important that this be turned around before a major dispute.

Well, perhaps the minister should make sure that he works a little bit harder on that area of his plan because, as we all remember, community reaction was certainly against him. The community could see what he was up to and offered overwhelming support to the rights of people to keep their jobs. The 21 May edition of the Business Review Weekly labelled this minister as:
. . . possibly one of the most interventionist industrial relations ministers in Australian History.
This minister claims he wants a deregulated system—but only deregulated in the area of workers' rights. This bill does not seek to create a deregulated system; it seeks to establish an unfair one.

We view this legislation in a climate of much distress for working people. Insecurity about their futures and the futures of their families is on the increase. We know that government policy should be about providing the basis of stability, a framework for greater skills and an independent arbiter. We should be providing security. In particular, we need policies that will stimulate job growth and job security. If you ask workers—and I am sure the minister does not—and those people who want to be workers what the most important thing to them is, the resounding reply will be jobs and job security. This cannot be underplayed. But the bill addresses none of these vital objectives.

Let us look at some of the things it does seek to do. This bill seeks to move the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to the zone of irrelevancy. This government does not support the role of an independent umpire. This minister wants control of what the commission do, how they do it and, very importantly, who will do it. On 28 August the Daily Telegraph said:

A senior member of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has launched an attack on Government plans to limit terms of office. The Senior Deputy President, a member for 10 years, said limiting tenure to seven years would make it impossible for members to maintain independence.

We need an independent system. Workers and employers need to have equitable access to a forum whose decisions are not only fair but are recognised as being fair. That will not happen if that independence is questionable.

This government have shown, through their calculated attack on the MUA, that equity is not the driving force in their policies. Their plan is to lessen workers' rights. This bill is about stripping conditions from awards so that they contain only basic provisions. They want to remove provisions for superannuation, long service leave, training provisions, skill base classification and non-state gazetted public holidays. To anyone who has had experience in this field, this is foolish behaviour. It becomes even more ludicrous when you note that this bill seeks to restrict the commission's compulsory conciliation process. This option is linked to the plan to charge for mediation—a privatised process which could see workers hit with charges of $500.

This is an attack on a mechanism for dispute resolution. This government is intent on destroying the process of conciliation. This bill seeks to limit workers' conditions and their access to a fair and equitable dispute resolution process. It also seeks to remove the right to information and representation for workers. The intent is to remove unions from the process, as if unions and workers were separate entities. Must I remind the House that a union is a representation of the body of workers—of the collective group? This legislation seeks to restrict right of entry permits even further. You can see why the government would want to do that: work forces kept in the dark about their rights are an awful lot easier to manipulate and a lot easier to do over.

Why is the minister so afraid of union organisers going on site to provide information and to ensure that the legislative requirements are being met in the areas of wages and conditions and in particular occupational health and safety? Because that is what union organisers do. That is what their members want them to do. That is why they choose to join.

Employers do not seem to be getting any restrictions in this bill. They have unfettered access to lawyers, industrial relations consultants and the like. This government seeks to intervene in the relationship that exists between employers and unions. This legislation seeks to define what constitutes a closed shop. If over 60 per cent of the employees at a site are members of a union, then look out—because the minister has you in his sights. What a blatant attack on freedom of association.

Most workplaces have healthy relationships with their employees, and these healthy relationships have grown out of a solid link with the relevant trade union. These are workplaces which recognise that unions will ensure workers know what is going on and are having their views negotiated in a fair and regulated manner. This government seeks to put industrial remedies out of the reach of ordinary workers. The introduction of costs cuts out those people who need representation the most. It prices them out of the market. This government progresses further and further down the path to industrial desolation. It is not, and has never been, about resolution; conflict and division is far more its game.

I want to concentrate now on what these sorts of legislative conditions mean, and have meant, for Tasmania. I want to start by pointing out that the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business seems to believe that reducing wages creates employment. In Tasmania, we have some of the lowest wages in the country and very high unemployment. In Tasmania, we do not believe that the previous rounds of industrial relations reforms have assisted Tasmanian workers in pursuing higher levels of employment or living standards but have in fact let employers achieve greater flexibility of labour to the detriment of workers' security and incomes. This bill gives legislative credence to the ideological argument that unions are somehow separate or alien to the workplace, that unions are an outside interference. That workers need to draw on support from their unions is not paternalistic but realistic. We need to recognise the fundamentally unequal power relationship that exists. Employers have the power to hire or not. They can call upon resources to load the bargaining exercise, through the employment of consultants and lawyers. It is only through collective action that workers can go some way towards evening the balance.

Tasmania has experience with these sorts of fundamental changes to the legislative framework, under the Tasmanian state act's part 4A agreements. This legislation has led to reductions in security and conditions for many workers. The lessons learned have been amplified with the experience of the Workplace Relations Act. A 1996 Tasmanian House of Assembly inquiry into the state agreement system found that employers were in a strong bargaining position where there was not a union, because employees as a whole were unaware of their rights and were therefore unaware of the availability of assistance. It found that employees demonstrated little understanding of the details of their workplace agreements, despite allegedly agreeing to them. Employers typically had expert advice and employees typically had nothing except what the employer or consultant gave them.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would well recall the election results in Tasmania. They indicate that workers recognised the appalling outcomes of the industrial relations process and they said no. They said no because they had experienced the reality of the system. Experience has shown evidence of dodgy ballot papers, where workers were told to bring their signed ballot papers back the next day. It has shown evidence of agreements which were retrospective for up to three years to justify underaward payments. It has shown agreements with no wage increases for the life of the agreement—sometimes up to five years. We have seen an abolition of career paths and the scrapping of public holidays.

This sort of experience has been reinforced with the existence of AWAs in Tasmania. We have seen cases of employers who offer an AWA with the words, `Take this or leave.' That is a great choice for most people! One employer offered an AWA to a new employee, despite the fact that there was a collective agreement in place. AWAs will be altered under this proposal. The minister seeks to remove the cooling-off period and the option of collective bargaining. In December 1997 the ILO Expert Committee on the Application of Conventions and Recommendations investigated alleged breaches of the ILO's Right to Organise and Collective Bargaining Convention No. 98 by provisions of the federal Workplace Relations Act. I quote:

On the subject of AWA's they found that Part VI(D)(AWAs) promoted AWA's which are essentially individual in nature over collective bargaining. The Committee considered that primacy is clearly given to individuals over collective relations through the AWA procedure. The Committee considered that the provisions of the Act noted above do not promote Collective bargaining as required under Article 4 of the Convention (98).

Collective bargaining is the only way to maximise the bargaining potential for workers. But this government is not interested in supporting workers. It is not interested in negotiating rights because it is not interested in workers' conditions. One thing it is interested in, though, is masking the harsh reality of the true plans for workers. If you look at the bill, you could almost get the impression that it was benign because it uses such safe language. It talks about `choice'. But this is a fraud. It is a fraud perpetrated on working Australians because the language does not reflect reality. The provisions of this bill undermine collective action and improve the ground for employers. In fact, in the words of one advocate for workers' rights in Hobart, it is as `fair as a free kick in front of the goal before the other side is even on the field'.

There are a couple of options before us: either the minister has absolutely no knowledge of the everyday life of those workers who do not have strong bargaining positions or resources or he does know and he simply does not care. Perhaps workers of Australia are not as important as his business mates. The minister should learn that government is for all Australians, not just for a couple of the minister's friends.

I would like to continue to discuss the many disturbing aspects of this bill and the merits of the member for Brisbane's amendment, but I am conscious of the need to maximise the time for consideration in detail. However, in conclusion, I would like to reiterate my despair at the actions of this government—despair but, I must say, not surprise. After all, look at the minister who introduced this bill—the minister whom workers cannot trust, who actively seeks to dupe workers. After all, in his infamous waterfront strategy paper, whilst actively planning an attack on workers in the maritime industry, the minister highlighted the need to `keep the unions wondering whether the government would settle for an evolutionary approach'. This was while he was engaged in `intensive planning on how to manage a major dispute'. The government have introduced unfair legislation. They have introduced bad legislation. It is an ideologically driven attack on workers. It is made without any reference to, or understanding of, the sorts of lives that workers lead. It has been made by people who do not understand the issues that workers come up against.

There was a case in Tasmania recently where a new business was set up. They employed a young woman. They did not start off by paying her the right amount of money, but they said, `Don't worry. We're going to fix it up later on. Everything will be fine.' After four weeks of her pleading her case, the boss finally said, `Look, just take it out of the till.' Later that afternoon she was dismissed for theft. This woman and other people in these circumstances need to know that they have rights to representation, that they have access to conciliation and that they will be subject to an independently arbitrated decision. It is the only way to guarantee equity in the workplace. This bill makes a mockery of those simple requirements. Perhaps the bill should be retitled `What jobs? Lucky to get paid'.

talk.start.para: —My colleagues who have spoken before me have done a superbly detailed and thorough demolition job on the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 . For those who are interested in issues of industrial relations, workplace relations and the like, it really does pay to read through the second reading debate on this legislation and see just how comprehensively the arguments of the government have been demolished. So there is no need for me to repeat those, and I do not intend to. I also do not intend to provoke the government, which has been suggesting that it might gag this debate if it goes on for much longer.

speech.para: I want to summarise some of the issues that have been raised. This legislation has been referred to as Peter Reith's second wave. One of the features of a wave is that it ends up dumping somewhere. In the case of Peter Reith's second wave, it dumps on job security, family life, skills, the independent umpire and workers. Let me deal with each of those points in turn.

Firstly, the second wave dumps on job security. It weakens the transmission of business provisions, encouraging dodgy corporate restructures as a way of avoiding awards, whereas in the past an award automatically applied to new businesses upon transmission. Also, notice payments on terminations are to be taken out of awards at a time when workers are fighting to get paid the entitlements that they are owed under existing awards. The minister's provision will simply exacerbate this problem. I find it extraordinary that the government is prepared to weaken those transmission of business provisions and take notice payments on terminations out of awards at a time when there is a great deal of community awareness and an awareness in this place about the issue of workers losing their legitimate entitlements when companies go under, and when work is being done by the government and by the opposition on how we can secure superannuation, leave entitlements and the rest.

Secondly, the second wave dumps on family life. We see the protections for casual workers being eroded—the proportion of casuals, hours worked and rostering are all to be taken out of awards—at a time when the casual sector is growing. The removal of award provisions dealing with transfers will have a dramatically negative impact on trying to match work with family life. It will diminish workers' rights concerning transfer between locations and from one type of employment to another. With casualisation in Australia the second highest of OECD countries, the minister wants to remove the existing protection for casual and part-timers by taking out those provisions that provide the number or proportion of employees of a particular type or classification, provide the number or proportion of hours an employee may work and provide maximum or minimum hours of work for regular part-time employees.

I think one of the most serious issues in the Australian community today is the way in which people endeavour to balance work with family life. There has been a lot of comment about how people these days are working longer hours rather than shorter hours. We have seen the abolition of public holidays, not least in my own state of Victoria. In various ways, families are finding it tougher to bal ance work with family life. Instead of making it easier for them, these provisions will make it more difficult.

Thirdly, the second wave dumps on skills. It removes skill based classifications and training—so much for our desire to be the clever country or the knowledge nation. The minister claims that he wants to reward achievement, but he is removing from awards the only way for employees to be recognised for extra skill and responsibility.

Fourthly, the second wave dumps on the independent umpire. It shrinks the powers of the commission, which is not to be allowed to use fairness and decency as a test on setting standards. Access to the commission and courts is being restricted through the introduction of new policies of charging fees for applications. The legislation makes it harder for workers to prove their claims once they get to court, with records of hours, classifications, et cetera, gone. The detection of award breaches will become more difficult as examination of records by unions is being restricted.

The minister's department is in the process of abdicating its previous responsibility for inspection of workplaces, handling claims of underpayment and so on. We also see the appointment of commissioners for a short time only—constant downgrading of those who once had the status of High Court judges. In one case, we can have an acting commissioner being appointed for up to one year, so the government can see if it likes the commissioner's performance! It is scandalous. We also have the situation where the commission cannot effectively arbitrate during disputes. We saw during the MUA dispute that this caused massive problems. That dispute naturally ended up in the courts as a result. There was nowhere else for it to be resolved.

Fifthly, Peter Reith's second wave dumps on workers. The minister pretends he wants a deregulated system. That is a matter of pretence. He only wants the system deregulated for business. He wants to control workers. His legislation restricts the capacity of workers to bargain to ensure that they do not have a fair chance. Industrial relations is still to be regulated by the common law which is, in my view, designed for commercial matters rather than these sorts of matters. Strong negotiation is limited because the bargaining period can be easily suspended or terminated by the employer. Workers' rights of representation have been slashed through severe restrictions on union right of entry to talk with workers, inspect books and negotiate essential things of that character. Finally, the fair wear clothing industry code—a matter of interest in my electorate which still has a textile, clothing and footwear industry—that protects outworkers' wages and rights will be outlawed by this legislation.

In all these ways, the second wave dumps on workers. The second wave might not be a tsunami, but it is not what this country needs either. I urge the House to support the amendment moved by the member for Brisbane.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —There are a few matters that I would like to speak on with regard to the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 to counter some of the wild assertions and scaremongering that a succession of opposition members have indulged in. What we ask of the opposition in approaching this legislation is to debate it on a very factual basis without their pandering to their constituencies in the wildest language.

speech.para: Sadly, I feel that the opposition have not lived up to the normal requirements and, indeed, responsibilities of opposition. Instead, they have engaged in the worst kind of class warfare. They have deeply insulted him but they have not hurt, let alone bowed, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business with their insults. Instead, he has brought about a fundamental change to the way employers and employees can reach their own agreements on a sensible basis without the heavy hand of unwanted interference from either bureaucrats or trade unions. It is surely in the best of Australian traditions that people can freely and openly negotiate their own arrangements—always, of course, with the safety net of protection for workers.

The government is very proud of this legislation. We stand shoulder to shoulder with the minister, who has had to bear the brunt of personal as well as professional abuse. There is no question whatsoever that workers are the beneficiaries of this visionary legislation.

talk.start.para: —I thank honourable members who have spoken in the debate on the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 . This bill will deliver what we promised in our More Jobs, Better Pay policy in September 1998 for the subsequent 1998 election. It will amend the Workplace Relations Act to improve the quality of workplace relations in Australia and the outcomes for workers, employers and those seeking work. The bill provides for evolutionary change, building on the government's 1996 workplace relations reforms.

speech.para: The position that the opposition has adopted on this bill makes it very clear that it does not want to build on these reforms. It does not want to further the benefits of reforms that have helped strengthen Australia's economic performance with fewer strikes, the lowest since 1913; low inflation, the lowest in 30 years; higher productivity; and low interest rates. It does not want to build on the changes that have helped Australian families improve their living standards with more flexibility and more disposable income and that have protected the low paid with real wage increases. The opposition does not want to build on the reforms that have helped create more than 400,000 new jobs and have helped reduce unemployment to the lowest levels this decade.

It is one of the ironies of this debate that the Labor Party, whilst stridently opposing this bill, does so in the face of the clear benefits which have flowed to Australians regardless of their circumstances. We are particularly proud of the benefits that have flowed to low income workers, who under this government have seen lower interest rates—meaning, therefore, less financial pressure on them in respect of meeting their mortgage repayments—but also higher real wages. We have seen in the time that we have been in office, according to the ACTU's recent strategy document, real wage increases of nine per cent or thereabouts, compared with when Labor was in office for over 13 years, when real wages actually fell.

The opposition's position shows that they are out of touch with the needs of Australian workers and businesses. Stripped of the rhetoric, the opposition's objections to the bill amount to no more than the fact that they object to employers and employees taking responsibility for their own workplace relationships without the intervention of uninvited third parties. Not only is their policy direction wrong, but they are wrong about the content and effect of the bill. Their contribution to the debate has been a series of errors about the purpose and effect of the proposed amendments, and I welcome this opportunity to set the record straight.

In respect of the Australian Workplace Relations Commission, let me make some remarks. The opposition wrongly claims that the bill will undermine the independence of the Australian Workplace Relations Commission. The bill simply provides the capacity to make seven-year term appointments as an alternative to the existing tenure arrangements. These provisions will apply only to new appointees. Existing appointments will not be affected by the proposed changes. The concept of term appointments is, of course, not new. Term appointments are widely utilised in a range of Commonwealth and state tribunals and statutory offices.

The honourable member for Brisbane made the extraordinary claim that the bill imposes 12-month appointments. This is simply wrong, and it is irresponsible and unhelpful to the debate to make the claim.

talk.start.para: —It lets you appoint people on a 12-month contract.

—You are just plain wrong. You do not even understand the basic proposition in the bill. I do not mind you attacking us for what we are doing but, for heaven's sake, do not attack us for something that we have not even proposed.
—Be honest about what you are proposing.
—You should be intellectually honest enough to recognise that you have failed to understand a simple proposition. It is a simple proposition. These are seven-year term appointments.
—Say on the record that there is no 12-month contract.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, he can interject until he is blue in the face, but the fact of the matter is that he does not understand what we are proposing. This is typical, unfortunately, of a lot of the rhetoric we get from the Labor Party. The bill provides for the Governor-General to appoint acting commissioners, including for periods exceeding 12 months. By providing to this effect, the bill extends the same arrangements to appointments at the commissioner level as those already applicable to acting appointments as presidential members under the Workplace Relations Act. Have you got that? Do you finally understand it now? Not only is this later provision included in the current act, it was also in Labor's industrial relations act. So you do not even understand what we are doing, let alone understand what was actually in legislation which you yourself have supported in the past.

speech.para: Let me say something about award simplification. Once again, the opposition have embarked on an attack on award simplification and once again they have got it wrong. The honourable member for Brisbane claimed that the bill will stop people from receiving notice of termination of employment. Again, this is just plain wrong. The bill will provide for the removal of provisions about notice of termination from awards, but it will not mean that employees will not receive notice of termination.

The Workplace Relations Act provides directly for notice of termination, and the bill will simply eliminate the duplication of notice provisions. Similarly, removal of long service leave from awards will mean that long service leave will no longer be regulated by both awards and state legislation. The honourable member for Lalor claimed that the bill will take away skill based classification structures and the regulation of redundancy pay—wrong again. Awards will continue to be able to provide for classification structures, with criteria that include qualifications, skills or tasks. The intention of the amendment is to remove from awards detailed provisions relating to training and the like that are better dealt with at the workplace level.

Awards will continue to be able to provide for redundancy pay. The amendments will make clear that redundancy pay provisions must apply only in circumstances of genuine redundancy, not in situations where, for example, an employee resigns, as is currently the case in some awards. Awards will continue to be able to deal with wages and key conditions of employment. Contrary to the opposition's claims, award simplification is not about award stripping; it is about making awards less prescriptive and detailed, removing obsolete clauses, removing duplication of regulation, providing for more flexible arrangements, and making awards more user-friendly and easy to understand.

talk.start.para: —No-one believes that.
—What a foolish statement to make. Award simplification was proposed by the Labor Party in 1993 and 1994.
—But that is not what you are doing.

—You ought to read the statements of your own party when they were in favour of the concept of award simplification. You cannot even stand up for things which you supported when you were in government, which just demonstrates the paucity of intellectual understanding, let alone conviction to actually reform this system for the benefit of workers.

speech.para: The opposition have also attacked the proposal to speed up the award simplification process, providing that awards must be simplified in order to be varied for safety net adjustments. Of course, they have neglected to mention that this amendment is needed to avoid a repeat of the delaying tactics engaged in by unions during the first round of award simplification. For all their apparent concerns about safety net adjustments, the oppoisition have neglected to mention the track record of unions in applying for award variations to give effect to safety net decisions. As at December 1998, less than one-third of federal awards had been varied to provide for the 1997 and 1998 safety net adjustments. On the basis of this track record, it is hardly surprising that workers are leaving unions in droves. The fact is that you do not back up your rhetoric. You do not bother to understand what we are actually proposing. You simply take your faxes and phone calls from the ACTU head office and you get up here and sprout things when you do not even understand what is being proposed.

Let me make it clear that the proposed amendment linking safety net adjustments to award simplification is not intended to preclude award variations for next year's safety net adjustment. I will be moving an amendment to the bill to provide that the proposed provision will not come into effect until the end of a six-month transitional period. That matter came up in our discussions with some of the church groups. I understood their concern; I did not think it was entirely substantiated or justified, but it was fair enough for them to raise it. We take the attitude with this bill that we have put the bill out, we are prepared to sit down and talk to people, and if there is a better way of doing something or if we can allay concerns, then we are happy to talk about them.

talk.start.para: —You are a caring and sharing fellow.

—The fact is that we have talked not only to church groups; we have talked to women's groups and we also talked to the ACTU in the committee on industrial legislation. We do take a reasonable attitude, and I must say that it is in contrast to the negative, whingeing, whining tone that we have from the member for Brisbane, particularly having now read the amendments which they are proposing to move—but more of that later.

speech.para: In respect of freedom of association, the honourable member for Brisbane attacked the provisions of the bill that will prohibit clauses in agreements that encourage or support union membership, claiming that clauses that discourage union membership would not be prohibited. Again, this is simply wrong. Item 44 of schedule 14 of the bill makes it very clear that clauses that encourage or discourage union membership are equally unacceptable and are inconsistent with the principles of freedom of association enshrined in the act.

The opposition is also wrong about the operation of the proposed prohibition on closed shops. It is simply not the case that a workplace with union membership levels of 60 per cent or more will be investigated. That is simply quite wrong—and again, it is silly of you to say things which are not based on the facts or the particular proposal. A claim that a closed shop is being maintained can be pursued only where another breach of the freedom of association provisions relating to non-membership of an industrial association—or restrictive arrangements—has been established. Where such a breach has been established, it is entirely appropriate to examine whether the specific breach is part of a wider pattern of conduct designed to maintain a closed shop.

I must say that your bona fides on the question of freedom of association are completely shot to pieces when, in your amendments, you oppose every proposed measure to make changes to the freedom of association provisions. You are not prepared to even countenance measures which will provide proper protection for workers in the freedom of association provisions—which shows how hollow your interest is when it comes to actually protecting workers' rights.

In respect of agreements, the opposition has also made a number of extravagant and misleading claims about the proposed amendments to the AWA provisions. The amendments relate to the procedures for making and approving AWAs, and they are aimed at providing a simple and speedy means of formalising agreements entered into by employers and employees. The amendments do not change the substantive requirements for AWAs. Requirements relating to genuine consent, the information statement and explanation of the AWA remain in place, as does the no disadvantage test. Similarly, the substantive requirements for certified agreements remain in place, including the require ments that the employer explain the terms of the agreement to employees, valid majority approval and the no disadvantage test.

The honourable member for Jagajaga spoke at length about the recent Steggles dispute involving an employee who, for family reasons, objected to an earlier starting time. The honourable member failed to mention that this dispute arose in connection with an award provision, not an agreement provision. It serves to demonstrate the need for greater flexibility in awards and greater scope to enter into agreements that can be tailored to the needs of individual workers and their employers.

With respect to independent contractors, the opposition has attacked the proposed repeal of the contract review provisions. What the opposition has not said is that these provisions are rarely used and that there are comparable remedies available to contractors under the Trade Practices Act 1974 and state unfair trading legislation in respect of harsh or unconscionable contracts. Of course, behind that approach by the unions and the Labor Party is that they are totally opposed to small business. They are not interested in the importance of the small business sector. Given the fact that so many jobs are created by small business, it is easy for us to mount the charge that their opposition to small business is opposition to that sector of the economy that has created the most jobs in recent years.

This is a bill that provides for continuing reform of the workplace relations framework. It will take Australian businesses and workers forward by building on the reforms introduced by the government's 1996 legislation and ensuring that its benefits are delivered more widely. I should point out that the 1996 reforms were of course supported by the member for Dickson, who is now a frontbench member of the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: —And she's your mate, so cut it out.

—`She's my mate,' says the member for Banks. What that demonstrates is that, if we can get your people off to one side and actually talk about the merits of what we are doing, you will see that many of the things that we are doing are perfectly sensible, as the member for Dickson demonstrated because she supported them. The fact is that you are just opposing for the sake of opposing and because you have been told to do so by the trade union movement. Most of the speakers we have had from the Labor side have been former union hacks just doing the bidding of the unions and the people who run their preselections.
—How did you get into parliament?
—I got in by knocking off a Labor member.
—Order! Both the member for Banks and the minister might return to the subject.
—On my second time, I should say.
—That is right.

—The bill will ensure that the workplace relations legislative framework will be fair and balanced and appropriate to the needs of the modern Australian workplace. There are a few elements in the bill that require some finetuning. As I said, some issues have arisen in the course of consultations about the bill and the need for some technical amendments has also emerged. I will be tabling those amendments shortly.

speech.para: The bill will continue to give workers and employers at their workplace more choice and more opportunities to manage their relationships without forced interference from third parties. It will continue to devolve to the workplace the right to make decisions about whether to make agreements individually or as a group, to withdraw labour or not, to join or not join unions and how industrial disputes should be resolved. The bill will remove unnecessary complexity from the system so that workers and employers can have more direct control over the management of their relationships without the need to engage outside assistance. It will continue to provide safeguards in relation to the content of agreements and maintain a safety net of minimum wages and conditions to protect the low paid and the disadvantaged in the work force.

The fact is that this government's reforms to the workplace relations system in Australia have been of tremendous benefit to workers and employers alike. Australia's productivity performance has been the best it has been for many years.

talk.start.para: —On the waterfront.
—You mention the waterfront.
—Tell us about P&O.

—I am very happy to tell you that we set a waterfront benchmark for the Australian stevedoring industry, and the Patrick business in Melbourne now runs at 25 crane lifts an hour. In terms of the national average, obviously you have the Patrick organisation and P&O, and one is ahead of the other, but there we have already seen a lift-up. The figure that was announced today was the highest number ever recorded. What is your policy? Your policy is that you are in favour of nick-off time. You are in favour of people sitting at home watching TV and getting paid double time and a half. That is what you are in favour of.

speech.para: Right across the Australian economy productivity has improved. It has improved in such a way that we are now as an economy in a position where we are seeing higher living standards for everybody. One of the proudest boasts of this government is that the people who have been most advantaged by our reforms are people who are on low incomes. Since 1996, in the order of 400,000-plus jobs have been created. Not only have more people got jobs; they are getting better pay in the jobs that they have. That is something that we should all aspire to.

It was a great irony that when the unemployment rate hit seven per cent—the lowest it had been for 10 years, and one of the reasons we got to the lowest level for 10 years was our workplace relations reforms—the Labor Party was marching with the unions in Melbourne opposing further reform. This is against the interests of working people. The Labor Party's record for low income people was not only the highest level of unemployment since the Great Depression but also declining real wages. The former Treasurer used to boast about the fact that real wages had fallen when Labor was in office.

talk.start.para: —We gave them other conditions.

—You did not give them other conditions. Their real wages fell and they lost jobs in record numbers. Since we have been in, exactly the opposite has occurred, as the official figures reveal. These are evolutionary reforms. They are sensible reforms. They build on the sensible changes we made in 1996. I commend the bill to the House. We look forward to seeing its implementation.

speech.para: Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Bevis's amendment) stand part of the question.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move amendments Nos 1 to 64 as circulated in my name in the following order: group 1, amendment No. 1; group 2, amendments Nos 2 to 6, 15 to 29, 39 to 40; group 3, amendments Nos 11 to 14, 30 to 38 and 57 to 62; group 4, amendments Nos 63 and 64; and group 5, amendments Nos 7 to 10 and 41 to 56.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment No. 1:

speech.para: (1) Clause 1, page 1, lines (4-6) omit the clause, substitute:
This Act may be cited as the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment Act 1999 .

Before I deal specifically with that, it might suit the convenience of the House if I just explain that each of these groups deals with broad areas of policy in relation to industrial relations. Whilst it is clear the opposition does not support the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 at all and has just divided on the second reading, given the time constraints it is not proposed that we would divide on each of these groups that the House has just agreed to deal with. It would be my intention, though, to divide on the third group, which is an important issue. I indicate to the House and place on the record the Labor Party's opposition to the bill as a whole and that we divide on one only for the convenience of the chamber.

Amendment No. 1 deals with the title of this bill. It has been the subject of some comment in this parliament and elsewhere that we have a bill before us that the government has now titled for its short title `More Jobs, Better Pay'. There is actually not a person outside the politics of the Liberal Party who believes this bill is about more jobs, better pay. There is no-one working in Australia who regards that title as in any way reflecting the motivation and desire of this minister or this government to provide more jobs and better pay in pursuing this piece of legislation.

It is only this minister, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, that would introduce an industrial relations bill into the parliament and seek to place as its legal name `More Jobs, Better Pay'. That is fine as the title of a Liberal Party propaganda document, which they had for the election campaign. They can call their propaganda document More Jobs, Better Pay. They can call it whatever they like—it is part of their political spin doctoring at election time—and that is what they did. But to rock up to the parliament and actually include in the title that piece of political spin doctoring so the legal name of the bill is `More Jobs, Better Pay' is a total outrage, and it is one that we are not willing to let pass.

It reminds me of that famous skit in the first episode of Yes, Minister. All of us in this place from time to time have been known to watch and enjoy the Yes, Minister and Yes, Prime Minister series, and very often the series cuts close to the bone. In the very first episode there is an illuminating exchange where Sir Humphrey is sitting down with Sir Arnold—Sir Arnold being the permanent head of Prime Minister and Cabinet—and they are educating Bernard about the way in which government operates. Bernard had made this comment about a publication, the title of which was `Open Government' and Sir Humphrey said, `Always dispose of the difficult bit in the title; it does less harm than in the text.' Sir Arnold reinforced that for young Bernard by saying, `It's the law of inverse relevance. The less you intend to do about something, the more you have to keep talking about it.' That was the Yes, Minister skit verbatim.

Obviously this minister and this government watched it and subscribed to it. To put forward a piece of legislation that takes out of awards a whole set of conditions that are already theirs by right, to take those things out, to reduce the role of the umpire, to reduce the right to collective bargaining, to reduce the right to collective representation, to ramshackle the commission and reduce its independence—to do all of that—and then give it a title that says `More Jobs, Better Pay' is a good comic skit but is a tragedy when it is imposed on the people of Australia in the way this government is proposing to do it.

The one good thing that this bill title has done is provide a bit of mirth around the place. `More Jobs, Better Pay' has been referred to as the `mojo bill'; `This is the minister's mojo'; and `He is chasing his mojo'. But, unlike Austin Powers who chased his mojo to the 1960s, this minister is chasing his mojo back to 1904. To find the last time the parliament tried to nobble an industrial commission, you have to go back to 1904 to provide that opportunity. We have here a minister chasing his mojo back to 1904, titling his mojo bill the `More Jobs, Better Pay' bill, but I am afraid it is a title that should not be left uncommented on and one that we think should be changed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is an amendment to simply change the title of the bill which will change the act, and in that sense it will not have lasting implications. Quite frankly, it is not a matter of great consequence to working people in their terms and conditions. But, without wanting to delay the House on a matter which compared to all the other things is trivial, the reason we adopted this title was that in the last election we gave commitments to the Australian people about what we would do. This bill simply fulfils promises that we made, and we make no apology for it. To say that this is somehow an odd occurrence is also not true.

speech.para: Taking the tax package, for example, many of the bills have been described as `a new tax system'. That simply demonstrates the fact that these bills are consequent upon a policy which we took to the Australian people. It is hardly extraordinary and, quite frankly, it reflects on the Labor Party that they should make such a big deal of it. It is pathetic. I say no more, but it is typical, unfortunately, of the standard of debate we get from the Labor Party—when you consider all the things that are relevant to workers, such as whether or not you have a right to be a union member or not to be a union member and whether or not you can have a vote in deciding whether or not you should go on strike. If you are running a small business, it is important that you know whether or not, when you employ somebody, you will be able to deal with them on a fair basis, instead of getting a letter of demand from some local solicitor and being told by your own solicitor, `It is basically blackmail, but you might as well cough up.' I concede that those are important issues. However, even though this is our bill, I have to say that I do not think the issue we are considering is important at all. We do not accept the opposition's amendment. It is a silly amendment and it reflects the paucity of intellectual capacity on their side—and I am being generous.

talk.start.para: —I should read into the Hansard the actual title that we propose. We propose that the legislation should be cited as the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment Act 1999. That seems to me to be a fair and reasonable description. All Australians would understand that it is a fair presentation of what the government is seeking to do. I do not propose to speak for five minutes, but I do want to make a couple of quick comments in response to what the minister said and in relation to the opposition's amendments.

speech.para: This minister is too smart by half. This is the same minister being too smart by half too often. This is the same minister who stood in this parliament and told the parliament that he knew nothing of the Patrick fiasco that unfolded, and then introduced laws into this parliament 12 hours after the sacking.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is the opposition's amendment. The rules of the House require people, within some ambit, to stick to the matters. If they want to debate the waterfront and Labor support for all the rorts and nick-off time, we are happy to have a debate on those things. If they want to talk about how the waterfront figures are the best they have been for many years, fine. But this is not relevant.
—Order! The suggestion that the member for Brisbane is perhaps drifting away from the point of the amendment I think is well made and I ask him to return to his amendment.

—The point of my comments is to pick up on the views actually expressed by the minister. The title of the bill is both a matter of substance and a question of tactics. The minister, in his comments, saw fit to talk about the relevance of this and the question of tactics. I make the point, I think quite validly, in response that the minister has been too smart by half in adopting a tactic to label a bill so clearly contrary to its intention, in the same way that he has been too smart by half in the past, and as he was with the Patrick dispute. Whilst the minister might think this flippant, clearly his electors do not. At the last election the swing against the minister was double the state average. People out there do take some—
—Mr Deputy Speaker—
—Order! The honourable member is now well away from the point of the amendment.

—Just to finalise the matter, seeing as we are having two shots at this each, the shadow minister said that his objection to this was that it was contrary to our intention—namely, that the words `more jobs, better pay' were contrary to our intention. The fact of the matter is that the intention of this bill is to continue evolutionary reforms to produce more jobs and better pay. That is what we promised the Australian people that we would do. It was our policy. It is a pretty odd thing when you are criticised by the opposition for attempting to legislate your policy. People are cynical about Australian politics because on many occasions politicians have not done what they said they would do. Let us accept the criticism. What we are attempting to do is to meet that criticism by doing what we said we would do. Naturally enough, we do not think this is being too smart by half. The only reason the honourable member is surprised by this is that it is novel to have a government that is determined to do exactly what it said it would do. The fact is that our intention in this area is to have more jobs and better pay. We are entitled to say that because, since we have been in office, there are demonstrably many more jobs in the Australian economy—what, 500,000?
—The highest ever.

—We have the highest number of jobs ever. Furthermore, people are receiving more pay. There have been increases in real wages of around seven per cent for low income people. That is a good record, but it is proof of the pudding that we set out that as our objective and we are continuing to pursue that objective. In one sense this is a matter of trivia—I am quite happy to say that—but it is also important to us that we stick to what we said we would do. We reject out of hand the opposition's silly amendment.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.
