These amendments deal with questions that go to the protection that workers have in determining their wages and conditions, and specifically the provisions in the bill—and, I might say, in the 1996 legislation—that strip away their current entitlements. The minister in his summing up of the second reading debate made reference to the fact that what the government has been involved with is not award stripping; it has been simply trying to modernise awards. Let us look at what he means by that. As I commented in relation to the title, this is a minister who likes being too smart by half and presenting a view of what he intends to do that is very different from what is happening.

In relation to the bill before us, the simplification that the minister talks about is simplified to the point of taking these things out of awards. You are going to take skills based structures out of awards. Interestingly, the government is not proposing to take a non-skills based structure out of awards. So it is quite okay to maintain in an award a wages structure that does not recognise skill, but if you actually have a skills based structure, this government wants to remove that as a matter which the commission can insert into awards. At a time when we are endeavouring to educate and skill the community for the 21st century, why any government would want to impede that process is beyond any reasonable analysis—but that is exactly what this does.

It removes long service leave as an allowable matter. Is that simplification? You tell that to the workers who rely on their award for their conditions. Yes, there are statutory entitlements for long service leave. They exist around the country, but very often they are less generous than the provisions that are available in awards and agreements. The government want to remove the opportunity for workers to have long service leave.

They also propose—as part of what they call `simplification'—to take away rights in relation to compassionate leave. They are also proposing to take away redundancy pay as an issue that can be included in award matters. On the one hand, this government would have the public believe that they are concerned about workers, such as those at Oakdale who lost their jobs and were without income for some time. The government would profess to be concerned about people in that situation, but for people who are made redundant they are proposing in this bill to remove the right of workers to have redundancy clauses in their award. They are also removing the notice of termination provisions from the award and, unbelievably, they are removing paid jury service leave as well. This is not award simplification.

The minister stood here less than half an hour ago and told the House that the government were not involved in award stripping. He said that what they are doing is simplifying the award. It is not simplification of the award to take those things away. It is not simplification of the award to tell workers that they cannot take paid jury service leave, which raises some interesting questions about the sort of society we as a nation want to develop. The very independence of the courts has been predicated on the basis that, for a whole range of offences, you can be tried by 12 of your peers. Under this bill it will become 12 of your peers who are rich enough to turn up and spend the required couple of weeks on the jury, because the government is about to take paid jury service leave out of awards. That is not the first time it has taken a counterproductive stance.
Ms Gillard interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The interjection was `the removal of defence force leave', which occurred as a result of the 1996 legislation and which the government has refused to have debated when I have moved private members' bills on the matter. The defence forces themselves told you that they estimate there are more than 100 awards in which defence force leave applied. The defence forces said to this government, `Please, do not take that provision out of awards.' But for blind, ideological reasons, for mad, right-wing, antiworker reasons, the government actually decided to hamper the defence of the country by doing away with defence force leave. (Time expired)

—A lot of claims have been made which are simply not true. In respect of defence force leave, the fact is that, if you are an employee and you are required to perform your necessary service under the reserve system, your employment is protected by section 118A of the Defence Act.
—Come in spinner!
—It is. What you are proposing—
—Be careful, Peter.
—I am a lot more careful than you seem to be. We have looked at defence force service leave.
—So have we.
—You obviously have not, with some of the things you are saying. In all honesty, you are using East Timor as a basis for running the ACTU's line on award simplification. That is a fact.
—Talk about the issue.

—I am happy to talk about the issue. It would be good if someone on your side did for a change. We did have defence force leave and it did go out as an allowable matter—that is true. The coverage was no more than about five per cent. Of that five per cent, about half of it—and that is at the top end of the range—was public sector and in the Australian Public Service we have determinations covering it. So you are down to about 60 or 70 awards. To say that removal of allowable—
—What's happening with Telstra at the moment?

—Hang on. What you are saying is that this has undermined Australia's reserves. Quite frankly, that is a stupid thing to say. We are talking about 70 awards. Many of those awards are single enterprise awards. So to say that what happened in respect of 1996 had some impact, when people's basic rights to leave are protected anyway, is just a nonsense, and anybody who knows anything about this would appreciate that. There is a fair debate that you want to have about award simplification, but do not say that this is undermining Australia's efforts in East Timor, because that is simply not true. I am happy to have a debate about any of these things, but let us at least have the facts on the table.

speech.para: You talk about skills based classifications. I invite you to understand what I said in my summary, and that will put an end to the claim you have just made. You made a claim about notice of termination. Okay, it comes out of the award, but your basic rights are protected under the Workplace Relations Act. So do not give us this nonsense telling people that somehow they have been deprived of their basic rights. You made the same claims about redundancy. Again, I have answered that in full. You do not seem to have understood what I said, so I am not going to repeat it. It would be nice for a change if you could actually understand what we are saying. Then sure, come back with a response and tell me where I am wrong. That would be fair enough. I do not mind having a debate about these things, but do not go on as if there is no responsibility to at least argue the points, understand the facts and put up a different point of view.

With regard to long service leave, there is a difference of opinion. You are wrong to go around suggesting to people that they are going to be worse off or that they are going to be deprived of long service leave. The fact is there is a state system available for people and it does provide a safety net. All we are saying is that we do not need to have two safety nets which are contradictory. We should have one system, and that removes complexity in the system.

talk.start.para: —They have to go to the magistrate's court and the Federal Court to hear their claims.

—One thing at a time. In terms of long service leave, the advice that I have had is that, in many circumstances, it will actually provide people with a more generous safety net than they have now. If you want to contest that, fair enough, but you show me the facts and figures. That is my advice. Do not go around telling people they are not going to have long service leave when that is factually not true. By all means have your debate about award simplification, but do not tell people things which are factually not true.

speech.para: There were the same, quite frankly, silly remarks made about jury service. Yes, there is a debate about jury service. Our argument is that people already have protection under state law. That is the basic point. There are other points you can make, but do not deceive people about what we are actually proposing. I will make this the end of my five minutes, subject to any contrary points. What you are saying on award simplification is, for example, that we should keep the tally system. That is your position. The Industrial Relations Commission has just spent 12 months—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The problem on this side is not that we do not understand what this Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Busi ness says; like most Australians, we just do not believe it. Let me deal with a couple of the issues the minister has just dealt with. With regard to Defence Force leave, the minister refers to the provisions in the Defence Act in relation to this. If he bothered to do the investigation, he would know that there has never been a prosecution as a result of the provisions in that act. The Department of Defence do not want to use it to enforce the provisions because they do not think they can make it work. That is the reason.

speech.para: I can tell you that, with some personal experience of having sought to prosecute such a case where a person was in the reserves and was victimised in their employment, the very persistent, strong view expressed by the Defence Force was that they wanted us to jettison that reservist rather than access the clause to which you refer.

talk.start.para: —Why didn't you change the Defence Act?

—If you have a look at what the former Labor government proposed in relation to this, it was to do that as well. The problem that you have at the moment is that the great bulk of reservists actually do rely upon their employment conditions for their leave. There are about 152—or there used to be before your 1996 legislation—awards that had Defence Force leave in them. You have managed, as a result of your 1996 legislation, to strip all of those away and, to my knowledge, only one has been resurrected—I might say against the wishes of the employer.

speech.para: If you do not take our assessment of how that has been detrimental to defence, you might take the views of the defence department. Your government was advised in 1996, when you did this, as follows:

As reserve members constitute approximately 40 per cent of the ADF work force, their continued availability for training as currently provided for in awards, agreements and company personnel policies is essential to the Australian Defence Force capability. Existing awards have been important in providing institutional support for reserves through the inclusion of provisions which allow leave for military training purposes for members of the reserve.

That is the formal minute your government got from the defence department. You ignored it and, for ideological reasons, you overrode the defence department's requirements to strip all awards out of Defence Force leave.

You referred also to jury service and said, `Be honest about it,' which is an interesting comment coming from this minister. Being honest about anything, for this minister, is a bit of a challenge. He said that there were other provisions for jury service. Let us compare them. You have a base legislative entitlement that the state government provides where you are talking of people being paid $15, $20 or $30 a day for jury service or you have the award, which guarantees them full pay. That is the trade-off, and this minister would have us believe that, when we say he is going to abolish paid jury service leave, we are somehow gilding the lily. I can see all the workers out there saying, `I really think I would rather get paid $20 as the base rate that this state provides for me as a juror. I'll take that $20 and I don't want my paid leave. I don't want my normal day's pay. I'll give that up because Mr Reith says it's a good idea.' You go and find me some punters out there who want to follow you down that path, Minister.

The simple fact of life is that your process contained in this bill we are seeking to change here with these amendments is not about simplification and it is not about modernisation, both of which you know full well the former Labor government started and which this opposition supports and indeed the trade union movement supports. What this bill does and what your 1996 bill did was not to seek to modernise but rather to strip clauses out of awards. They seek to reduce the minimum benchmark. That is no surprise to any of us because in your confidential letter to the Prime Minister last year, when you set out your plan for three years, you actually complained to the Prime Minister that the basic wage adjustments that the Industrial Relations Commission had given were too generous. You proposed setting up an alternative tribunal made up of people that you could appoint who might come up with a different answer. Your agenda for reducing the minimum standards of Australian workers is plain. It is in black and white and in formal advice to the Prime Minister. This bill and these award stripping provisions are just another aspect of it.

talk.start.para: —No strident speech can disguise the embarrassment for the Labor Party caused by the fact that, since we have been in, people on low incomes and people generally who are at work have enjoyed higher wages. They have enjoyed higher wages in a time when interest rates have been down, so they have had more money in their pocket as a result of that. They have not lost those wages by high inflation as a result of deals done with the ACTU under the accord.

speech.para: When all is said and done, most people want to know: have I got a job? Am I getting fair pay for the work I am doing? The fact is that more people have jobs and more people have better pay. All of the nonsense that we hear from the shadow minister about award simplification also betrays the fact that, when the Labor Party were in office, they were in favour of award simplification. Their former esteemed leader, Mr Keating, publicly advocated award simplification—not exactly the same as us, that is true, but by and large he was in favour of award simplification. He said that it was a necessary part of modernising Australia's workplace relations system, and the reason he said that was that the consequence over time of a more flexible system is that people do end up with higher pay and we do create more jobs. We have demonstrated that, and it is ironic therefore that the Labor Party claim to be supporting the working person but oppose the very measures that would actually give them higher pay and more jobs in the future.

Let me give you an example: the Labor Party proposes in this matter that we have before us to retain the system of tallies in the meat processing industry. This is madness. The Labor government itself, back when Peter Cook was the minister, made a submission to the Industrial Relations Commission advocating the abolition of tallies.
Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It was your policy. This just demonstrates that you are not up to pace on this. You have a proposal here to do away with the allowable matters list—the whole list. In other words, tallies should be an available, allowable matter in the system that you are proposing. You would not have an allowable matters list; you would have a complete jurisdiction for the commission. You are unhappy with the commission in the tallies decision because you are opposing us removing tallies. If you are opposing us for removing tallies, it is fair enough for me to assume that you are in favour of tallies. Why would you want to keep them in unless you are in favour of keeping them? Isn't that your position?
—We might be in favour of letting the commission do its job.
—It has just done its job, and it said, `Tallies are going,' so why are you opposing the removal of tallies from the allowable matters list? Why?
—It's opposing the legislative removal.

—Oh, right! So this is a new world from the Labor Party: `We are not going to have tallies in practice, but because they are so important and the ACTU has told us we are going to have them in the allowable matters list.' So they are going to live on in Canberra in legislative form, while you acknowledge that in practice they are gone, finished and that the commission said they should go. Do you seriously think that is a tenable position? Doesn't it occur to the Labor opposition that it is slightly inconsistent to be saying that this is a matter for the commission but that, when the commission gets rid of tallies, you are in here today arguing for the retention of tallies? That is a nonsense position. It is completely untenable.

speech.para: Mr Zahra interjecting—
Ms Roxon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Here we have two new backbenchers. I know you are learning the ropes, but you have to think these things through for yourselves. You have to work it out for yourselves, and it is slightly inconsistent to be saying that it is a matter for the commission and, when the commission has said that tallies are going, to be up here arguing to retain them. This is from a party that wants to allow union picnic days to be imposed on people who are not members of unions—another matter which we do not think should be allowable but which you argue for. No better testimony is there of the way in which you just do what you are told by the union movement than for you to be supporting an anachronistic system of union picnic days and imposing them on people who are not members of unions. I will be fascinated to hear whether they have an answer to that. (Time expired)

—I will endeavour to make this my last contribution in this bracket of amendments to the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 . I say one thing only about the tally circumstance, and that is that the commission decision which the minister has sought to put an interpretation on in the course of this week is actually not a final decision. They have sought further submissions. The matters on which they have sought further submissions include a bonus structure. It will be interesting to see what the final determination of the commission is. When the final determination of the commission is available, we might find the minister less cocky than he was earlier this week in question time.

speech.para: There are two or three additional matters that I do need to address. One is the decision this government took, along with its insane propositions about jury service and defence leave, in its 1996 legislation, which we are seeking to amend here, to remove leave for people to donate blood. As with jury service, the operations of the Red Cross blood service are fundamental to the way in which our community functions, yet the government decided to make it harder for ordinary men and women to donate blood to the Red Cross. Not surprisingly, the Australian Red Cross blood service have been moved to make a submission to the Senate inquiry they are so concerned about what has occurred. In their submission they say that, since the removal of this provision from awards, blood collections have fallen in comparison to last year's figures by 2.4 per cent in New South Wales, 4.7 per cent in Queensland and 8.4 per cent in the ACT.

Two years ago this government decided to abolish leave for people to give blood, and as a result—surprise, surprise—fewer people are now giving blood. The Red Cross pinpoints that as one of the key contributing factors in the drop in the number of people who are now providing blood to the blood bank. What an absurd decision for any government to take. Why would you do it? You would do it only for the crassest of political reasons that only this minister and this government could devise. We seek in our amendments to restore some commonsense in that.

The other amendments here touch broadly on the question of how workers have their conditions protected. One of the themes that runs through this government's industrial relations legislation is its desire to reduce minimum conditions, to reduce the role of the umpire and to force workers onto individual contracts. I want to make an observation about individual contracts. There may be opportunity later to make a few more comments. In relation to individual contracts, I want to quote from some people who might surprise the government in this respect. There is a quite worthwhile publication simply titled Workplace Relations Act 1996. It was penned by Joe Catanzariti and Mark Baragwanath. These two gentlemen are well respected in the industrial relations field. Mr Catanzariti is a partner in the law firm Clayton Utz, not normally renowned for its support of left-wing causes. Mr Baragwanath was a solicitor there and he is now a lecturer in the field of industrial relations. In their book on the 1996 legislation, they talk about what happens when you have individual contracts and when you do not have the protection of collective bargaining. They say this:
In a situation where the agreement is with an individual employee, that employee has virtually no bargaining power.

The minister stood here and said that the government is on about allowing workers and employers to negotiate their conditions fairly without interruption. He knows, and everyone in the country knows, that what Catanzariti and Baragwanath say is the case. In fact, when this system was established and when the Harvester judgment came down in 1907, Justice Higgins actually commented that the contract entered into under those arrangements was the same as the contract between the sheep and the wolf—and we know who the wolf is. The simple fact of life is that, without the protection that the Industrial Relations Commission and the umpire afford, workers left by themselves to negotiate their own conditions are left in a very parlous state. These amendments we have moved we strongly support. They restore some decency to the rights of workers to have collective agreements. They restore some decency to the award system and allow the Industrial Relations Commission the independence to go about its work unhampered by this government. (Time expired)
Amendments negatived.

These amendments we will divide on. These amendments go to the heart of the industrial relations system. They deal with the question of the independence and the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. It is a fundamental difference between our side of the parliament and the government's view of industrial relations as to whether there should be an umpire. We now have the first government since 1904 that believes there should not be an independent umpire with the authority to determine disputes in industrial relations.

The 1996 legislation went a long way to undermining the industrial commission. This bill goes incredibly further. This bill goes to the heart of whether the commission has any independence at all. Whichever way the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business likes to cut the cake—and he made some comments when he was summing up in the second reading debate—this bill will allow the government to appoint commissioners for seven-year appointments on an appointment where, as a body that should be impartial and independent, it would become impossible for them to exercise that impartiality without looking over their shoulder. This is particularly the case given the form of this minister. This is the minister who has publicly attacked the commission when they have made decisions that he did not see eye to eye with. This is the minister who has also been willing to attack individual commissioners when they have inserted clauses he did not like, saying that the president of the commission needs to educate his commissioners better.

So one of the provisions here is that we are going to legislate to require all of the commissioners to undergo annual training. This will be Peter Reith's training school for industrial commissioners. The law will require every one of these people to undergo an annual training program. We do not legislate to require anyone else to undergo these annual training programs. We do not legislate to require the cabinet, the parliament, the courts, our generals in the military or our public servants to do so, but this group above all else we single out in legislation and they are going to undergo re-education camps every 12 months. Every 12 months they go off to boot camp and they learn what the government's instructions are. They are on a term appointment, and if they do not follow the instructions they are given at that annual boot camp then it is pretty clear what will happen: they will be booted out.

A seven-year appointment is totally contrary to the entire concept of an independent body. That is a view not just held by the Labor Party in this matter but which has been expressed by every single commentator. It has been expressed by employer groups, governments, unions, the judiciary and the legal fraternity. In fact, Senior Deputy President Polites, who I am sure is well known to the minister, has made comments critical of the provisions which seek to place commissioners on term appointments. He pointed out the impact that will have on the independence of the commission. So too have a range of eminent commentators. For example, Keith Hancock is a well-respected academic and practitioner in this field. He comes from the National Institute of Labour Studies in South Australia, much loved by many people on the conservative side of politics. In his submission to the Senate inquiry, he refers to the attacks on the industrial commission and says:
Another set of proposals which reduces the commission's role for no other apparent purpose is the restriction of its powers to conciliate.

So we have got the restriction on their appointment and we have got the restriction on what they can do. They will no longer have the power to conduct compulsory conciliation. In fact, if they do undertake voluntary conciliation, the act will require them to charge participants $500 for turning up. We used to actually have a system in this country where the umpire would sit down, mediate, concili ate and, if necessary, arbitrate. That was seen as a public good. That was seen as a desirable thing in settling disputes that arise from time to time between workers and management. This government is about politicising the appointments to the commission, reducing their tenure and then reducing their authority. That is precisely what this bill says and it is exactly what a litany of commentators have had to say about it.

talk.start.para: —It is not true.
—I do not know whether the minister bothers to read any of the submissions that are actually made—(Time expired)
—The shadow minister just said that we are reducing people's tenure. That is not true.
—Oh!

—It is not true—understand? You attack the 12-month provision, which is the same provision that you had when you were in office. Let us go to the tenure point because this is the heart of your concerns. What we are proposing is that people may be appointed for seven-year terms.
—But what are they currently appointed for?

—Yes, okay, but let me go on. We also retain the right for the government of the day to appoint people as they are appointed today. This does not mean everybody is going to be on seven-year terms. All the existing personnel retain their existing tenure, so there is no change to existing tenure. So for you to say we are going to reduce people's tenure is simply not true. You should withdraw it because it is not true.

speech.para: Secondly, we give the government of the day the capacity to appoint people for seven-year terms. This is, as I say, the heart of your objection. I find it hard to believe how you could be so excited by the proposition. We have people today who exercise federal jurisdiction who are on fixed terms. They are people who are dual appointees. They are state appointees who have dual appointments to the federal commission. Three of the states have had in recent times fixed tenure. Has anybody seriously suggested that there have been any decisions by any of these people with these limited tenure appointments which have somehow been subject to the accusation that they were not made independently? No, absolutely none.

talk.start.para: —But you don't appoint them.
—We do appoint them, because they are dual appointees. They are our appointments.

speech.para: Ms Roxon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The comments will come through the chair. I remind the member for Gellibrand that she is out of her seat, if she wishes to interject.

—The member for Gellibrand says we do not appoint them. I am sorry, we do appoint them. That is the fact of the matter. So we already have some people through the state system, and I do not think anybody would fairly make criticism of any of those appointments. They are all good appointments, and that is good—it is part of the harmonising of the system. But, furthermore, we have in various Commonwealth tribunals—where people exercise quasi-judicial powers—people with fixed term appointments. Again, are there allegations made against those people where they hold terms of seven years? No, there are not any. So why should you be making such allegations about this particular proposal? Lastly, how could the Labor Party possibly make this claim when they themselves appointed a president of the commission, Deidre O'Connor, for a fixed term?
—You know that was a special circumstance.
—Oh, a special arrangement! I see, right.
—But it was on a request.
—Oh, right!

speech.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Okay, I had not appreciated that there are special fixed term appointments that the Labor Party can make for five years.
—Not for every commissioner.
—No, not for everyone!

speech.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Right, not for every commissioner!
—Absolutely.
—Well, that is our proposal. Our proposal is that we can continue to appoint people—
—Appoint people to do what you like.

—Oh, I see, right, this would give us a power that we could use, but it was okay when you were in government because there were special circumstances. That is absolutely laughable. You had a five-year fixed term appointment and when I make that point you say, `Oh, no, special circumstances.' Certainly there were special circumstances in your view because it was a Labor Party in government and the Labor Party could be trusted to manage that issue. That was your view?
—No.

—Did we stand up and say, `This is an outrage because this person will not be independent'? No, we did not. Why didn't we? Because it is not unreasonable. Why are you opposing this? You are opposing it for the sake of opposition; you are just drumming up every argument you can think of.

speech.para: It was said that we have publicly attacked the commission. Compared with the attacks that the Labor Party mounted against the commission, we have been nothing but polite and respectful. You show me a quote where I have been anything other than respectful of the commission. I did not talk about a dog returning to its vomit, as Bill Kelty did. I did not talk in the way that Keating did about the commission when you got decisions that you did not like. Sure, when there are decisions we do not like, we have a mandated right through the parliament to take appeal processes. We have done so, and that is perfectly reasonable, but to say that we have somehow publicly attacked the commission is laughable when we think of the record of the Labor Party in office. There are a few other things but we will see what your response is.

talk.start.para: —It is plainly a matter of record that this minister and this government have in fact attacked the commission on a number of occasions.
—Give me a quote. Give me just one quote.
—I will give you one quote.
—Give me just one quote.
—I do not have the document here, but I am sure you will remember it.
—Don't dream it up.
—I am sure neither of you will dream it up, nor will the Speaker in the chair. Please come through the chair.

—I am sure the minister will remember—I think it was last November—when Deputy President Munro agreed to a certified agreement which included provision for an encouragement clause for union membership. That incurred your public wrath and condemnation and your admonition to tell the president that he should train his commissioners better. There is one example that might come to mind.

speech.para: The minister seems to want to twist both history and facts to suit his own purposes. Let me not enter that political debate but use the submissions made by others—respected commentators—on this very issue. Again I refer to the submission made by Keith Hancock on this bill which is about to go before the Senate inquiry. It said:

Taken together, these attributes of the bill represent a reduction of the role of institutions in the labour market and an enhancement of the capacity of employers to determine wages and conditions of employees. To a greater extent than for many decades, present and potential employees will depend on market forces to protect them against the exercise of employer power.

In other words, workers will be without any real protection from this government or, because of this legislation, will be unable to avail themselves as easily of other protections. They will be without that opportunity to an extent not seen for decades. Coupled with the other provisions, that means that the minimum standard is reduced, because we have seen the award stripping provisions take away what is the minimum standard—the award—and we have then seen workers left with less opportunity to negotiate collectively and exposed increasingly to individual contracts in which their bargaining power is next to nil.
I have already referred to Catanzariti and Baragwanath in an earlier contribution in this debate. On that point, Professor Keith Hancock referred to a British Labour lawyer, who said:
The relation between an employer and an isolated employee or worker is typically a relation between a bearer of power and one who is not a bearer of power.

Every worker understands that predominantly to be the case. People can cite the exceptions to the rule in certain industries and skill groups but, overwhelmingly, that is the arrangement individuals face if they are left to negotiate their own conditions. There are plenty of examples of where that has happened.

The simple fact is that, by stripping away the authority of the industrial commission, as this bill does, it denies workers a meaningful recourse to advance their conditions. Worse than that, because of the other changes, it denies them the opportunity to protect their current conditions. Unbelievably, this government will take away their conditions and their awards will be stripped before they can get a wage increase. The commission will have no option but to do that, because the bill ties the government's hands. Clearly, we could engage in a very lengthy debate on this matter, but I am conscious of the time and hope that I will not need to speak further on those particular amendments.

talk.start.para: —One of the amendments to the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 moved by the opposition spokesman is the total removal of schedule 12, which deals with the secret ballot for protected action. He has not yet spoken on that particular part and he just said that he does not want to waste too much more time of the parliament. I would have thought that this would have been an exceptionally import ant amendment. I will read schedule 12.1 on page 142 of the explanatory memorandum so the parliament fully understands what it is the opposition wishes to remove from this bill. The explanatory memorandum reads:

speech.para: This Schedule proposes to introduce new preconditions for the taking or organising of protected industrial action by employees and organisations of employees. In order to be protected action under the provisions of the Act, it is proposed that industrial action must be preceded by a secret ballot process overseen by the Australian Workplace Relations Commission.

The new provisions are intended to ensure that protected industrial action is not used as a substitute for genuine discussions during a bargaining period, and to ensure that the final decision to take industrial action is made by the employees directly concerned.

How can anyone possibly take issue with that? I was recently in Ireland and spoke to the Irish union bosses over there. When I brought to their attention that we were having a battle back in this country about industrial issues, and in particular the taking of industrial action with or without a secret ballot, they were dumbfounded to find that we are still having such battles. They take it for granted that it is every worker's right to keep their own position clear. They do not have to endure the indignation of standing up—or sitting down, as the case may be—in front of their colleagues and declaring a different position from that of their union bosses. This is about people's rights. This is about the individual—whether they be unionists or not—being able to say what they want to do, clear in their own conscience that they do not have to incur the wrath of their workmates for wanting or not wanting to take that industrial action.

A simple secret ballot goes to the fundamental freedoms of Australia—freedom of association and freedom to make your own decisions. This opposition seeks to remove this. It does not seek to replace it, water it down, change it or in some way omit one or two lines, but to remove the entire schedule. One must ask why.

Recently down in Melbourne I represented the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business at a function. A bunch of unionists arrived at this place to protest. They did not go there under their own free choice; they were forced to go there from their workplace as their employer was told which quota of his work force must attend this rally. I have no issues with unions or individuals taking any form of industrial action if it is their choice, but when they are forced to turn up to rallies, and when they are forced against their will to make choices such as going on strike—taking the sort of action which impinges upon their ability to fend for their family because they lose wages—I believe that we as a government have a responsibility to ensure that secret ballots are put in place so that they can protect the decision that they make.

I am sure we would all scream blue murder if we decided to remove secret ballots from any other walk of life—from state elections, federal elections or any other election—but to those opposite it seems quite right and proper that a show of hands in a workplace, with the intimidation that is quite obviously in place, is quite okay. I would dearly love to hear the opposition spokesman's answer to this and why he sees fit to take away the basic freedoms that unionists and non-unionists enjoy in this country—to keep to themselves their decisions as to why or why not they would want to take industrial action.

talk.start.para: —I am indebted to the member for Longman for raising the issue. The present act includes provisions for strike ballots to be ordered by the commission. As a person who spent 13 years as a union official, I have conducted many secret ballots for industrial action and for a whole range of other things. The provisions that are proposed here are not about democratising the workplace; they are about putting in place impediments that guarantee that workers will not be in a position to take industrial action. The bill provides a mechanism that I do not have a problem with. The commission is able to deal with applications and order ballots where it sees the need to. Any individual is able to go to the commission and seek such an order.

speech.para: The simple fact is that if you want to be even-handed about this, why don't you pro pose that employers are required to conduct a secret ballot of shareholders using the same restrictive procedures that you seek to impose on unions? Why don't you require employers to do that before they take industrial action? You are not; and the reason you are not is that you know it is unworkable. The reason you are not is that you know that the bill puts in place a series of impediments that are designed to prevent people from taking the action, not to introduce some sort of industrial democracy.

But, in terms of what the big issue is, anyone who has actually been in a union and been an officer in a union knows full well that the common practice in the overwhelming number of unions is in fact for those ballots to happen. If there were a problem—
Mr Reith interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It depends how you want to write the rules, Peter: you want to write the rules in such a way that they do become impossible. If you had a problem, one would have thought that it would show up in the requests for compulsory ballots. In fact, if you look at the record, in 1995-96 there was one request; in 1996-97 there were two; in 1997-98 there were six requests; and in 1998-99 there was one request. The simple fact is that this is not, in the real practical application of what goes on in industrial relations, an issue.

speech.para: My assessment—and, I might say, the assessment of many others—that these amendments are not about democratising the workplace but about denying workers any real opportunity to take industrial action, is borne out by some of the commentary that has been placed before the Senate inquiry. I refer in particular to the evidence of Professor McCallum, who is one of the most respected industrial relations academics and practitioners in the country—and is, I might say, internationally recognised. For the past 16 years he has been a member of the international panel, the National Academy of Arbiters, which is the foremost body on labour arbitration in the United States and Canada. He is a recognised world authority. This is what he said about these amendments:

For example, if enacted into law, these regimes would make it virtually impossible for a union to take meaningful and effective protected industrial action to press its demands at the bargaining table.

They are the views of one of the most respected industrial relations figures in the international community. The simple fact is that this person has said—as every other fair commentator has also identified—that the bill is, in relation to strike ballots, not about regulating them but about preventing them. Therefore we do oppose it, and that is what the amendment does.

talk.start.para: —This proposal from the government and Labor's now proposed amendment have finally flushed them out on this issue. You see, if they were fair dinkum, they would be putting up amendments to our proposal to make it work. Their whole argument is, `Oh no, we are not opposed to the in-principle concept of secret ballots; it is just that we don't have a workable system.'
—The law currently provides for them.

—And then there is this other little bit of deception, that the current law provides for them. Well, it does not provide for them as mandatory steps prior to the taking of industrial action. That is the point, and you know it; and you should stop deceiving people. I was very interested when I read their amendments. The fact is that they are not being fair dinkum. They are totally opposed to having secret ballots. And why? Because right across the front bench of the Labor Party you have got a whole lot of ex-trade union officials whose last idea is to ever ask the workers what their view of the world is. The shadow minister—like the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who was a former ACTU president, and like the member for Batman, a former ACTU president—is a former teachers union official.

speech.para: To show you how confused he is, he says that in his years as a union official they conducted many ballots. In other words, it is possible to conduct ballots; but of course in the next breath they say, `It is impossible to conduct a ballot; therefore we are going to oppose this proposal.'
Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is your position.
—Don't verbal me.
—I am not trying to verbal you.
—Order! I am sure the comments from both sides of the House will come through the chair.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I appeal to your sense of fair play and judgment. Is it not fair to reach the conclusion that the Labor Party are totally opposed to secret ballots when, in their amendments, they make no changes to the detail of our proposal? That is all I am saying. That is verballing, is it? Is this such a difficult thing for you? Is it really? You see, you are opposed to secret ballots. If you were in favour of secret ballots, you would put up some propositions to make them workable. That would be your position. You quote Ron McCallum to me. Let me quote the leader of the trade unions in the UK. I went to see him.
—A week after I did.

—That is right. We paid for your trip. I went to see him—he is Bill Kelty's counterpart. And I said to him, `We are thinking of having secret ballots in Australia. I notice that you have got secret ballots in the UK.' And he said, `Yes, we have.'

speech.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The answer to that is: the details of the provisions in the UK are not the basis of an amendment from you. That is the point.

speech.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Who is trying to verbal whom? I am in favour of secret ballots. My point is that you are philosophically opposed to them, and the reason you are opposed to them is that former trade union officials like you never want the rank and file to have a say. That is the reality of it. I said to the trade union boss in the UK: `Blair has come in, Thatcher introduced them, are you going to keep secret ballots?' And do you know what he said to me? He said, `It is very hard to take a democratic right away from somebody once they have got it.' That really sums up this whole debate.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order!

—Madam Deputy Speaker, let me again appeal to your sense of fair play. When it comes to providing people with basic democratic rights, on this issue the government is delivering and the Labor Party is opposing. That is all there is to it.

speech.para: You want to talk about the details of the provisions. I do not mind talking about the details of the provisions. I went to some lengths to understand how the UK system works, and I will make you an offer now: if you are fair dinkum about it, I would be happy to talk to you about the details.

talk.start.para: —It is your bill, Sport!
—I have certainly made—

speech.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —As usual, the Labor Party—
—Order! I call both sides of the House to order. I have called the minister. If others wish to take part in the debate, they may seek the call. The minister has the call.

—You must be very disappointed, Madam Deputy Speaker, that the Labor Party has just dealt itself out of this issue, as it did with tax reform and a whole lot of other issues over the years. Secret ballots are an important basic principle. We are for them and the Labor Party is against them.

speech.para: Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Bevis's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —In regard to opposition amendments Nos 63 and 64, the opposition opposes schedules 13 and 14. These amendments deal broadly with questions of freedom of association and the right to organise. I do not propose to speak at length about these matters, but there are some important points that need to be made.

speech.para: One of the provisions involved here deals with the right of entry of union officials to workplaces and what they are able to do when they enter workplaces. It has long been a fundamental tenet of the operation of our industrial relations system that authorised union officials are able to enter workplaces, and the customary arrangements that we have had in both state and federal jurisdictions for the great part of this century have authorised those union officials to inspect time and wages books and other conditions to ensure that the law is being applied; that is, that the correct award or certified agreement rates and other occupational health and safety issues are being properly addressed.

That system has actually been the mainstay that has guaranteed workers some certainty. As everyone in this place would appreciate, it is one thing to acquire an award or an agreement but it is another thing to enforce it. The enforceability of that has largely rested on the union officials—the workers' representatives, elected by them to ensure that those conditions are met. Industrial inspectorates have historically been very small in number and capable of undertaking that work. More recently, they have been stripped back to nothing. In the case of the Commonwealth, there is now virtually no industrial inspectorate and no-one doing the work.

I think it is instructive to have a look at the way in which some employers deal with this question. They seem to want to go out of their way to prevent union officials having any access at all to employees. I note in the submissions to the Senate, a submission from the Australian Services Union that included correspondence from the Northern Territory News. The union organiser there had actually written to the proprietors seeking permission to come to the premises and to meet with employees. The company wrote back to the union on 22 April this year—so it is quite recent—and, in part, the secretary of the company said:

I am not aware of any staff member seeking to participate in discussions with you concerning the pending negotiations or any other subject matter. If that is not the case, please advise me with the names of employees who have made such a request and we will promptly attend to your request to meet with them at our premises.

What we now find in the operation of businesses is that companies deliberately seek to prevent union officials from entering the premises. They certainly seek to stop them looking at time and wages books and they certainly seek to stop them talking to individual workers.

I do not think we have to guess what editorial line the Northern Territory News might run when dealing with this bill, given the practices they follow in relation to their own employees. When you restrict the opportunity for union officials to enter premises to check conditions of employment and to talk to people, you not only raise fundamental questions of freedom of association but also place at a disadvantage those decent employers who are trying to do the right thing by paying correct wages. You also make it harder for union officials to deal with employers who cut corners and who prevent union officials from checking to see whether the corners have in fact been cut.

The situation in respect of right of entry is actually one of the fundamental questions for the operation of trade unions. The proposals in this bill are designed to further restrict unions from being able to visit workplaces to meet with employees. The provision that requires unions to identify the people who have asked them to attend and then pretend that that is somehow protected by saying that that information can then be sent to the registrar rather than the company does not provide the level of protection that has traditionally been available. If you couple that with the efforts this government is making on unfair dismissals and the general tenor with which they have approached industrial relations, you leave individual workers naked to attacks from employers who are quite happy to victimise them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —As per schedule 12, this is another issue which goes to the rights and freedoms of individuals. What the opposition spokesman is actually saying is that even if there is only one union member on a work force, then the union should have unfettered right of entry to come in and ensure that the employer is meeting their obligation and be able to examine not only the books of that particular individual—which he or she should be able to do; there is no problem with that—but also all of the books on wages and entitlements, and in doing so tie up the time of the employer for people who are not even represented by the unions.

speech.para: Let us get this into perspective: 21.4 per cent of the population is now currently in the private sector and has union membership, so that is approximately one in five members of the work force. Out of a work force, for example, of maybe 50 employees, two or three may elect to be members of a union. We in the government respect their right and, in fact, encourage people to make that decision, knowing full well that checks and balances are in place. But, that decision having been made, the unions then feel that it is their right to be able to come in and impinge on the employers' valuable time and look at what they have been paying to each and every one of the employees, regardless of whether they have taken up the opportunity to be members of a union.

They remove from much of this legislation the role of the Employment Advocate. The opposition spokesman said earlier that, if you remove the rights of the union to have unfettered right of entry into businesses, then you remove the only opportunity that employees have to have their rights protected. The fact is the Employment Advocate is there to advocate on behalf of the employees.
Ms Roxon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —This is not some sort of a police force against unions. This is some form of—
—That is exactly what it is.

—That is so typical of the opposition's attitude towards these matters. They do not want an independent umpire, if you like, to be able to come in to look at the books of employees who are both union members and non-union members, and more importantly—

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —what the Employment Advocate will not do is come into someone's workplace and start canvassing for cheques to go to a union. The point is that it is a free service which is available to employees, so with any qualm or concern whatsoever they have that they are not receiving their due pay and conditions they can ask the Employment Advocate to come in and look on their behalf. That applies to both union and non-union members. What the opposition is seeking to do by removing schedule 13—entry and inspection of premises by organisations—as it was with the secret ballots, is to remove the fundamental rights of individuals.

speech.para: If four out of every five workers, or 80 out of every 100 workers, in Australia's private sector elect not to be part of a union, why should they and their employers have the imposition of the opposition's representatives—since every member of the opposition is in fact a member of a union—coming in, taking up their time and incurring the expense? Why should they run their fingers over the books and then talk to each one of these employees simply to be able to extract money from their pay packets to prop up the unions?

I have no problem whatsoever with unions representing their members to the full. They should and, in fact, it is their obligation to ensure that their members are looked after and that their pay and conditions are met. But when the opposition suggests that the union should have unfettered right of entry, re gardless of whether it meets the interests of the workers, it is simply denying those workers and the employer their rights. The opposition stands condemned for both schedules 12 and 13. It cannot justify these in any shape or form. It will stand here and go on with a whole lot of rhetoric but, at the end of the day, it seeks to be able to build up membership of unions regardless of what they are going to provide. It takes away from the opposition the responsibility to provide a real service to union membership so that they will stick with the unions in the future. Do not talk about 1907; talk about 1999 and the role the opposition's unions play. Why is the opposition becoming an irrelevance? It is because it seeks to remove measures like this from bills such as this one before the parliament at the moment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Our next bracket of amendments deals specifically with the Office of the Employment Advocate, so I will leave the bulk of my comments in relation to that until then. I think the member for Longman honestly believes the things he just said, which indicates that he has swallowed the line. I hope when we talk about the OEA, he might have a better understanding of what the OEA actually does.

speech.para: The question as to why a union official should be able to check the time and wages book of someone who is not in the union is an interesting one. What is the purpose of a union official checking those time and wages books, safety procedures or any of those other matters? The principal purpose is to ensure the law is being adhered to. Why is it that the parliament would want to prevent the enforcement of laws or arrangements made in accordance with its laws? Why would any government want to put in place a system that facilitates, encourages and hides employers who wantonly or inadvertently break the law? That is precisely the mechanism we are now putting in place. In fact, to a large extent, it is already in place.

Once upon a time, as I said, there were industrial inspectors who used to do this sort of work. There were never enough of them; they were never able to do the job properly. If you spoke to an industrial inspector, they would tell you that they relied on unions to ensure that awards, conditions, safety procedures and the like were being adhered to. That is what the industrial inspectorate used to say, but the industrial inspectorates have now gone. The Office of the Employment Advocate is not an industrial inspectorate, and I will say more about that when we get to it.

The point is not whether people are in a union per se. The point is whether, as a legislature, we put in place a system that ensures for all Australians—whether or not they are in a union—a better chance of having their legal entitlements met. Say an employer has 10 workers and five of them are in a union and five of them are not. The union official goes in and checks the five who are in the union—provided that the procedures have been followed—but they are not to check the other five. Why would an employer not want to disclose the other five? If the employer is actually paying the legal rates of pay, why would they want to hide that? The truth is—and practice bears this out; if you talk to people on the ground they will tell you time and time again—that employers will not make that sort of information available because they know they are breaking the law and they do not want to be exposed.

But there is another side to this: it is the side of the decent employers who are doing the right thing. The National Electrical and Communications Association, an employer body, in a submission to the Senate inquiry, commented specifically on this right of entry issue:

The proposed amendments make it increasingly difficult for union officials to enter the workplace for the inspection of pay records, and these people have been the only enforcers since workplace inspectors have gone.
The submission went on:
The action aimed to provide protection to both employees and employers. The above proposal could have the effect of making low union density industries' employees more vulnerable.

This employers association understands that in practice the only people who are actually ensuring that award or certified agreement wages and conditions are being paid, that safety conditions are being met and that superannuation is being paid are the union officials. The decent employers that are doing that know that they have to compete with the unprincipled employers that are cutting corners and cutting people's conditions and wages. They have to compete out there on an unfair basis. What the decent employers have said in a submission to the Senate inquiry on this very bill is: `Let the union officials do that job properly. Let the law be enforced properly. Don't expose us as decent employers to the unscrupulous ones. That is an unfair advantage that you give to the unscrupulous employers.' Sadly, that is the model we now have, and it is about to get a lot worse under this bill.

talk.start.para: —I do not wish to add much to what has been said by the honourable member for Longman on this issue. I simply restate what we think is a fair principle, and that is that unions should have a right of entry but they should have a right of entry upon request of their members. When all is said and done, we think that is a fair proposition. In some of the consultations that we have had when we have discussed this issue and explained it to people we have found there is quite a lot of support for that proposition. We will obviously reject Labor's amendment.

speech.para: In respect of freedom of association, let me simply say here again that there is a simple principle at stake: people have a right to join a union and likewise they have a right to not join a union. We simply want to ensure that those rights can be observed. We find it strange indeed that the Labor Party should be opposing what are essentially technical amendments to make sure that those basic rights that people enjoy can be upheld through the legal system.

I am not surprised they would oppose these proposals, because we find today that the Labor Party in New South Wales is proposing a system to require non-unionists to pay between $250 and $500 a year to the trade unions in New South Wales.

talk.start.para: —That has nothing to do with the amendment, and you know it.

—It does have something to do with it. It goes to the basic proposition as to whether or not you genuinely believe people should have basic rights to join or not to join an association. You talk about freedom of association but you have never been in a shearing shed in Queensland and had an AWU bloke come around, barge his way in, and basically muscle in and heavy people. With great respect, the honourable member simply has not had much dose of real life and an understanding of what actually happens in these workplaces. If you had some idea of what it is like to run a small business and to have a union heavy come in and start pushing their weight around, you would not make some of the rather more ridiculous statements that the Labor Party makes.
—View from the penthouse.

—The fact is that the view on this issue is the view of a trade union official. That is the problem with the Labor Party. Fifty years ago a lot of people were in unions and you could understand a lot of ex-trade union officials being in the Labor Party. People in modern Australia have been leaving unions, but the trouble is the front bench of the Labor Party is still run by former trade union officials.

speech.para: When it comes to a simple thing like freedom of association, when it comes to basic principles like your right to join or not to join a union and the right to run your business without being harassed by some union thug, then you people have a blind spot about basic rights.

talk.start.para: —Now you are going to harass the union members who want to be in unions.
—The member for Jagajaga should not harass the minister.

—Here is a classic example of this blind spot: here in New South Wales—and you all think it is great—they are proposing a policy, which you all support, where people who are not members of a union will have to pay $250 to $500 to a union of which they decided not to be a member.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That is because I am happy to support somebody's argument. I am prepared to support somebody's argument on the merits. In this debate, you are the ideological ones; we are the pragmatic ones. We just want a system that works in the interests of employees and employers.

speech.para: This is one of the most outrageous proposals the Labor Party has ever put up to basically dragoon people into a form of compulsory union membership, which thereby portrays your real attitude on this issue. When we hear the member for—Lalor?

talk.start.para: —Gellibrand.
—One Labor backbencher is the same as the next.
—She will be here a lot longer than you will.
—She has never lost a seat.

—She has never won one from the Liberal Party either. Let her start by telling us the answer to this: what is your basic objection to the idea that right of entry should be for those who are members of unions? (Time expired)

—At the risk of introducing some facts into the debate, we have just had the view from the penthouse of the way in which workers see the world. If we are talking about people who are in unions, who want to be in unions and the encouragement or discouragement to join, the simple fact is that all the major surveys I have ever seen done on unionism and people's attitudes to it show that some 40 per cent of the population say they want to be in a union. In fact, about 28 per cent of the population are in a union. What that means is that about 12 per cent of the population actually want to join a union and are being denied or persuaded or prevented in their workplace from doing it.

speech.para: This government has gone out of its way to take a very one-sided view of the debate. In his comments a moment ago the minister was at pains to try and talk about the fact that somehow all the ideologues in this debate are on this side of the House. I do not mind being called an ideologue in many respects, and certainly in this debate I can handle that crown quite happily. But to describe this minister as not ideologically involved in this issue is stretching things. I remind the minister of what he said to that business lunch in Perth just last year: `Never forget the history of politics. Never forget which side we're on. We're on the side of making profits. We're on the side of people owning private capital.'

That is what the minister said to a business audience just to make it plain to everybody that, when it comes to running his portfolio, he is not about an even-handed balance system. He is not about looking after the interests of workers. He is not about looking after the competing interests of capital and labour. What this minister has clearly placed on the record is an overwhelming commitment he has to the side of capital. If we want to be ideological about it, let me mention the hard-nosed ideology that has been brought to bear in industrial relations. And the minister is proud of it in other places. When he sits down with the H.R. Nicholls Society he actually beats his chest to show the H.R. Nicholls Society how macho he has been; to tell them how ideologically committed he is to the cause.

talk.start.para: —That is a vision worth contemplating!

—It is a frightening prospect. I am glad I am not invited. Unfortunately, that hairy-chested attitude that the minister likes to adopt in this regard has been at the cost of ordinary Australian workers' entitlements. In relation to the question that is before us now, there is no sensible reason why government seeks to prevent the enforcement of awards, the enforcement of safety provisions and the enforcement of other legal entitlements. But for ideological reasons this bill does just that.

—This is not a view from the penthouse, shadow minister, because I lived in a shed for seven years. We ran a little factory and I can tell you that I know your union mates first-hand. We ran a tiny little business, we worked like hell, and I know what your union thugs are like. Let me tell you a few little stories from the factory floor, because I am fed up with your ideological rubbish. You do not give a hoot about small business and you do not care about jobs. You know that this minister has been able to deliver more employment. We have got unemployment down to—what is it?—7.1, 7.2 per cent. You do not care at all for those people that are out of work, and you certainly do not care about small business. Let me mention a few views from the shed and the factory floor.
—Order! Before the member for Dawson continues, I might remind her to address her remarks through the chair.

—Indeed, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will do that. I am afraid my passions ran away with me, because I well and truly remember what it was like. I will tell you a few little stories about what it was like. I can well recall employing some people in our factory when the union rep came along. He was known as `red socks'—red socks in more ways than one. Do you know what? These people had been unemployed for 18 months, so they had absolutely no money and they had families. We took them on board and the union rep, who had access whenever he wanted, came in and said they had to join the union and had to pay up—I cannot remember the amount—about 150 or 200 bucks. They did not have it. I certainly was not going to pay it, so they had to leave. So much for unfettered access. So much for freedom of association. Way back then you did two people out of a job. I can recall a host of other things that happened.

speech.para: Those opposite talk about people being able to come in and have unfettered right of entry. I can tell you that when you are a small business trying to do a contract it is an absolute and utter nuisance. There is no problem with a union coming in and checking on the terms and conditions, if they have an invitation from a member on the site and the member has their identity protected. There is no problem with that. But we were being hassled all the time. Those opposite have never worked in a small business. Being hassled continually by the union rep was an absolute nuisance. I see they are laughing. They think it is funny. I suppose they think that 7.1 per cent unemployment is funny too. Is that something to laugh at? I do not think so. They are living in the past, because they will never get unemployment down.

Do you remember Mr Beattie who promised five per cent unemployment? Let me tell you what he is doing in Queensland, and the shadow minister would know this. I have been talking to some of the cane farmers. The Labor Party has done away with the levies that underpin research and development in Queensland for the sugar industry and the horticulture industry. It is not interested in the future; it is interested in the past. But what it has delivered in Queensland is unfettered right of entry. So cane farming families, small business, are just going to have the union reps walking through their farm, going through their books and interrupting their operation.

What the minister has proposed is fair, decent and balanced. There is nothing wrong with that. What those opposite propose is a walk in the past. They have no interest at all in the unemployed. They have no interest in small business. They have no interest in balance and fairness. What is wrong with a member issuing an invitation for the union rep to come in? There is nothing wrong with them doing that and checking the terms and conditions of their employment. There is then an opportunity, through the Employment Advocate, for the department to investigate any award breaches. That is fair and reasonable. Unfortunately, there are employers who do do the wrong thing—I grant you that—and there should be an opportunity for that to be checked. But what the minister is suggesting is absolutely fair and reasonable. But those opposite do not want that. What they really want to do is to ratch up their union membership. That is what this is all about—preserving their power base and forgetting about small business and the unemployed. I am totally and completely in support of what the minister is doing.
Amendments negatived.
